For the information of senators, I now table a list of the full ministry indicating the new representational arrangements. In all other respects the list is the same as that presented to the parliament on 7 October 2003. I understand the list provided to senators in the chamber today also reflects these changes.

—My question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister representing the Minister for Employment Services. Can the minister confirm that research into the Work for the Dole program, undertaken on behalf of the government by the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research, has found that the program in its currents form has `large significant adverse effects' in shifting people off benefits? Why did the government seek to suppress the findings of this embarrassing report for four months? Is it because the report's findings are in direct conflict with the government's continuing ideological enthusiasm for the Work for the Dole program?

talker.name: Abetz, Sen Eric
Senator ABETZ
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —I inform the good senator that I now have responsibility for this area in the chamber. I am sure that, if Senator George Campbell were as up to date with the ministerial arrangements in this place as he should be, he might also have been more up to date on Work for the Dole reports. The government welcomes independent evaluations of its employment programs by academics such as Professor Borland and the Nevilles. In this case, however, Professor Borland's study is simply out of date as it refers to Work for the Dole pilot projects that were in operation in 1997 and 1998. Since 1997 major changes to employment services have occurred. The Job Network, the Australians Working Together measures and the active participation model have been introduced. All of these changes have been about helping people to move forward by providing opportunities for participation and, ultimately, economic independence.

answer.para: A more recent and comprehensive study has been conducted by the independent Centre for Applied Economic Research. The study was undertaken by Anne Neville and Professor John Neville. It looked at the current Work for the Dole program. The Nevilles' book Work for the Dole: obligations or opportunities was launched recently. In contrast to the Borland findings, the Nevilles concluded that, on balance, Work for the Dole does help participants find jobs, in particular young participants. In fact, they found that, by international standards, Work for the Dole appears to be remarkably successful in helping participants find employment. As somebody who has launched a number of Work for the Dole schemes in my home state of Tasmania and who has also been at the graduations of these same programs, the confidence of the people involved in Work for the Dole programs is immense. In fact, if there is one regret of those who participate, it is that it lasts for only six months. Another key finding is that Work for the Dole has a positive and significant impact on employment. This is very encouraging and is in agreement with Minister Brough's department's own findings.

Mr President, if Senator George Campbell were genuinely interested in the answer to the question he asked, he would not be on the phone now. He is not even listening to the answer that I am providing. It just shows what happens with the Australian Labor Party. The questions committee farms out the questions. There is no interest at all from the person asking the question and there is no interest whatsoever in relation to the answer being provided.

talk.start.para: —I would have thought that, even if Senator Campbell were not interested in the answer, Senator Sherry might have been. But he is shouting so loudly—
—Order! Senator Abetz, ignore the interjections.

—Let me assure Senator George Campbell and those opposite that Work for the Dole has been a most significant development. It has been very welcomed by the people of Australia and it has a community acceptance rating well above that of the Leader of the Opposition. I assure honourable senators opposite that we as a government are proud of Work for the Dole. We will continue with it and we are always looking for ways to improve it. Unfortunately, to quote from studies back in 1997 and 1998 reflects more on Senator Campbell than it does on the Work for the Dole scheme.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the research was out of date, why did the government seek to suppress it? Can the minister confirm that this Melbourne Institute research has found that Work for the Dole participants are 12 per cent less likely to move off benefits than unemployed people who do not participate in the program? Will the minister now acknowledge that the facts unearthed by the Melbourne Institute demonstrate that government claims that Work for the Dole produces good employment outcomes are misleading and untrue? Will the minister finally accept the fact that, by keeping people on unemployment benefits longer, Work for the Dole is actually costing the community more?

talker.name: Abetz, Sen Eric
Senator ABETZ
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —Work for the Dole is not costing the community. It is of great benefit to the community. In relation to specific information, in scientific terms Work for the Dole has a positive employment effect, with a net impact of around four percentage points. This means that participants in the program are 14 per cent more likely to be employed 16 months after commencing the program than similar job seekers who have not participated. The beneficial effects of the program are particularly obvious over the longer term. The bottom line is that, three months after participating in Work for the Dole, some 32 per cent are employed or are in further education. After 12 months, this increases to around 46 per cent. Those figures speak for themselves and show once again why Work for the Dole has been such a popular initiative introduced by the Howard government.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Will the minister inform the Senate how the Howard government's responsible management of the Australian economy is continuing to deliver benefits to Australian workers and their families?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Brandis for his important question. The Australian employment market continues to perform strongly under the Howard government's responsible management of the Australian economy. The most recent labour force figures are outstanding. Australia's unemployment rate has dropped to 5.6 per cent—its lowest level in 22 years. The number of long-term unemployed has dropped to its lowest level for seven years. There are now more Australians in work than ever before. Since coming to office, the Howard government has helped to create almost 1.3 million new jobs. That is 14,000 jobs per month, which is double the rate of job creation achieved by Labor in its last two terms of government. We have delivered the goods on job creation. We have given young Australians the chance to secure employment for the first time and given existing workers confidence in their ongoing job security. That job security allows Australian families to plan confidently for the needs of their families in areas such as health and education. With business and consumer confidence remaining strong, indicators suggest that labour market conditions will continue to improve in the months ahead.

answer.para: What a contrast with Labor. Who will ever forget their bungled management of the economy, which put more than one million Australians out of work, sent interest rates through the roof and sent the budget spiralling into debt? It is an appalling record, and they have not learned their lesson. We have taken the tough but necessary decisions to get the budget back into surplus and to keep it there. It is this responsible economic management that has enabled us to deliver historically low interest rates, low inflation, to repay much of Labor's debt and to put more Australians into full-time jobs than ever before. Every one of these decisions that we took to strengthen the economy was opposed by the Labor Party. The coalition's record speaks for itself.

What is the alternative? It is the same old story from Labor: whip out the government credit card, put up taxes and run up massive budget deficits. We know what the results will be. It is clear from Labor's track record that history will repeat itself, with record high unemployment, record interest rates and record levels of government debt. You cannot trust Labor on economic management, you cannot trust them on taxation policy, you cannot trust them on jobs growth and you certainly cannot trust them to keep interest rates low.

talker.name: Faulkner, Sen John
Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. Minister, given that crews of previous people-smuggling boats, including the crew of the Palapa, who were rescued by the Tampa, have been arrested, charged and jailed, why weren't the crew of the Minasa Bone dealt with, using the full force of the law, like those previous people smugglers?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Faulkner for his question. Senator, as you know, we have a very strong view that people who seek to come to Australia illegally should have to come to the mainland. Those who attempt to come here illegally, if we have the opportunity—that is, if they do not make it to the mainland—will be processed offshore. To achieve that, it may well mean that a boat and its crew will need to be returned. I do not want to make a point here that the crew are not to be regarded as people smugglers. In many cases they are clearly involved and clearly do know what they are doing. I do not have figures on this, but there may be examples of where crew have repeatedly come to Australia for a fee in the past, or have sought to come to Australia, to deposit people here who do not have a proper entry permit to come to Australia.

answer.para: The decision was made, and was always going to be, that a boat that seeks to come here illegally would be returned whence it came or taken to another place to be processed offshore. Those arrangements in relation to the Minasa Bone have worked very well. The boat was returned in the direction whence it came and was delivered to just outside Indonesian waters. Because of prior indications to the Indonesian government, the International Organisation for Migration was on the island—in fact, they were in the town of Saumlaki—to make appropriate arrangements for the care, accommodation and that sort of thing for the potential illegal immigrants, and the UNHCR would of course be involved.

As to the fishermen, you cannot necessarily return the illegal cargo, if you want to put it that way, of the vessel quite as easily if you have accepted it onshore and then tried to return it, so it went back with the crew. But you should not assume that, because the crew have gone back, no further inquiries are being made about that boat or that we are not keen to pursue anybody who is involved in people-smuggling. I do not have the particular brief with me, but I was advised over the weekend that a number of people have been successfully extradited to Australia to be prosecuted for people-smuggling in various states. We continue to be very interested in pursuing people smugglers. People who are used as crew may be similarly placed to crews of boats that bring drugs here, for example. They may be able to give us information about who paid them, when the arrangements were made and whether they have been involved in this sort of thing in the past but may not themselves have been the primary people smugglers.

In relation to the ongoing investigation by the Australian Federal Police, I do not have information; Minister Ellison may well have. There are two aspects to our policy. One is that people who try to come here illegally should be processed offshore. If they are found to need protection, we do our fair share. I am advised that over a fairly recent period we have taken 80 people from Indonesia who have been processed under these arrangements. Equally, we have another view—that we should be in constant pursuit of the people smugglers, and that is continuing to happen.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given that Minister Ruddock stated last week that there are 2,000 further asylum seekers looking for passage from Indonesia to Australia, why did the Howard government let those people smugglers who were bringing the Kurdish asylum seekers go? Could you explain to the Senate where the deterrence value is in letting those people smugglers go?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —Senator, I had assumed you had a greater understanding of foreign affairs and sovereignty issues than is displayed in your supplementary question. The first part of my answer to you made it very clear that our policy is not to accept people coming here illegally. That means the boat has to go somewhere else. You would equally understand, Senator, that when the boat does go somewhere else, `somewhere else' is not in our jurisdiction. Therefore, we work in close cooperation with the Indonesian government and others in relation to the prosecution of people involved in people-smuggling. So you should not infer, Senator, that anyone has got off scot-free and that investigations are not proceeding. I made that clear in my answer. If you are under the impression, Senator, that we have the capacity to prosecute people in Indonesia, you are under a misapprehension; you are the victim of a misunderstanding. The deterrence factor is that the people smugglers are not successful. And do you know what happens when a people smuggler is not successful? He does not get any more customers. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, Senator Coonan. Will the minister inform the Senate of the Howard government's policies to balance the budget and retire debt and of how this has strengthened Australia's economy? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Barnett for his ongoing interest in the good economic management of the Australian economy. The Howard government believe in keeping taxes as low as possible, consistent with delivering the services that Australia needs. In this year's budget we managed to increase spending on health, on education, on defence and on other social services. At the same time, from 1 July 2003 we delivered tax cuts for every Australian, worth $10.7 billion over four years. The government took this decision because of a strong balance sheet, because we could meet our commitments and because we could maintain a surplus. In these circumstances the government believed that it was responsible to return this money to the taxpayer, and delivered a budget surplus. The government is committed to retire debt. Eighty billion dollars worth of debt was run up by the last Labor government before they were turfed out of office. The Howard government have reduced this debt by $66.6 billion over the last six years, with $8.4 billion paid off in the 2002-03 financial year. That means that we are saving over $5 billion a year in interest payments on this debt.

answer.para: I have been asked about some alternative policy approaches. Over the last few weeks the Labor Party has had some difficulty in agreeing on a tax policy. Things have got a bit tense on Labor's frontbench, with shadow ministers falling over their own feet to disagree with each other. Labor's shadow Treasurer, Mr Latham, has supported tax relief for those earning top marginal tax rates and a wealth tax, and it has got him into a heap of trouble. In 1998 death duties were lauded by Mr Latham as part of his `progressive expenditure tax', or PET. Mr Latham's preferred model proposed a marginal tax rate of 400 per cent—that is right, 400 per cent—on taxable expenditures of between $40,000 and $50,000. You find this in his book Civilising Global Capital on page 346. If you find this confusing and contradictory, Mr President, so did other Labor spokesmen.

Within days of his unauthorised spruiking on tax, his colleagues lined up to have a go at him. Mark was a marked man, you might say. Other leadership hopefuls—Anthony Albanese, Wayne Swan and Lindsay Tanner—were quick to have a go. This is not just another embarrassing Labor wrangle—it has exposed the very deep divisions in the Labor Party on tax. Mr Albanese wants debt financing for Labor's pet projects. Debt financing is just another way of running up a budget deficit or spending more than you have, whacking it all on the Bankcard. That is exactly what Labor did through all of the nineties until they were turfed out of office. As Senator Hill has just said, the Labor Party did very little to help the workers. When they were in office, we had a million out of work, we had record interest rates and thousands of small businesses went to the wall. Wayne Swan—who is not sympathetic to tax cuts—wants to spend more on services, more on infrastructure—

talk.start.para: —Minister, I remind you that when you are referring to members of the other place you should use their correct title.

—Tax cuts come about third. He has no idea, of course, where the money will come from. Not to be outdone, the leader of the AMWU, Mr Doug Cameron, says the unions are going to want to have a say—I bet they will—on tax cuts. We know that they do not believe Labor's rhetoric about this being a high-taxing government, because Labor wants to put taxes up. The Labor Party is adrift without a compass on tax policy. It is wide of the mark on policies. (Time expired)
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister advise the Senate of any further alternative policy approaches to good economic management in this country?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator Barnett, for that supplementary question. I have just detailed, of course, that the Labor Party is hopelessly confused on tax. It does not have a compass in trying to work out where to go on tax policy. It is wide of the mark in its tax policies and it is, in fact, having great difficulty in working out what tax policy might be efficient to deliver prosperity for Australians. As a principle, the Howard government, of course, is committed to responsible economic management, balanced budgets, meeting our commitments and then, in a responsible way, looking at whether we can return money to the Australian taxpayer. This government will continue to maintain its sound economic policy, which has delivered prosperity for all Australians for the past 7½ years.

—My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. Does the minister recall her statement on the Sundayprogram yesterday when she said that she did not know where the Minasa Bone boat is and that this was not important because it was people who were involved in people smuggling? Can the minister explain that the Australian government not only does not know where the Minasa Bone vessel is but also does not know where the crew are?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Sherry for the question. Senator, if I were you, I would not put too much store on inferring from one remark everything else you would like to infer that you think flows from it. I was asked—
—Yes, I did hear the question. I understand the remark I made, and the senator has asked me to explain it—
—Answer it!
—Order! Senator Sherry, you have asked your question.
—and if he will just zip up for a minute I will give him a go. But, if he is not interested, I am happy to sit down.
—Come on; get on with it.

—I will get on with it when you have loosened your jocks, basically. Now that we are all okay, perhaps I can go on with the answer. Senator Sherry asked about some comments made on the Sundayprogram and, in particular, whether I personally knew where the Minasa Bone was. I properly answered: `No, I don't.' He asked, furthermore, what was happening in relation to the crew. The mistake the good senator makes is to assume that I ought to personally have that information at hand. There is an ongoing investigation in relation to this matter. It is being conducted by the Australian Federal Police and, when the Australian Federal Police are ready to hand on to the government such information as is appropriate to pass on to the public, no doubt Senator Ellison will be the minister who does that—and no doubt I will have that information to hand. Senator Sherry is mistaken if he is trying to infer that something is wrong because a minister does not know something that the Australian Federal Police may well know and the minister does not seek to be involved in an Australian Federal Police investigation.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that the Australian government was aware at the time that the Minasa Bone was being returned to Indonesia that people-smuggling is not a criminal offence in Indonesia? Isn't the real consequence of letting the Minasa Bone people smugglers go, as the Howard government has done, that these smugglers get off scot-free and are able to engage in further criminal activity?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —Yet again, Senator Sherry indicates that he simply does not understand. The point is this: we have a policy that people who try to come here illegally will have to get to the mainland, otherwise they will be processed offshore. Labor clearly has a policy that says: `Now we are open for business. Bring the people down. We will process them onshore.' That is why Mr Crean excised from the transcript that he released of his discussions in London those portions which indicated Labor is about to have a big about-face and would like to process people onshore. The consequence of processing them offshore is frequently that the crew need to go to the same place that the people on the boat go to. You can draw no inference whatsoever that the crew or people smugglers are not being pursued by way of a Federal Police investigation. Nor, with respect, can you draw an assumption that the crew are in fact the people smugglers and organisers as opposed to simply being people who are paid money. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for the Arts and Sport, Senator Rod Kemp. Minister, at the Australian Film Institute Awards ceremony last Friday night several of our best-known members of the Australian film industry made very strong statements calling on the government to guarantee that protection for cultural industries will not be undermined as a result of the proposed US free trade agreement. I understand your department is responsible for briefing DFAT on the potential impact of the FTA upon the industry and for providing advice to the negotiators. Will you give the parliament a clear and unequivocal statement that Australian film and television content in both traditional and new forms of media will be exempted from the US free trade agreement?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator Ridgeway, for that question. Yes, Senator, you are quite right. There has been some press on this issue. Indeed, I am aware of some of the comments that were made by some prominent actors at the AFI Awards. I think some of these concerns are not based on any careful study of what the government has said. The government has made it clear that the outcomes of the Australia-US free trade agreement will not undermine the government's ability to regulate cultural and social objectives now and in the future. Minister Vaile, the Minister for Trade, who is in charge of the negotiations, has made these statements, which I think will equally give some comfort to the industry: `The government's direct support for Australian culture, including film production, will not be affected in any way by these negotiations.'

answer.para: The government has a very strong track record of supporting the film sector, and this is clearly demonstrated by the fact that in 2003-04 the government is providing over $130 million to the film sector. I would have to say that this is substantially more than the Labor government provided in those barren years up to 1996. In 2001 the government provided almost $93 million towards an innovative package of funding for the film industry, and that money is now being put to use in building the capacity of this very important sector—among other things, training next year's film industry professionals, boosting digital capacity and funding Australians to make film and TV programs that tell our stories in our voices.

The government are very proud of our film sector. It is a sector that the government want to develop. We are maintaining very close contact with this sector. They are, as you mentioned, being briefed on the progress of trade negotiations on the US free trade agreement, and their input is being sought. I draw the Senate's attention and Senator Ridgeway's attention to the statements that the government have made in this area. I draw senators' attention to the important support that the government already provides to this sector. I equally draw the Senate's attention to the important statements that Mr Vaile has made in this area. This is an important sector in the Australian economy. We are very proud of the film sector and, as I mentioned at the start of my remarks, it is a sector that we would seek to expand. Also, of course, we provide very substantial support to this sector.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I thank the minister for his answer and ask a supplementary question. I understand the government's support for the sector through subsidies, tax concessions and quotas. Is the minister aware that the Prime Minister has also recently commented that Australia is prepared to be fully flexible with respect to local content and, more particularly, new media? Given that the future of our cultural sector will be determined by access to emerging technologies and new modes of delivery for cultural content, can the minister guarantee that Australian content quotas for new media will be at least the same as those for current local content on television; that is, 55 per cent?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —If you had been with us at Senate estimates, you would be aware that there was quite a bit of discussion about new media. Indeed, it is very hard to predict in this area just where the major developments will come. I have pointed out that the government provides very strong support to this sector. I have pointed out that the government has made it clear that the outcomes of the US free trade agreement will not undermine the government's ability to regulate for cultural and social objectives now and into the future. I think that those are the assurances that are important to the sector. Quite obviously, we are listening to what the Americans are saying and, quite obviously, we have our views. I can assure you that this country and this government always have the interests of Australia at heart. I can assure you of that. Unlike, I might say, we have seen with the previous government, this government is—(Time expired)

talker.name: Faulkner, Sen John
Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate

talk.start.para: —My question is again directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. Can the minister confirm that her press release on 9 November stated: `The passengers on the Minasa Bone did not claim asylum in Australia'? Can the minister indicate on what basis she made that statement and whether she questioned the accuracy of that advice? Will the minister table any original advice she received?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for his question. Senator, you are asking me a question to which you already know the answer, and I have in fact put out a press statement to cover some of that material or at least made some remarks in the media with respect to that.
—You did a runner! No-one could find you!

—The statement that there had been no asylum claims made by the passengers was based on information available to the government's People Smuggling Task Force at the time the statement was made. As further information came to light, it was checked, and the details were made public—illustrating the transparency of the government process. Therefore, Senator, I do not concur with any inferences that you might want to draw. I note that Senator Ray made an interjection to the effect that I did a runner. He may be referring to the time when I had allocated space to discuss this matter with the media, when a young man, with some intent and at speed, proceeded towards me, referring to me as, I think, a procreating female bovine. I decided that it was a quite judicious move to say, `Thank you very much,' to close the press proceedings and to move on, which I did.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that, three days before 9 November—three days before that statement that the passengers on board the Minasa Bone had not sought asylum—the minister told the 7.30 Report, with regard to these passengers:

quote.para: I'm not sure yet that they are asylum seekers. I think all the facts point that way, but we haven't got that confirmed at this point.

question.para: Can the minister indicate what facts she was referring to when she said on 6 November that the passengers on board the Minasa Bone were most likely to be asylum seekers? I ask again whether the minister will table any original advice she received prior to her press release on 9 November that led her to make the statement—the inaccurate statement—that the passengers on the Minasa Bone did not claim asylum in Australia.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —Senator, the only person I know of in Australia who was of the view that a number of people, claiming to be Turkish or Kurdish, in the care of Indonesian fishermen were not possibly going to be asylum seekers was in fact your own spokesperson on this matter. In fact, it was your spokesperson who said that, for all she knew, they might be here to go to the rugby final. She was the only one who thought it was a joke. Everyone else clearly understood that there was a real possibility that that would be the case. I am afraid that it was only your own spokesperson who was treating it as a joke. The fact that we had regulations ready and signed to call an executive council meeting should such a boat arrive indicates that, from the very beginning, what we have been saying all along—which is that the northern islands provide an opportunity for people smugglers—has proved to be correct, and we were very wise to be well-prepared to have those excision regulations gazetted. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, Senator Ian Macdonald. I refer to today's sterling action by gold-plated Australians who have brought a halt to the vandalism of the iconic forests of the Styx Valley in Tasmania—vandalism by Gunns who, amongst other things, are destroying through logging and poisoning the habitat of rare and endangered species. I ask the minister: is it not the job of the regional forest agreement to protect rare and endangered species? What will the government do to stop the illegal logging of these grand forests by Gunns Pty Ltd and Forestry Tasmania?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Brown for, I think, the first question he has asked that has had anything to do with the environment for a long time. Usually Senator Brown's questions are about stunt issues rather than the environment, so I am delighted that he has asked about the Styx Valley. As Senator Brown well knows, there is quite a lot of misinformation surrounding the issue. The facts speak very clearly for themselves. Under the regional forest agreement, two-thirds of the Styx Valley is either in reserves or not available for harvesting—that is, over 66 per cent is in reserves or not available for harvesting.

answer.para: Furthermore, throughout the state, 86 per cent of Tasmania's old-growth forests on public land and almost 95 per cent of Tasmania's high-quality wilderness are protected in reserves created by the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement. The recent review of progress with the implementation of the RFA by the Tasmanian Resource Planning and Development Commission found not only that there was a significant increase in the protection of old growth but also that the Tasmanian government's commitment to ecologically sustainable forest management was clear and unequivocal. Ecologically sustainable forest management is all about ensuring that the forest resources are managed not just in terms of timber but also for all of their ecological values, including protecting biodiversity, wildlife habitats and watercourses and preventing soil erosion and land degradation. Certain groups in Tasmania contend that Tasmania's timber needs can be met from plantations, but this is simply wrong.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The minister might depart from his written script to answer the question which was about rare and endangered species which are guaranteed under the regional forest agreement. What is the government doing about that?

—The minister was referring to both matters that you raised: the Styx Valley and the regional forest agreement. I cannot direct the minister how to answer the question. I will ask the minister to return to his brief.

—The question was clear and is being clearly answered insofar as I have gone. The regional forest agreement does deal with these things and, as I say, it protects the forests—not just the timber but also all of the ecological values and that includes protecting biodiversity, wildlife habitats and watercourses. I am told there is no real difficulty in the Styx Valley. The Styx Valley is an area of some significance and that is why over two-thirds of it has been locked away in reserves, as Senator Brown well knows.
—You rise on a point of order, Senator Brown?

—The point of order is that the question was asking the minister about rare and endangered species in the Styx Valley which are having their habitat logged by Gunns. There is one minute to go, and I expect him to answer that question: what is he doing to protect their habitat?
—Is that a supplementary question or a point of order?
—It was a point of order.
—It sounded more like a supplementary question. Senator Macdonald, you have 52 seconds.

—I do not know how many times I have to say it, but two-thirds of the Styx Valley is locked away in reserves and nothing will happen in those areas—nothing will happen. That is a very significant commitment from both the Tasmanian government, who have the responsibility for forest and land management in that area, and—I might say with some pride—the Commonwealth, who initiated the regional forest agreements. Those agreements, as Senator Brown well knows, were started under our predecessors. They were on the right track, but they never quite got to signing them. Senator Faulkner was sacked from the forestry portfolio before he was able to put those arrangements into effect, but still it was a good start to the process. (Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the influence of Gunns in being able to breach the regional forest agreement manifest because of donations to the Liberal Party? Did Gunns donate $10,000 to the Liberal Party last year, as Mr Cheek the former leader said, or was it $25,000—the figure according to the Liberal Party director Peter Skillern? Is it true that the money has been laundered through the Free Enterprise Foundation to try to hide from the public that the funding from Gunns to the government has a corrupting influence, as we have heard from the minister's attempt to avoid answering the last question?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —I was right earlier: Senator Brown is not interested in the environment but is interested in stunts. If he had a serious question about political funding, he would not be asking the forestry and conservation minister; he would be asking the appropriate minister, who is Senator Abetz. He is not interested in answers, simply in stunts. Gunns is a very reputable and prominent Australian company that provides a lot of jobs and wealth for Tasmania. It is one of the most significant employers of labour in Tasmania and does a very responsible job. It creates a lot of export wealth for Australia and it is a company with whom I have a great deal of—
—And get a lot of money.

—I get nothing from them. I have no idea what money they give in donations to anyone. I suspect that they probably, like most companies, do support all forms of political parties. I do not have that information, but they are a very good company. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to Senator Kemp, the Minister for the Arts and Sport, and follows on from an earlier question. Can the minister confirm that Australian feature film and TV drama production declined in 2002-03, as measured by total expenditure, number of feature films made and value of Australian production? Given this significant downturn in the production of Australian feature films, why is the Howard government willing to trade away any ability to support and regulate for local film, television and new media now and in the future in the free trade agreement negotiations with the US?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —Senator Lundy, the second part of your question does not follow from the first part of the question. I do not know who prepared the question for you. As you would be aware—and as the first part of the question mentioned—it is true that there was a decline in the number of local films produced in the current year. We are aware—as, indeed, the industry is fully aware—that there was a decline.
—Why do you have to kick them when they are down?

—Senator Lundy, you have asked me a question. Do you think I may have a chance to answer it? I am just saying that we are aware of the decline in local production. There has been a very extensive comment made on that in the media, which you should be aware of. You should equally be aware that support for the film industry by this government has risen from the levels that existed under your government. This government has provided very extensive support to the industry, of which we are proud, and we are pleased to do so. That is the first point.

answer.para: As to the second point, I think a better question was asked by Senator Ridgeway. I am rather inclined to refer you to the answer I gave to Senator Ridgeway. What you have to understand is that we are in the process of negotiating a free trade agreement with America. This government signs treaties which are in the national interest of Australia. Certainly, a treaty along the lines of that being discussed has the potential—and now we will see what the outcome is—to greatly increase the ability of Australia to trade with the US and could have a major beneficial effect on the Australian economy to the tune, possibly, of billions of dollars.

We have made it very clear that we continue to strongly support the industry. We have made it very clear that the outcomes of the Australia-US free trade agreement will not undermine the government's ability to regulate for cultural and social objectives. We have made that point. As I said, we are not a government that trades away Australia's interests. Above all, we are a government that is very conscious of the interests of this country. Let me make it clear to you that we are very conscious of the interests of the film sector. The film sector is a very important sector in this economy. We are very well aware of the need of that sector for particular government support, which we are pleased and proud to provide.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it not the absolute right of all Australians to see our stories and hear our voices on television and cinema screens? Does the minister agree with Geoffrey Rush who said, `Young actors seeking work on Australian programs and movies yet to be dreamt up, delivered to audiences in yet to be conceived ways, will find that these opportunities just will not be there'? Or does the minister agree with Toni Collette—who won her fourth AFI on Friday—who said that it was a `sad state of affairs' when the government was prepared to give up the local control quota system for television? She said, `You're talking about changing the way we think and the way we express ourselves. The government is in crisis, not the industry.' I ask again: will the minister now act to have film, television and new media made subject to an exclusion clause in the US free trade agreement negotiations?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —Senator, do not take my word for it; why don't you take Mark Vaile's word for it? This is what the Minister for Trade, the person who is carrying out the negotiations, said:

quote.para: We will ensure that our capacity to support Australian culture and national identity, including in audio-visual media, is not watered down in the negotiations.

answer.para: That is the comment that was made by the Minister for Trade, Mr Mark Vaile. I think those comments should give great comfort to the sector. Senator, it is no good you showing me that rather turgid press statement that you prepared. It is another one of your boring efforts. The truth is: why don't you get a real policy?

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Would the minister inform the Senate of the government's success in deterring the flow of people-smuggling boats to Australia? Would the minister inform the Senate of any alternative policies in this area?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for his question. Coming from the Northern Territory, he obviously takes a very close interest in border control. We have a very strong border control policy and strong regional arrangements. I notice in the gallery a delegation from the All-China Youth Federation. I acknowledge and welcome them here and make it clear that we have very good arrangements with China in relation to immigration policies, for which we are very grateful. Equally, we have good relationships with Indonesia. We have been very successful. We have had regional cooperation and arrangements with Indonesia since 2000, and only two boats have been successful since that time in getting to our territorial waters. Part of the success of this policy is that the people smugglers realise that they will not be able to get people to Australia to seek a migration outcome; they will be taken to an offshore place if they have an asylum claim to make, it will be made and we will take our fair share of people who are properly judged to be refugees. People who want to seek asylum obviously have the right to have that claim heard. They do not have a right to dictate where it will be heard, and they do not have a right to dictate where protection—should it be required—will finally be offered.

answer.para: This is a very serious business. Some four million people are apparently trafficked or smuggled each year and we need to get rid of the incentives. One incentive was: if you come to Australia, you may be able to use our court system to stay longer and longer and eventually claim some sort of alternative migration outcome. That incentive has been removed and you can see the success of this policy with only two boats having arrived.

I am asked whether I am aware of any other policies. Up until recently, I had thought that there was a bipartisan approach to this, an understanding that we did not want to send a green light message to people smugglers saying: `Australia is open for business. Bring your tawdry cargo here, dump them off and we will process them.' I had thought that, until I saw a transcript of what Mr Crean apparently said in London and noticed that some parts of the transcript have been taken out of the copy that Mr Crean distributed. This is Mr Crean's excision policy: you say something in London which you later regret, so you cut it out of the transcript and distribute an edited version of the transcript. The journalists in the United Kingdom—probably Australian journalists travelling with Mr Crean—were right on the money because they said:

quote.para: We don't know yet whether these are genuine refugees though, yet we send them back. So do you support the sending them back before we've established that?
No. I think what we have to do is assess whether they're genuine or not. If they're not genuine, of course they should be sent back.

answer.para: Implicit in that is: bring them on down! We will process them here. We will take the burden of it. The journalists wanted to clarify that point so they said:

quote.para: But should we assess that?

answer.para: There is some more in this, Senator Scullion—there is plenty more here. Mr Crean said:

quote.para: Of course we should. We've got an obligation to assess that.

answer.para: Again, quite clearly: bring them here. The journalists, realising what is happening, say:

quote.para: So they should be disembarked on Australian soil?

answer.para: Mr Crean—pennies starting to drop quite rapidly—says:

quote.para: Well, it depends where they're ... it depends on where this interception, if you like, is made, and that's unclear. But what is wrong with making the assessment and doing it quickly?

answer.para: All of that, and more, was taken out of the transcript. So Mr Crean has said that we are open for business and he does not really mean it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister further advise the Senate of any alternative policies in this area?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —Yes, there is an alternative policy that I have not mentioned. I go to what Dr Carmen Lawrence has been saying. It is pretty clear that Dr Lawrence would like an alternative policy as she is calling for the party to take a more compassionate approach to boat people. In Dr Lawrence's language, that is code for, `Bring them on down and we will assess them here.' Labor frontbencher Carmen Lawrence is quoted as saying that there was a momentum in the party for a new approach, denying it would cost votes at the next election. That may be, but it is very clear that the newly elected President of the Labor Party wants a change. The other thing that is very clear is that Mr Crean has given in to that demand. He made it very clear in London that he believes Australia should be open for business, that we should bring the boat people down and let them in on the mainland. They will even put out a coastguard to usher the vessels right to our shore, just to make sure that they get here safely. `We'll assess them; we'll take the burden.' That is the alternative Labor Party policy.

—My question is to Senator Patterson, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Can the minister confirm that the Family Assistance Office, which administers the government's family payments systems, operates out of Medicare offices, sharing terminals and other infrastructure? Can the minister confirm that the government's two-tier plan for family health thresholds, which is linked to eligibility for family tax benefit A, will require Health Insurance Commission staff to access Family Assistance Office information?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —When we introduced the family tax benefit, which is of enormous assistance to families—providing additional funding in the order of $2 billion—we ensured that they had better access by enabling them to attend a tax office, a Medicare office or a Centrelink office. Therefore, those facilities have together been termed `a family assistance office'. In regard to assessing the Medicare changes that will be occurring—the bill is now before the Senate—I am not sure whether this is an appropriate question. I do not know the exact detail of how that information will be transferred from Medicare offices to the tax office and vice versa. I will seek further information for Senator Bishop and get back to him. We do have, for other purposes, information which is exchanged between various departments while complying with the privacy legislation. In opposition, I was one who considered that very strongly and was very concerned about it. We have very strict regulation and oversight of the way in which data is exchanged between different departments, but as to the absolute detail of that question, I will get back to Senator Bishop as soon as I can.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Arising out of the minister's undertaking, I ask the minister: what action will Family Assistance Office staff take to prevent individuals who are not entitled to family tax benefit A from providing a false estimate of income in order to access the lower $500 threshold?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —That is a detail that I believe will be debated and discussed in the committee stage of the bill. It is an issue that needs to be addressed. One of the issues is that we have to ensure that people have access to it but that people cannot abuse the system. I will get back to Senator Bishop with further detail on that issue.

talker.name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
Senator BARTLETT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. It relates to the finding of Justice Mildren in the Northern Territory Supreme Court regarding action to do with the detaining of asylum seekers off Melville Island and the finding of the judge, amongst other things, that it is plain that the policy of the government is to operate `as clandestinely as possible', the finding of the judge that even the information provided to the court by the minister's representative was found to be `quite minimal', the court's finding that `behaviour of this kind usually implies that there is something to hide' and the judge's comments that he was `far from satisfied' that detention was unlawful.

question.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I ask the minister: is this an indication that the government have something to hide? Why is it that they have something to hide?

question.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That was a very long question but there was a lot of noise on my right as well that did not help.

—Mr President, the plain facts are that I did not hear what the question was. I did hear a lot of preamble, at which point the time for the senator's question expired and his question, if he did in fact put it, was drowned out by my colleagues alerting you to the fact that his time had expired. If you wish to allow him the question, he will have to put it again, but he can only have a minute to do it.
—Senator Bartlett, could you ask your question briefly.

—I will ask the question within a minute—as I did the first time, I might say. My question relates to the finding of the justice of the Supreme Court last week who, among other things, said that it was plain that the policy of the government was to operate `as clandestinely as possible' and that even the information provided to the court by the minister's representative was found to be `quite minimal', the finding that `behaviour of this kind by the government usually implies there is something to hide', and the justice's comment that he was `far from satisfied' that the detention was unlawful. In my 30 seconds remaining, the final part of my question to the minister is: what has this government got to hide? Why is the government so keen to keep information from the public, legal advisers and even the courts about its actions relating to asylum seekers and refugees?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for his question. I have not read the full judgment of the Northern Territory court but I am aware of the remarks, generally speaking, that Senator Bartlett refers to. Putting aside the judge's reference to what certain behaviour usually means and whether the judge is therefore backing away from saying he concludes it means that in this instance or is simply seeking to get the benefit of making that inference without actually being prepared to say that, yes, Mr President, I can assure you that the government takes people-smuggling very seriously. When we believe there is a people-smuggling boat in the vicinity, relevant agencies go into operational mode and they are very careful about what they say, I think for quite obvious reasons, because there are people in the community who will take any opportunity they can improperly to frustrate the government in its objective of lawfully carrying out its policy. The government is required to act lawfully and if on any occasion it does not it faces the consequence of that. I have no reason whatsoever to believe that the officer who made remarks, if it was in fact an officer, or the barrister who was acting for the Commonwealth, said other than what they knew at the time.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Given the minister's comment or statement that there are people in the community whom they need to keep in mind when considering the way they act, does this mean that Australia's courts, including the Northern Territory Supreme Court, are amongst those that they need to keep information from? Has the minister received categorical legal advice that indicates that all of the government's actions in relation to the recent activity off Melville Island were lawful in every way? Does the minister also have legal advice indicating that the government's overall policy of ongoing detention is lawful in every way?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —Senator, the answer to your first question—does this mean that the Northern Territory courts or other courts are in the category of people from whom information should be kept?—is no, it does not mean that at all. As I indicated to you in my answer, I have no reason to believe that the advice offered to the court was not the best advice available at the time.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

debateinfo.title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: TAKE NOTE OF ANSWERS

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Arts and Sport (Senator Kemp) to questions without notice asked by Senators Ridgeway and Lundy today relating to the Australian film and television industry and the proposed Australia-United States free trade agreement.

speech.para: Once again the Minister for the Arts and Sport has declined to take the opportunity to rule out selling out Australia's cultural sector. It was only last week that the Australian Film Commission released its annual national drama production survey revealing a dramatic drop in feature film and TV drama production, which shows the extent of the harsh attitude that the Howard government takes to our cultural sector and in fact the policy negligence it is about to perpetrate. According to the survey, the production of Australian feature films has plunged by one-third, down from 30 in 2001-02 to just 19 in 2002-03, and total expenditure on feature film and drama production is down by 23 per cent. There were no Australian features with budgets over $10 million this year and only one in the $6 million to $10 million range. In the area of adult TV drama co-productions made primarily for the international market, there has been an overall downturn in expenditure in the foreign adult TV drama production, which halved from $102 million in 2001-02 to $51 million in 2002-03.

Incredibly, in the same week as these figures were released the Howard government have reneged on their commitment to protect Australia's cultural identity. They have admitted that they are prepared to trade away in the US free trade agreement negotiations any ability to support and regulate for local film, television and new media now and in the future. I think this is a serious case of kicking a sector when it is down.

It took John Howard and Mark Vaile, through the visit of the US President here, to really let the cat out of the bag. I think it is a disgrace that, at a time when the survival of Australia's film and television industry is at stake and they are suffering from a serious downturn, the Howard government is about to sell out the right of every Australian, now and in the future, to create and share in Australia's identity through the production of feature films and television programs that portray the diversity of Australian life, culture and heritage.

In a mean and tricky strategy to distract the cultural sector, the Howard government has spent the last 12 months assuring that sector and its representatives that everything will be okay. In fact, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Kemp, told a conference late last year that cultural support mechanisms, such as local content rules, would not be traded away. All we have heard since are weasel words and more weasel words. Despite the opposition and other senators giving Senator Kemp ample opportunity to stick to that commitment, all we get in this place when we ask a question is weasel words about where the Howard government is going to go and the extent of the sell-out. So why is it that the Howard government is so incapable of making a commitment to an exclusion clause? The only answer to that is that it is not going to, that it is prepared to trade, and everything that Prime Minister Howard, Minister Vaile and now Senator Kemp have said confirms this more strongly each time they have the opportunity.

The Howard government is happy to allow existing Australian content rules to be either scrapped or capped at their current rate in a bid to deliver the US free trade agreement, despite the industry needing more support than ever. That would be true negligence. And, of course, there is the issue of new media. It would be an absolute disgrace if the Howard government were prepared to trade away our future. Geoffrey Rush was absolutely right when, in the words that I read out in question time today, he said that what we have not yet even dreamt up will be disabled, locked down and prevented from having support mechanisms through the industry.

All Australians have the right to hear Australian stories. Without the ability to determine future local content provisions and provide strategic financial support, the economics of the film and television industry will determine that Australian stories are simply not told. That is why that support and the ability to put into place these regulations are so important. We know the economics of that sector will determine that those stories will not be told without that support from an Australian government. Our cultural identity is unique; it defines who we are as a nation. Labor is not prepared to sit by and see it used as a cheap bargaining chip in a free trade agreement, the details of which are not known and the details about which are being hidden and kept secret by the Howard government. Labor demands an exclusion clause for all present and future cultural content in any free trade agreement with the United States. For this to occur, an exclusion clause would have to be included in the FTA.

An exclusion clause was successfully argued under the Singapore-Australia free trade agreement and contains a specific exclusion relating to creative arts, cultural heritage and other cultural industries, including audiovisual services, entertainment services, libraries, archives, museums and other cultural services. It also covers broadcasting and audiovisual services, including measures relating to planning, licensing and spectrum management for both here in Australia and overseas. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I never knew that five minutes could be so long.

—It was a long five minutes, Senator Abetz, you are quite right. Senator Lundy has misrepresented the situation altogether. I am sure that everybody in this chamber, this parliament and the whole of Australia is very proud of the Australian film industry, and we all want to see it continue to prosper and represent the cultural identity of Australia around the world. The film industry has done very well over the years. We have produced some outstanding films like Gallipoli,Strictly Ballroom and so on—many films which have captured the spirit of Australia. Nobody wants to see either Australian film production or Australian television production reduced, and that certainly is the government's position also.

speech.para: Senator Lundy says that we are kicking an industry when the industry is down. Again, she is making huge presumptions about the government's position on the Australian film industry. This has all come from some comments that were made at the Australian Film Industry Awards last Friday night when a number of people, including, as Senator Lundy said, Toni Collette and Geoffrey Rush, jumped to conclusions about what might be contained in the Australia-US free trade agreement in respect of local content. Again, I have to say that these people are jumping to conclusions. The Australian government is keen to see the Australian film industry and television production thrive and prosper, because it is seen as important that the world hear and see what Australia has to say about itself.

The fact is that this government has given enormous support to the film industry. In 2003-04 the government provided direct support amounting to $133 million to the Australian film sector through funding programs, grants and subsidies delivered through the Australian government film agencies, including the Australian Film Commission and Film Finance Corporation Australia. These programs, grants and subsidies will go a long way towards ensuring that our film industry is able to train the future professionals in the industry, they will boost our digital capacity and they will provide funding that will ensure that Australians make film and television programs which tell our story as a nation not only on cinema screens but on TV around the world in the countries to which we sell our programs.

There is no doubt at all that this government will continue to provide that kind of funding to support the film industry. It is quite irresponsible of Senator Lundy—who sits on the committee that holds the estimates hearings into the arts and hears what Film Finance Corporation Australia and Australian government film agencies are providing to the film industry—to make the kinds of comments that she has. It is quite clear that the Australian government will continue to provide direct support for Australian culture, including for film production, and that will not be affected in any way by the free trade negotiations.

There is no doubt at all that the Australian film industry has done a great job, as I have said; but Australian films and Australian television productions have to compete on their own merit in the world market. That is not a new thing; they have been doing that for many years. We have had great success selling television programs like Neighbours and Home and Away on the international market; they have been very well received throughout Europe, in Canada and in the Asian region. That will continue. If these programs have universal appeal as stories about people, as they do, then they will be purchased internationally.

The free trade agreement is not going to affect the production of Australian film and television programs. The federal government is committed to supporting the Australian film and television industry to the extent that it is doing at the moment and more so—the Howard government has committed $133 million to the Australian film and television industry in 2003-04 for training and production purposes. That is a fine record. We stand on our record and we will accept no criticism of it.

talk.start.para: —I also wish to take note of answers to questions asked by Senator Lundy in respect of the Australia-US free trade negotiations. The debate surrounding the impact of a US-Australia free trade agreement on our creative industries has centred on the negative cultural impacts such an agreement would have on Australia. It is not hard to understand why this has been the focus when you consider that a bilateral agreement of this type has the potential to severely erode local content standards and negatively impact the quality and vitality of our creative industries, with disastrous cultural ramifications for our national identity. In Australia, 63.4 per cent of all new television hours broadcast on television are sourced from outside the region. Compare this to the United States, where 98.5 per cent of television broadcast is new local programming—and we have just received the news that our feature film industry is in decline. The days when we can go to the cinema for an Australian perspective on the world may be numbered. I do not need to elaborate on the cultural impact of this decline; it is very clear.

speech.para: There is another part of this debate that has not received the attention it deserves: the economic impact on our cultural industries and the Australian jobs that are at risk. It may not be as glamorous as a debate comparing films like Lantana, Breaker Morant and the television series The Secret Life of Us to Pulp Fiction, Saving Private Ryan and Friends. However, it is equally as important. Currently, our film and television industry alone provides employment for almost 50,000 Australians. If the government trades away its rights to protect our film and television industry, who knows what will happen to these jobs? There will certainly be a substantial number of Australians currently employed who will be looking for alternative employment.

Last week we received the news that Australian feature film and TV drama production declined in 2002-03: expenditure was down by 23 per cent, from $663 million to $513 million. The number of feature films made was down from 39 to 26 and the value of Australian production was down by 21 per cent, from $343 million to $271 million. You do not have to be a trained economist to see that fewer Australian films means fewer Australian jobs. We also must not forget the flow-on effects major local and foreign films have on local economies. From 1997 to 2002, TV drama productions spent an average of one-third of a billion dollars annually in Australia. If our film and television industry loses what government support it has, communities across Australia will suffer.

This proposed agreement also puts at risk a significant stream of revenue that flows into the pockets of Australian businesses and creators. Overall, Australia's copyright industries are worth $20 billion to the nation. Since 1987-88, Australian exports of cinema films, TV programs and videos have been worth over $2.3 billion. In 2000-02 alone, audiovisual royalties earned by SOCOG contributed $1.133 billion to the balance of trade. But a note of caution must also be sounded: these figures are dwarfed by Australia's import of foreign culture. Excluding the effect of the Olympics, audiovisual exports have dropped by 54 per cent over the last three years, while imports have risen by six per cent. This will only worsen if Australia sells its cultural industries down the river in the current free trade negotiations.

It is important to note that this government is obsessed with one feature in terms of the free trade negotiations with the United States: access for our primary industries—and if it can get that in an agreement, the rest will not matter; it will sell the rest of the industry base of this country down the river. Who in their right mind would expect a US Senate, in a presidential election year—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The government are always pleased to be able to join this debate, which has been raging in the last week in particular, following the AFI awards and the opportunity that many have taken to raise this issue. We are happy to respond to it. As we have in the past, we wish to assure those in the industry that the exaggerated claims and opportunism of the opposition are false and that our national identity is well and truly safe and secure. This has the look of an opposition overreaching for an issue, trying to win an industry that they once had, during the Keating years—the black tie and red carpet years. They have since lost significant support in that industry, quite frankly because of this government's record. We did not come in and slash and burn the TV and film industry at all; in fact, they were spared the famous 1996 budget cuts. This is an industry that has not had budget cuts at all.

speech.para: Recently, in the AFI awards, Japanese Story scooped the pool for best actor and best film. That film could not have come about without government support through the Australian Film Finance Corporation and through the Australian Film Commission contributing also in its own way. Japanese Story, a fine film with a good actress, was supported by the government. The Australian Film Commission has been part of the Australian film culture for many decades now and we have no intention of removing it. That has been put on the table in the free trade negotiations. I think the opposition are truly underselling—deliberately, of course—this industry's plight. In fact, I do not think the industry has ever been better. Look at the great actresses and actors whom we have been exporting—Nicole Kidman, Cate Blanchett, Russell Crowe and Geoffrey Rush himself. They are all great international actors and actresses who have achieved their success here in Australia because of government support. Little is it known and recognised by the opposition that Australia has some of the best film technicians in the world and some of the best advantages to film here in Australia, so much so that many films, such as Matrix 1, Matrix 2 and Matrix 3 have been filmed here in Australia. Hollywood has shifted much of its base out here in Australia.

There is nothing to say that this industry is ailing and there is less to say that, under the Australia-US free trade agreement, which is under negotiation at the moment, this industry will suffer at all. We have a commitment that we will not reduce the Australian content of the television industry. Why would we want to? Why would the Americans ask us to? The Americans have said that they are not asking us to make this commitment at all. As for some secret negotiations, that is classic opposition beat-up—they have to earn their pay each day. There is nothing secret about the US trade negotiations. At the moment they are quite open. I believe the Minister for Trade, Mark Vaile, has just returned from Washington yet again with regard to finalising this agreement. Why put anything on the table or publicise anything at the moment until you have a draft agreement? You put it on the table then for public scrutiny. Again, I say that this is an industry valued by the government and proven so with regard to funding.

In fact, I visited the set of Stingers recently, a Channel 9 high-rating TV program. Its cultural value and its employment significance are properly highlighted. They pointed that out to me, and I can assure you that the minister is well aware of that too. This is a successful program that can stand up alone against any United States competition—and we know that there is a great deal of competition. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I also rise to take note of answers about the effect of a free trade agreement in the entertainment industry. Before I get into the bulk of what I want to say, I should pick up some of Senator McGauran's comments where he indicated that we are exporting actors to the US. Indeed, that is terrific. It is great to see successful Australian actors performing in the United States. But our difficulty is that they are telling American stories for American audiences which then get sent to the rest of the world, including Australia. We actually want to hear Australians telling Australian stories. We want our Australian culture to survive this round of free trade agreement negotiations. The other point which Senator McGauran wanted to harp on is that the negotiations are not secret. I find that an absolutely bizarre statement. The fact is that the negotiations are secret. If they were not secret, we would not have to ask these questions in question time and the government would be able to give us appropriate answers.

speech.para: What we saw today in the answers to the questions that were asked was simply a lot of nice, warm, fuzzy words. Senator Kemp said all the nice things. He said that the entertainment industry is an important sector in the Australian economy and that the government wants to develop this sector and has close contact with and input from the sector. I think that is terrific. If he was saying all those nice things, why can't he give the Senate the guarantee that was asked of him? Why can't he agree to guarantee that existing and future mediums in the entertainment industry will not be subject to open slather, free trade with the United States? It is a very simple ask.

talk.start.para: —Because if you do it for one senator, you have to do it for every other senator. It's very simple.

—I know that Senator Abetz is interjecting. Even he must understand that these negotiations are following what we know as the `negative list model', which means that, unless something in the free trade agreement is specifically reserved or excluded, then it is automatically included in the FTA. That is what we are clearly asking for. If the government were good to their word, they would agree to an exclusion clause for this industry and include that exclusion in the negotiations. But, again, it is a matter of talking the talk but not walking the walk. While they make all the nice, fuzzy noises about it, the Prime Minister himself has raised the speculation about this aspect of the negotiations. In the Australian Financial Reviewof Saturday, 22 November, Mr Howard said:

quote.para: The line we have taken to date is that the existing local-content rules ought to be preserved in relation to existing media.
As to some discussion about what might apply to future arrangements then that might be part of the negotiation.

speech.para: While Senator Kemp can point us to Mr Vaile, I can point you to Mr Howard, who has clearly raised this issue and put it on the public agenda. To forgo our right to regulate future mediums is ridiculous in the extreme. To take that view is the equivalent of this parliament in the 1930s, prior to television when all we had was cinema and theatre, saying: `We will forgo our right in the future to regulate or make rules about new mediums.' Those new mediums turned out to be television and the Internet.

Not too long down the track we will see new modes of delivery in this industry, and we will see new technologies develop. If the government, by refusing to put exclusion clauses in this agreement, forgoes our right in the public interest to make rules and regulations in the entertainment, media, arts and film industries, it will forgo its obligation to regulate in the public interest. It is an appalling situation that we find ourselves in. All the government needs to do is to guarantee to the Senate and to the Australian public that it will include an exclusion clause in the FTA but, every time it is asked to do so, it simply refuses to do it.

The only conclusion we can draw from the government's refusal to do it is that it fully intends to trade this industry off. It intends to trade off this industry for access to agriculture or access to other industries in the free trade agreement. But it is not just an industry that we will trade off in these negotiations; it is our very culture. Culture is the essence of a people and it is the essence of a country. It is not something that ought to be simply traded off in trade negotiations between countries. It is something that we need to preserve. We need that exclusion clause. Australians do have stories to tell, and we need an industry through which to tell them. (Time expired)
