subdebateinfo.title: Employment, Workplace Relations and Education References Committee

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report of the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education References Committee entitled Bridging the skills divide.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.para: On 6 November the Employment, Workplace Relations and Education References Committee tabled out of session its report Bridging the skills divide. The title Bridging the skills divide sums up the main messages of this report. Employers, unions and educators agree that Australia is currently facing serious skills shortfalls which are set to worsen over the next decade unless action is taken. The report found that, apart from the well-known and persistent skills shortages in the health and education sectors, there are many skills shortages which are not properly recognised. Many of these are in the skilled trades and in occupations at associate professional levels.

The government insists that it is on track with training at middle skill levels and that training in the skilled trades remains strong, given occupational decline in the trades relative to substantial employment growth in non-traditional traineeships. In fact, numbers in training in the metal trades, engineering and manufacturing sectors have fallen disproportionately since 1996, according to the National Centre for Vocational Education and Research. Shortages in the metal trades, engineering and manufacturing, and electrical have become endemic during the last five to 10 years. This points to a serious erosion of the skills base in areas of strategic and economic significance which continues unabated despite the restructuring of the training system.

Because skills development in skills shortage areas has not been a policy focus there are now too few people with the required levels of skills and knowledge to fill available positions across regions, occupations and industries. Far too many industries have sacrificed investment in the recruitment and training of skilled people for the sake of short-term cost savings. Too many individuals, including the growing band of casual and contract workers, are being denied opportunities for training, to the detriment of their future employment prospects.

With this in mind, the committee majority concluded that Australia needs a new and refocused policy on skills formation. Far from finding that the government's approach to skill shortages is satisfactory or sufficient, as asserted by the Minister for Education, Science and Training in his media response to the report, the committee majority found that substantial or significant adjustment to the employment and vocational and educational framework is needed if systematic failings are to be addressed. The large number of recommendations in the report—some 52 in all—reflects the breadth of issues covered and the extent of necessary change. Many recommendations relate to the training needs of the traditional trades, skilled vocations, young people and the unemployed. Others are directed at providing a foundation for a more equitable and effective investment in skills formation, including training of the existing work force.

A major issue for employers was the need to improve information gathering and the national coordination of existing data to better identify, predict and respond to present, emergent and cyclical skill needs. The Australian Industry Group was particularly concerned about the effect of major resource and construction projects scheduled over the next five to 10 years, given that the skills pool in the engineering, manufacturing and parts of the construction trades is almost empty.

The committee is aware that predicting future needs is an inexact science. Nevertheless, employer and industry associations' requests are legitimate. The report recommended that the National Centre for Vocational Education and Research should be the collection point and clearing house for nationally consistent and integrated data on skill shortages and labour market developments. NCVER should also establish a database for analysis of key trends, with updated information accessible on a web site. Employers and unions—and the range of stakeholders generally—are also looking for more tangible progress towards a national framework for skills formation. This includes a more consistent approach to New Apprenticeships incentives and better targeting of incentives for higher level skills formation in national priority sectors.

More fundamentally, the committee came to the view that current reliance on the market and employer demand with some targeted innovation initiatives is not an adequate basis for skills formation policy. Academic and other experts pointed out that the current competitive business environment and policy settings create a disincentive for many employers to invest in skills formation and that training incentives under the New Apprenticeships system were not effective. Instead, it was argued that New Apprenticeships, which are supposed to fit individuals with industry training needs, may be driving the massive growth trend in low skilled, part-time traineeships at the expense of more costly, longer term and higher value training. Most of the short-term traineeships do not provide the necessary foundations for higher skill development at Australian Quality Training Certificate level 3 and above. While the committee sees the importance of providing flexible working and training arrangements to meet the needs of business and the community, it believes that any stimulation provided by government should be targeted to achieve the highest quality training and employment outcome.

The report recommended that, as a priority, New Apprenticeships incentives should be made available for traineeships at certificate level 5 and above and that for skilled trades and higher level traineeships the bulk of the payment should be made on commencement of the training contract, contingent on compliance with a negotiated individual training plan. This should go a long way to assist industry offset the costs of taking on apprentices in the traditional trades in the early stages of training. The committee also recommended that the government should support partnerships between the TAFE, universities and industry to expand opportunities for building existing skills and acquiring new skills in skilled trades and vocational professions.

One of the most frustrating issues was the coexistence of skills shortages and high levels of unemployment particularly amongst young people. Demographic changes over the coming decades, including the declining cohort of young people, make it more important than ever that all individuals are trained to the level of their potential and a firm basis for lifelong employability. Poor education and employment outcomes for a significant minority of young people has emerged as one of the most crucial economic and social policy issues facing Australia.

Another concern in relation to vocational outcomes is that current funding arrangements do not encourage collaboration between schools and TAFE in sharing facilities. The committee recommended that the MCEETYA Taskforce on Transition from School and ANTA, which are considering new funding models for VET in Schools, should evaluate and remove any disincentives to collaborative training arrangements with TAFE to facilitate programs in a broader range of industry and occupational areas. Fees and charges should not be a barrier to student participation in any VET in Schools program. Consistent with its view that all young people should have a right to 12 years of school education, equivalent VET or decent full-time employment, the committee also recommended that all young people under 21 who have not achieved this outcome should have access to career counselling to reconnect them with education or full-time employment.

An additional provision should also be made through the Job Network job seeker account to support 15- to 24-year-olds to obtain employment related training that leads to national qualifications, particularly in the traditional trades and areas of skill shortage. The report anticipated and reflected the findings of the recent evaluations of Job Network and Work for the Dole in recommending that these programs require more adequate and better targeted funding to ensure young people get the training they need to obtain genuine and stable employment.

In conclusion, let me also take the opportunity to thank the staff of the committee secretariat for the work they put into this report. It was pretty long and arduous at the finish trying to get the report tabled in time for the recommendations to have an impact on the recent ministerial council meeting and, hopefully, to generate some initiatives arising out of that meeting to deal with the issues canvassed in the report. I know that a number of the secretariat put in a lot of long hours well into the night completing the writing of the report in time for that to occur. On behalf of the committee I wish to express the committee's appreciation to all of them for the effort that they put in. I just hope that at the end of the day the outcomes will prove the effort to be worth while.
Question agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment, Workplace Relations and Education References Committee

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report of the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education Committee entitled Hacking Australia's future: threats to institutional autonomy, academic freedom and student choice in Australian higher education, along with the transcript of evidence and the documents that have been presented.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.para: As honourable senators would know, this report is the result of a lengthy inquiry over many months on the proposed higher education legislation bill. The committee received more than 486 submissions in addition to supplementary submissions. The committee was charged with examining the legislation to discover whether or not it would be deleterious in terms of the impact on quality, access, equity and a range of other factors in relation to our higher education sector.

During the year before last, the Democrats initiated a comprehensive Senate inquiry into universities. The result of that inquiry was a report, entitled Universities in crisis, which looked at the decline in funds that we have seen over the past 14 years in the higher education sector. It also looked at the issue of fees and charges and the general issue of cost shifting in relation to students, and it came up with a series of comprehensive recommendations as to how we could improve the sector. They were to: invest in the future and not treat higher education as a cost; develop business and industry links where appropriate; and look at the issue of corporatisation and why it is not working in our institutions, particularly the marketisation of university courses, both undergraduate and postgraduate.

That report looked at innovative ways of expanding the sector in a way that did not hit hard at students, particularly those from lower socioeconomic backgrounds and other disadvantaged backgrounds, such as Indigenous students, students from rural and remote regions and students with disabilities. Unfortunately, the government chose to ignore that committee report and its recommendations, just as it really ignored the comprehensive Crossroads process of consultation that it initiated at the beginning of last year in relation to higher education. Instead, it has come up with a series of bills and guidelines that are still incomplete. That debate is obviously taking place but I will restrict myself to this current report and its various recommendations.

This report argued that the legislation should be either rejected out of hand or so substantially amended that the government should go back to the drawing board. The report examined the issue of disincentives, both financial and psychological, for people participating in the higher education sector. It looked at the reasons for the introduction of HECS, even though many of us still do not believe in fees for higher education; we believe education should be publicly funded and accessible to all and that, in a progressive taxation system, graduates will pay and contribute to that system. However, this report looked at the motive behind the introduction of HECS and, inasmuch as we can examine it in Australia today, looked at the impact of the distortions to HECS—that is, the changes that were made in 1996 by the coalition government.

We looked at research—we looked at AMP-NATSEM research, at Dr Bruce Chapman's work and at ACOSS's information and we received submissions from individuals, organisations and research bodies and we were able to see that debt aversion is a big factor in determining whether or not students will go to universities and that the most debt averse of all are students from lower socioeconomic backgrounds. The report concluded that this legislation or the policies that have been put forward would not `back Australia's future' but, as we have said, `hack Australia's future'. The report's examination of the legislation indicated that institutions, such as the VCA and UWS, would be worse off, that the transitional funding arrangements would not be appropriate, that regional institutions would be the biggest losers, and that, overall, the lack of indexation was one of the biggest factors hindering the expansion of and the quality in our university sector.

This report also looked at how the Commonwealth Grants Scheme is funding the $404 million extra that this government is purported to be providing to institutions—although when I say `extra' I should recognise the report's finding: that most of this money for the overall changes to operating grants is back ended. Most universities, if they do feel any benefits, will have to wait until 2007. This report also concluded that the tying of that Commonwealth Grants Scheme money to coercive workplace practices was outrageous; not only that, it represented the single biggest intrusion into university autonomy in our nation's history. Beyond that, the report examining this legislation discovered that the privacy of individual students would be compromised—in fact, breached—as a consequence of some unprecedented proposed changes in law. So on privacy grounds, on institutional autonomy grounds, on financial grounds, on social, equity and access grounds, this legislation was examined and rejected by a majority of senators who participated in the inquiry.

There have been supplementary reports and I have done a supplementary report on behalf of the Australian Democrats. But in relation to the government's minority report, very few constructive comments were forthcoming. What I would like to see is recognition, even belated, from the government, in this report or in the future from the minister's mouth, that people will be worse off under this legislation. Some institutions have done modelling; some have not, such as Melbourne University, because they do not feel that they have enough facts and figures at their disposal to actually do the required modelling for the future funding of their institution—there are too many contingencies. Will they get the workplace relations money—that is, the Commonwealth Grants Scheme money? No, they will not if they do not institute the workplace practice reforms. How can you calculate that in your modelling for between now and 2007? That is not all—there are the incomplete guidelines.

This report found—I welcome Senator Tierney to the chamber—that there was an almost unprecedented level of ministerial discretion and, in addition, a lot of the aspects that will be enacted by the legislation that was examined by this committee are in guidelines that are still incomplete. It was difficult enough to hold an inquiry that had only the shell of this legislation without the delegated legislation that accompanies it. It is only in dribs and drabs that those draft and incomplete guidelines have come out. So the report into this legislation, the legislation that we are being urged by the minister and by some sections of the AVCC—albeit the AVCC has called for radical amendment—to pass so swiftly, is not only fundamentally flawed but also incomplete.

It is incomplete and it has some aspects that are unlike probably any other legislation we have seen relating to this sector—for instance, the radical interference in institutional autonomy, interference in student private records and a student learning entitlement that is basically cut off after five years. This report also found that the HECS hikes, which will see fees increase by up to 30 per cent for students studying at universities around Australia, and the fee increases—these being a doubling in the number of full fee paying undergraduate places—will see higher education in Australia priced out of the reach of many students and many communities.

The Democrats have made strong recommendations in this report that relate not only to the specific legislation but also to student income support, because the Crossroads inquiry, Backing Australia's Future and the legislation accompanying that process are miserly when it comes to student income support. In fact, student income support issues were off the agenda. It is argued, of course—and I believe the research—that student income support is probably a more pivotal factor in determining participation in higher education than fees and charges, particularly for disadvantaged groups. What has the government done? It has run down income support. It has made it harder for students to access it. It still has disparities between Austudy, common youth allowance and unemployment benefits when it comes to rent assistance and other things. When the government has read this report, perhaps it could come back in the new year with a much better proposal, a better set of guidelines and a better piece of legislation or two to tackle the issues confronting our universities—because they are in crisis—and do something that invests in our future instead of hacks at Australia's future.

talk.start.para: —I also wish to speak on this report and I begin by expressing my dismay at the disgraceful abuse of parliamentary process in referring this piece of legislation to the references committee. This is legislation. We have in this Senate two types of committees: references committees and legislation committees. This abuse of the processes of the Senate to send legislation for inquiry to a references committee is something that the Procedures Committee should look at. This negates the whole purpose of the division between the committees in this place.

speech.para: Why did they do it? The whole thing was a cynical political ploy because the references committees are controlled by the ALP. So what the ALP did was set up the terms of reference for the inquiry, they called the witnesses and they set up where the inquiries would be held. As a matter of fact, there was such a lack of interest by students in this inquiry process, with so few turning up to actually protest at the inquiry, that they got desperate in Adelaide and held the inquiry in the middle of the student union. They still could not get any students to turn up except a few interested in the processes of government who sat up and listened to a Senate inquiry procedure. There were no protests. When we went to the very first hearing—this was to be their centrepiece, this was to be the big media event—at the University of Western Sydney on the first day of the inquiry, I turned up at 8.30 and the only one standing out the front was the vice-chancellor. There were no protesters. They did turn up at lunchtime. Sixty turned up at lunchtime but 20 of them were members of the AMWU who had their banners up. There were only 40 students out of a student body of 37,000, and this was repeated right around the country.

Before the inquiry started, the opposition parties had made up their minds. They said so. Senator Carr is on record as saying, `We are going to oppose this legislation.' I shared a platform in Sydney at the end of August with Senator Stott Despoja and she said, `The government has got to go back to the drawing board and start again.' This was before we had had one day of hearings. What was the point of having the process if the parties that set this inquiry up had no intention of listening to any evidence or changing their minds having listened to all the evidence and having read the submissions? All those people put all that time in, gave us submissions, turned up to the inquiry and gave their evidence sincerely, but the group that set it up had no intention of listening to them. They had made up their minds and they had done it for cynical political purposes.

They have done this before. At the end of the year 2000 there was yet another inquiry into the university system. They came out with a report called Universities in crisis. Why did they do that? Again it was a political ploy in the lead-up to the 2001 election. They wanted this as a weapon to beat the government over the head with during the 2001 election, and what have we just had—

talk.start.para: —They should do it again, it worked well last time.

—It will probably have a similar effect. Where are their policies? This was the question I asked constantly throughout the inquiry. This inquiry was set up to examine the bill we are debating in the parliament this week. I asked each vice-chancellor what their preference would be in relation to the three paths that lie ahead of us. One path is to leave things as they are. No-one wanted that.
—That's the Labor way.

—The minister has said, `If we leave everything as it is in the university sector, with no change'—because perhaps this bill will fail—`the whole sector will be on a collision course with mediocrity.' There will not be enough money in the system in the long term as we try to prepare Australia for the information age. There will not be enough money to do it. The second option was the Labor option. It might amaze my colleagues, but the Labor Party has actually come out with a policy. It has a policy on higher education.
—Was it a discussion paper or a policy?
—No, it is a policy. It is a very detailed policy. It is called `Aim Higher' and it came out on 26 July this year. Senator Campbell cannot remember it.
—Nor can most Australians.

—Senator Ferguson cannot remember it either. The reason is that it sank without trace in one day. Everywhere we went around Australia, I revived this policy. I highlighted it. People should realise what is in this Labor policy. The so-called `Aim Higher' policy—
—Is it on Kimmie's web site?
—It is probably on Kim's web site. What Aim Higher will do is return education to its impoverished condition under 13 years of Labor. It will put it back on the public—

—No, it is not. I am just warming up for that. That is a bit later. It will put back onto the public budget virtually all the funding in higher education. That is what those opposite did under Whitlam. That is what was happening under Hawke. That is what led to a reduction of resources and insufficient resources in the sector.

speech.para: The third option that I put to the vice-chancellors at the inquiry was this package—a very carefully crafted package. The package has two vital new elements. One is to put $1.6 billion of public money into higher education over the next four years and $10.5 billion over 10 years. That is a significant public investment in higher education. What does the Labor Party have in its policy? What is it proposing in Aim Higher? It says that it is going to fully index. In the way it works its figures, it is all due to full indexation of the grant for universities. But all indexation does is maintain current value. There is no real increase in money at all. You have to be a game person to believe the Labor Party when it says that it will fully index. We are just taking it at its word. The Labor Party got rid of full indexation. The Labor Party has form on this. If those opposite ever get back into power as a Labor government and run into financial trouble, as they always do—they racked up $90 billion worth of debt during the time of the Keating government—

talk.start.para: —They will send it through the roof again—back into the boom and bust cycle.

—Senator Campbell says `back into the boom and bust cycle again'. If they get in, they will want to cut back budgets. Guess which they will cut back? They will cut back the university sector again. They will guarantee the impoverishment of universities because the other thing that they will not allow—and this is the thing that is in these measures—is the flexibility in the university system to increase the money from the private sector. Some universities now do not receive the majority of their money from the public sector. Universities like the University of Melbourne can do that. Senator Stott Despoja would have us go back to a free university system all on the public budget. I worked in the sector. That was a recipe for declining resources and impoverishment of the sector. It will not set us up properly for the information age if we go down that path.

talker.name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
Senator BARTLETT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —For the purposes of enabling further debate on what is a worthwhile and comprehensive report that goes wider than just the legislation—
—It does not. Rubbish. It is purely on the legislation and you know it. It is a disgrace and you know it.
(Senator Watson)—Order! Senator Tierney!

—Senator Tierney's initial ridiculous assertions that somehow it is an abuse of process for this to go to a references committee are quite extraordinary: there was not even legislation before the Senate when we sent it off to a committee.
—There was when we had the inquiry, and you know it.
—Order! Senator Tierney, please resist.

—It is unfortunate. The reason the Democrats support Senate inquiries is that we like to work constructively across the community to develop ideas for addressing the real concerns of the universities. The fact that the government has not been willing to do that in this area is very unfortunate.
—Why does Senator Stott Despoja—
—Order! Senator Tierney, if you interject again, I will name you.

—The simple message I would send to the government is this: if they want to deal with this seriously, they should go back and look at all the concerns that were identified by people across the spectrum that came out through the committee report. They would then have a much better chance of having people take them seriously. It is an important report. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

speech.para: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian (Manager of Government Business in the Senate)
Senator IAN CAMPBELL
talker.role: Manager of Government Business in the Senate

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That—

quote.para: (1) On Monday, 24 November 2003:
(a) the hours of meeting shall be 12.30 pm to 11.30 pm; and
(b) the question for the adjournment of the Senate shall be proposed at 10.50 pm.
(2) On Tuesday, 25 November 2003:
(a) the hours of meeting shall be 12.30 pm to adjournment;
(b) the consideration of government documents not be proceeded with; and
(c) the question for the adjournment of the Senate shall be proposed at 10.50 pm.
(3) On Thursday, 27 November 2003:
(a) the hours of meeting shall be 9.30 am to 11.30 pm;
(b) divisions may take place after 6pm; and
(c) the question for the adjournment of the Senate shall be proposed at 10.50 pm.
(4) The Senate shall sit on Friday, 28 November 2003 and that:
(a) the hours of meeting shall be 9 am to 4.25 pm;
(b) the routine of business shall be:
(i) notices of motion, and
(ii) government business only; and
(c) the question for the adjournment of the Senate shall be proposed at 3.45 pm.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Resolution of the Queensland Legislative Assembly

talk.start.para: (Senator Watson)—I present a resolution agreed to by the Legislative Assembly of Queensland on 11 November 2003 relating to Pauline Hanson and David Ettridge.
(Senator Watson)—I present the following responses to Senate resolutions:

interjection.para: From the Minister for Family and Community Services (Senator Patterson) to a resolution of the Senate of 18 August 2003 concerning domestic violence;

From the Chairman of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (Mr Samuel) to resolutions of the Senate of 27 June and 12 November 2002 concerning an order for the production of a report relating to tobacco;
From the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr Truss) to a resolution of the Senate of 11 August 2003 concerning livestock export trade;
From the Queensland Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Nuttall) to a resolution of the Senate of 11 September 2003 concerning health and tobacco; and
From the Minister for Trade (Mr Vaile) to a resolution of the Senate of 9 October 2003 concerning free trade agreement and foreign television programming.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the response by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry that has just been tabled.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: Senators will recall that the original motion was moved by the Leader of the Democrats, Senator Bartlett, who may also wish to speak on this matter. The original terms of the motion supported a moratorium in respect of live exports but Senator Bartlett amended his motion at Labor's request. No-one—and certainly not the government—should misinterpret Labor's action as representing a blank cheque on the industry's future. The fact is that we have just about run out of patience with the minister's neglect of industry standards and his contempt for Australians' concern about animal welfare in the live export trade. Labor understands how much this industry matters to Australian sheep and cattle producers. That is why we are committed to industry reform—and the program I released on behalf of the opposition in July this year proposes just that. That is why Labor continues to scrutinise the industry and highlight the manifest inadequacies in the minister's portfolio administration. It is scrutiny the minister wishes he could avoid.

Almost three months ago I placed a question on notice directly related to the veterinary report subject to the Senate resolution. As is often the case, Minister Truss has been unwilling or unable to provide a response to my question on notice about this important matter. It is a matter, I might add, that has been repeatedly brought to my attention by Australians who have written to me expressing their disgust at the government's failure to enforce minimum animal welfare standards in the live export industry. Almost three months ago I asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry what action he had taken to investigate claims of serious animal cruelty involving Australian export cattle slaughtered at the abattoir in Bassatin, Egypt. I asked the minister when he became aware of the claims of animal cruelty at this abattoir. I also asked what action he had taken to improve animal welfare practices at the abattoir and what improved animal welfare practices had resulted from this action. Labor will look carefully at the terms of the minister's response to the Senate resolution, but I would be surprised if any Australian were satisfied with his action. Words are no substitute for action, and weasel words on animal welfare in the live export trade are fast becoming Mr Truss's stock-in-trade.

None of the crises that have engulfed the live export industry over recent months are unrelated. The common link is the woeful performance of the minister, and no incident better captures the inadequacy of his performance than his response to last week's alleged sabotage of an export feedlot in Portland, Victoria. Today the ABC Country Hour program reported that no export permit would be issued for the sheep stranded at the Portland feedlot until the government got a watertight guarantee that the importing countries would accept them. It has also been reported that the government believes action on this guarantee is a matter for the exporter, and not the government. That is, Mr Truss is doing his level best to avoid any responsibility associated with the resolution of this latest crisis. He is the minister for agriculture but sometimes he seems to be minister in name only. Action is nearly always a matter for others. Unfortunately for Mr Truss, on this issue he can run but he cannot hide. He has a direct responsibility to assist in the resolution of the Portland incident. He is clearly responsible for the export permit required to send the affected sheep on their way to the Middle East, and clearly he has a responsibility to secure a market for these sheep.

Mr Truss might have forgotten about this, but a few weeks ago he was telling us how many countries he had consulted in an attempt to resolve the Cormo fiasco. The figure Mr Truss quoted equalled about a third of all sovereign nations on the face of the earth. A few weeks on, and with another trade crisis on the minister's hands, I now say to him, `Don't hide your diplomatic talent under a bushel. Take charge. Pick up the telephone.' The problem Mr Truss has is that he knows what the rest of us know, and that is he did not take effective action to resolve the fate of the Australian sheep stranded aboard the Cormo Express. He tried to ignore the rejection of the Cormo Express sheep in the vain hope the problem would go away. He only acted in response to a demand from the Prime Minister, and then every action he took was overseen by a departmental committee coordinated by the secretary of the Prime Minister's department.

For many livestock producers and exporters, Mr Truss's action in the Portland incident has a ring of deja vu. To ignore his responsibility in this regard is to repeat his failings in relation to the Cormo fiasco. Tens of thousands of sheep are stranded at the Portland export feedlot, clocking up a bill of tens of thousands of dollars a day, and the minister has elected to look the other way. Mr Truss has sought to avoid his responsibility to secure an export market for Australian produce. He has also sought to pretend that Victorian government tests on the sheep have some bearing on his capacity to authorise an export permit. I understand that the testing required to determine the nature of the contaminant and its impact on the sheep was completed last week. I understand that testing currently under way does not directly concern the suitability of these sheep for export. I further understand that late last week both the Victorian chief veterinarian and his Commonwealth counterpart attested to the suitability of these sheep for export.

This minister is becoming adept at lapsing into inaction when direct action is required and sticking his head up when he should not. Last Wednesday at 5.12 p.m. AAP ran a story on the Portland incident titled `Animal rights campaigners try to sabotage sheep shipment.' A spokesperson for Mr Truss told AAP that if claims by animal liberationists that meat products had been fed to the sheep were confirmed it was `likely the 70,000 sheep will have to be destroyed'. There has, of course, been considerable international media interest in this latest saga. In fact, stories about disasters in the Australian live export industry are becoming a staple of the international news diet. Comments from Mr Truss through his spokesperson that the sheep would have to be destroyed have unnecessarily complicated an already complicated situation. Those comments incorrectly endorsed the claims made by the animal liberationists that their actions would prevent the export of these sheep.

It appears the opposite is the reality. Tests undertaken by the Victorian government found that a meat product had been fed to a small number of sheep. But those tests also confirmed that the sheep were in good condition and fit for human consumption. Irresponsibly, Mr Truss leapt into the headlines to link any confirmation of the nature of the material allegedly fed to the sheep with the destruction of all 70,000 of them. Minister Truss should have waited until the testing was completed. When the testing was completed, he should have announced the action he was taking to resolve their fate. What he did was seek a cheap headline at the expense of the producers and exporters involved in the Portland establishment. Yet when I asked him to guarantee the security regime at Australia's other export feedlots, to prevent a repeat of this incident, the minister responded with dumb silence.

On animal welfare and trade grounds, Mr Truss must muster all resources necessary to resolve the fate of the sheep now at Portland. He must not repeat the inaction that characterised his response to the Cormo Express rejection and leave these sheep stranded for another 80 days. The live export trade is under considerable and growing pressure, and that is largely due to the man in charge: Minister Truss. I suspect that his response to the Senate today will give me no comfort that he has any greater understanding of the job that needs to be done than he had on the day that the Senate resolved to demand action in the vacuum of his inaction on animal welfare in the live export trade. One hopes that we receive the document expeditiously.

talker.name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
Senator BARTLETT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I will not speak long on this response from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, despite its importance, because of the pressing other business before the Senate over the next two weeks. As Senator O'Brien mentioned, this response from the minister is to a motion that I originally moved in the Senate that was supported by a majority of the Senate. The minister's response is about 1½ pages long, and I guess we can be thankful that the minister has responded to some extent. I believe that the response is still not satisfactory, particularly in addressing the component of the resolution which urged the government to do more to promote the refrigerated and processed meat trade to help move away from the live export trade, which is clearly unacceptable in animal welfare terms and is in many respects unnecessary.

speech.para: The minister's response to that is inadequate. It continues to run the suggestion that there will always be a market for live animals and therefore we may as well keep doing it. Firstly, whilst there may be a small irreplaceable market in live animals, it is nowhere near as large as the existing market. Secondly, I would suggest that running the line: `If we don't do it, somebody else will,' which is what the minister is stating, is simply not sufficient. You could use the same argument in relation to growing opium crops—which are in great demand and which we could make a lot of money out of—for processing and export, but we do not do it, because we do not support it, except for appropriate legal means. We could—and unfortunately do—use the same argument in relation to uranium exports, much to the opposition of many Australians, including the Democrats. There are any number of other industries that we do not engage in, certainly not to an unlimited extent, because we do not believe they are appropriate, including components of the arms industry.

I am not trying to equate the live animal trade with the arms trade or the drugs trade; I am simply saying that the logic of saying: `If we don't do it, somebody else will, therefore we're not going to do anything about it,' is inadequate. There clearly are enormous animal welfare problems that are not able to be adequately addressed, and they are certainly not being addressed. I would suggest that, if you look at the totality of the trade, it is simply impossible to address them. There is no doubt that a lot more could be done to promote an alternative trade, which also of course would provide extra value to Australia.

So there is an inadequacy in terms of the minister's response. I would urge him to give further thought to these alternative approaches, which I suggest would meet the widespread support of the Australian people. It is quite clear that a very large number of people in the Australian community are concerned about the unnecessary and unavoidable cruelty involved in the live animal trade. I have mentioned before this is the largest petition by quite a way that has been tabled in this chamber so far this year, which contains over 20,000 signatures so far from people expressing opposition to the trade and, I might say, seeking a Senate inquiry into it. That is something that I will pursue a little bit further down the track. I anticipate as many signatures again, if not quite a number on top of that, some time before the end of this sitting fortnight. I anticipate that 40,000 or 50,000 Australians will express their views on that matter by that means. It is a matter of concern to the government. I suggest that if they treated it more seriously than they are and went beyond some platitudes then they would actually get a lot of public support. I would urge them once again to consider acting further in relation to this area, beyond what is contained in the minister's response.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The matter before the Senate deals with the response by my colleague the Hon. Warren Truss, Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, to a request from the Senate. As the response clearly indicates, most of the issues raised by the Senate have already been put in place, and had been before the Senate passed the resolution. Mr Truss's response very clearly and precisely indicates the government's view on the issues raised. I think it is a very clear exposition of the actual situation, devoid of any political points. I simply cannot understand why Senator O'Brien continues the campaign to vilify Mr Truss at every occasion, whether it is Mr Truss's fault or anyone else's fault.
—He's a very good minister.

—Mr Truss, as Senator Ferguson is saying, is a particularly able minister, a very hardworking one and one who, because of his background, intimately understands not only agricultural matters across the board but particularly these very difficult and complex issues concerning the export of live animals.

speech.para: Senator Bartlett, I know, is concerned about the welfare of animals, but he is not on his own. He makes a big thing about it, and good luck to him for it. I would venture to say that almost all senators in this chamber would be concerned about the welfare of animals. I think you, Acting Deputy President Watson, originally started the animal welfare committee, which became the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee in a later iteration. We are concerned about animal welfare. But we all do like eating meat. I accept that you do not, Senator Bartlett, but most Australians do like eating meat. To eat the meat—whether it is red or white, fish or chicken—those animals have to be slaughtered. In Australia we make sure they are dealt with in a way that is as humane as possible. Similarly, with the export of live animals, we want to ensure that they are dealt with humanely in transport and so far as Australia has any authority. That is the goal.

Certainly the live export trade is worth a lot of money to Australia—$1 billion annually—and that supports a lot of jobs and a lot of communities in rural and regional Australia. We care about animals but we also care about people, Senator Bartlett, and people have to have jobs. We care, as well, about country communities. There has got to be a reason for them to exist. All forms of agriculture, particularly the live animal export trade, create employment and ensure the continuation of many of these communities. I have to say in response to Senator Bartlett that, with respect, he seems to lack an understanding of international trade matters. If buyers want frozen meat or value added meat then they will obviously buy it and Australia will supply it. But many buyers in many countries prefer to have the animals arrive live, and then they want to deal with them. That is a fact of nature. If everybody wanted processed meat then Australia could supply it, but everybody does not. Some people prefer the live animals and that is why Australia is in that business, as are many other countries in the world.

Senator O'Brien, again with respect, raised a whole heap of issues—and somehow they are Mr Truss's fault. If the live animal trade is under pressure then the people to blame for that are the Australian Labor Party. We have never quite understood what their position is. I do not think they do have a position. Their only approach is to pick whichever approach will get them a headline and will allow some friends in the media to point a finger at the government. Whether they destroy the live animal export trade in the process does not really seem to matter. As I have said on many an occasion in this chamber, if Senator O'Brien has a good idea—and it would be a refreshing change if he did—why doesn't he tell us about it? From the government's point of view there are no particular politics in the live animal trade. If there is a difficulty and Senator O'Brien has the solution, let us hear it. But we never hear it. We always get pinpricking, political point scoring and doing what the union might have directed him to do that day.

I did not listen closely to everything Senator O'Brien said, but it became Mr Truss's fault that there was no security at the feedlots. Do we expect Mr Truss to go out with a team of armed people to surround the feedlot and look after it? I would have thought security was a matter for the state police forces. If Senator O'Brien has a complaint about state police forces, he should get on to the governments of the states. They all happen to be Labor Party governments, so it would be easy for Senator O'Brien to speak to his mates in the Labor Party and get them to beef up some security. The action in Portland has been shown to be a deliberate criminal activity. I am not quite sure why Mr Truss is responsible for that. I am not quite sure how Mr Truss can look after security. What we need, perhaps, is the Victorian police force to beef up security in these places—or perhaps it is the Queensland, New South Wales or South Australian police force; I do not know. If you have a problem with the police forces, Senator O'Brien, speak to your mates in the Labor governments in those states and get them to beef up security.

Again I cannot quite follow Senator O'Brien's argument. I understood him to be saying that we should let most of the sheep go. Senator O'Brien would know as well as anyone in this parliament that if these sheep then get to a destination in the Middle East and some prominent person in the Middle East gets up and says, `These sheep are contaminated,' then we have got the Cormo Express all over again. That would suit Senator O'Brien because he could stand up during every question time, he could make speeches here and he could blame the government and Mr Truss. That is what he is urging us to do. If we do that then we get into that same problem.

Unfortunately, running a government, particularly with international trade, is not a matter of political point scoring; it is all about trying to get a good outcome for Australia. That is exactly what Mr Truss has done. Again, it has to be very carefully looked at. It is not directly my portfolio and I have not had an opportunity to speak to Mr Truss, so I am not absolutely certain of what approach he has taken. But commonsense would tell me, as it would tell Senator O'Brien, that with this criminal activity and people who are deadset out there to destroy the live animal trade—that is what they are out there doing—that we have to ensure that the government of the country of proposed destination guarantee to take them or deal with them if they get there and some prominent person in that country convinces the consumer that they should not be accepting them. That is what commonsense would suggest you have got to do. You cannot do that overnight—it is a long and difficult process. That is what we had to do with the Cormo Express. Mr Truss had a magnificent outcome there. It was not easy—it was very complex, but he got there.

talk.start.para: —I think you are right, Senator Ferguson: the Labor Party were a bit disappointed that it did end as well as it did. This has been a good response to the Senate. It answers all of the Senate's questions and I commend the minister's response to the Senate.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —In accordance with the provisions of the Auditor-General's Act 1997, I present the following reports of the Auditor-General:

speech.para: Report No. 11 of 2003-04—Performance Audit—Annual performance reporting; and

Report No. 12 of 2003-04—Performance Audit—The administration of telecommuni-cations grants: Department of Com-muni-cations, Information Technology and the Arts, and the Department of Transport and Regional Services.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee: Joint

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on its visit to RAAF Williamtown, Darwin Establishments, East Timor and RAAF Tindal from 14 to 17 July 2003. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report and to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.para: The visit provided an excellent opportunity for Members to familiarise themselves with the ADF establishments situated on RAAF Base Williamtown and the various Defence establishments in the Darwin area, in particular Northern Command (NORCOM) and the North West Mobile Force (NORFORCE).

During the visit to RAAF Williamtown the sub-committee was briefed on the role and operation of the ADF Warfare Centre, and the Surveillance and Control Group. Number 381 Expeditionary Combat Support Squadron (ECSS), based at RAAF Williamtown, has assisted in a range of overseas operations including the recent war in Iraq.

As part of the visit of Defence facilities in Darwin, the sub-committee was briefed on the role and operation of Headquarters Northern Command (NORCOM), and the role of NORFORCE in conducting surveillance operations in remote parts of Northern Australia.

NORFORCE is comprised of about 60 per cent of indigenous Australians who perform a vital and effective role in operating in and providing surveillance in some of the harshest environments in Australia.

On Wednesday, 16 July, the sub-committee visited East Timor where, at the time, there were just under 1000 ADF personnel which formed Australian Battalion Group Rotation Eight situated in Forward Operating Base Moleana and in the Bobonaro District. The Australian contingent is part of `Operation Citadel', the Australian contribution to the United Nations Mission of Support in East Timor (UNMISET).
The ADF forces operating in East Timor perform under arduous conditions and are again a credit to Australia. The sub-committee visited the Forward Operating Bases at Moleana, Maliana and Gleno.

On Thursday, 17 July, the final day of the visit program, the sub-committee visited RAAF Tindal and was briefed on the role and operations of 322 Combat Support Wing and 75 Squadron. RAAF F/A-18 Hornets from 75 Squadron were involved in operations in the War in Iraq and received praise for their professionalism and skill.
In conclusion, ADF personnel, operating in a range of diverse environments, continue to demonstrate professionalism, dedication and expertise.
Mr President, I commend the Report to the Senate.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —At the request of the Chair of the Community Affairs Legislation Committee, Senator Humphries, I present additional information received by the committee relating to hearings on the budget estimates for 2003-04, there being five volumes.

—As Chair of the Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee, I present additional information received by the committee relating to hearings on the budget estimates for 2003-04, there being three volumes and attachments.
