The controversy also meant that Dr Shergold would have to have been particularly aware of the implications of what he was saying to me at the Senate estimates committee the following week. Shergold's department, while considering my question for two hours, must also have been aware of the sensitivity of the issue before advising the secretary.
And of course Dr Shergold was present when Professor Sara mentioned the government's legislative program as a possible qualification.

But after all that, Dr Shergold's answer was unequivocal. He said “harvesting activity will not take place in either facility”. He did not say “harvesting activity will not take place in either facility, provided current legislation and commercial arrangements do not change”. He could have said that but he didn't. In fact, in a controversial area like this you would expect him to be careful.

The only significant thing that appears to have changed between Dr Shergold's commitment and the Minister for Science notifying me that they had gone back on their word was the convenience of the commitment. Quite simply, a commitment was made to the Committee because it was convenient to placate me. The commitment subsequently became inconvenient and it was discarded. No government should operate that way.

The biggest disappointment to me is that the Minister for Science was dragged into this deception. He was not willing to challenge departmental advice and apparently decided that human embryo research should take priority over a commitment to colleagues. Did his senior Minister, the Minister for Education, Science and Training also agree to this course of action? Trust is an important social good. The currency of political life and negotiation is trust. Without trust, I will find it very difficult to deal with this portfolio.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to talk about the importance of participation in sport, in recreational pursuits and, in fact, in any physical activity. Regular exercise, whether as organised sport or other forms of physical activity, is of immense benefit to health. Research indicates that regular exercise can reduce risks for conditions like heart disease and type 2 diabetes, it can help to improve mental illness and it can improve the quality of life after strokes and heart attacks.

speech.para: The link between physical activity and improved health outcomes is not a new concept. Doctors, allied health professionals, sports scientists and fitness enthusiasts have known for many years that the human body responds positively to physical activity. What is new is the massive impact that the increasing incidence of preventable lifestyle diseases, like type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular conditions, are having on the general health of this nation. These lifestyle diseases are so named because they can develop as a result of unhealthy lifestyle habits—namely, eating a diet that is too high in overall energy content and failing to maintain adequate exercise levels.

It is truly ironic that at this time, when we understand more than ever before the value that physical activity offers to both individuals and communities, fewer Australians are exercising regularly. While on the surface the statistics seem to indicate that Australians are physically active, closer examination indicates that participation levels are dangerously low.

The Participation in Exercise, Recreation and Sport Survey, ERASS, collects information on the types of exercise, recreation and sports activities Australians aged 15 and over have participated in during the past 12 months. The latest ERASS report showed that last year 77.8 per cent of Australians were physically active. This statistic would lead you to believe that the majority of Australians are reasonably active. In actual fact, this statistic, although accurate, is entirely misleading. What this statistic shows is that 11.9 million Australians, or 77.8 per cent, participated in at least one physical activity in the past 12 months. The true story is revealed in participation frequency statistics. They show that in actual fact only 38.8 per cent of the Australian population aged 15 or over participated in exercise, recreation or sport activities an average of three times a week or more—the bare minimum recommended for maintaining good health. Only 50.7 per cent participated an average of two or more times per week, and 59.9 per cent once a week.

In reality, participation rates in this country are grossly inadequate. Unfortunately, these misleading participation statistics and all of our enthusiasm for our elite international sporting successes have lulled us into a false sense of superior fitness. While elite sport has flourished, participation has floundered as people have grown more content to support our national heroes from the stands or the comfort of their own lounge room rather than participate themselves.

The Howard government have not helped the participation cause; in fact the evidence shows that they have gone out of their way to hinder the growth of participation. A grand total of 13 per cent of the government's entire sports budget for this country was spent on encouraging participation programs in 2002-03—only 13 per cent. This was down from 19 per cent in the 2001-02 budget. In order to make it appear that the decreased funds still reached the majority, the Howard government pared down their sport and recreation funding mandate to include only organised sport and to exclude recreational pursuits. This has left a massive hole in the broader recreational sector and indeed in promoting participation. The latest ERASS report shows that the activities most Australians participated in regularly were walking, aerobics or fitness workouts and weight training. These are hardly activities that fit into the Howard government's very slender definition of sport.

In aggregate terms, people relying on clubs, schools or associations to organise their sport and recreation are indeed in the minority. The majority arrange their activity independently of these types of organisations. The Howard government's narrow and narrow-minded perception of recreational activities as a second rate cultural pastime has resulted in the millions of Australians who regularly engage in recreational and semi-structured physical activities effectively being ignored by public policy.

Participation in any kind of physical activity, be it organised sport or personal recreational pursuits, is critical to the health of this nation, and more funding and support needs to go towards the participation activities that currently do not fall within the Howard government's narrow definition of sport. The opportunity to participate in sport and recreation activities, particularly at the community level, is a basic right of every Australian. It is an elemental expectation that we, as the elected legislators of this country, must deliver.

The need for a coordinated approach to encouraging participation is more important now than it ever has been before as lifestyles become more sedentary. A major pillar of policy must be participation in physical activity and our goal must be to get more Australians physically active. The need for a strategically focused, federally coordinated approach to tackling this issue has never been more important than right now.

There are two key elements for change. One is a change in the concept of physical activity away from an oversimplified mainstream sport definition to a broader physical activity mandate. All physical activities must be considered eligible for funding if we are to see the required massive increase in physical activity participation rates across all demographics in Australia. The second element is interaction, and by that I mean that we need to strengthen the links between federal, state and local governments, communities, the education system and the private sector. The key to success is to get these sectors working together towards a common goal.

The Healthpact Australian Masters Games offers an excellent example of the health and sport industries working together to promote participation. The Masters Games promote the benefits of a healthy and active lifestyle to all participants with the emphasis being not on winning or having the fastest time but on participation, having fun, feeling good and enjoying yourself. For many the Masters Games becomes the motivation to step up the amount of physical exercise or perhaps get involved once again after a period of not doing anything.

The Australian Masters Games, now in their ninth year, have continually grown and now attract over 10,000 participants in more than 50 disciplines. The Masters Games encourage the over 30s in most sports to stay active by providing participants with the opportunity to compete on a national level. The Masters Games have shown that by working together we can increase the participation rates. I would like to congratulate organisers, volunteers, participants and sponsors for the excellent Masters Games that was conducted in Canberra just a few weeks ago.

Overall, the decline in physical activity participation rates cannot be allowed to continue. Less than half of Australia's population are as physically active as is recommended. This is not only having an impact on our health care system and health care costs but, more importantly, it is having an impact on the quality of Australians' lives. Participation in physical activity is an important part of life that brings a wide range of health and social benefits to individuals, to communities and overall to the nation.

Promoting better health and wellbeing for all Australians is a fundamental government responsibility and it is essential that we provide easily accessible and affordable participation opportunities for all Australians. That is one reason why Labor have released our policy on tackling obesity and improving overall community wellbeing. Our policy is built around a community development model that will help communities empower themselves and organise the sorts of events that suit them in their own communities to increase physical participation levels. Here is an example of Labor putting policies in place that match our view of the outcomes that we believe Australians deserve in improving their health and wellbeing.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 June 2003:

question.para: (1) How much notice did Telstra give its `communic8' customers in Southern Tasmania that the promotion providing free 15 minute calls to other Telstra mobiles would not be renewed after 15 February.

(2) With reference to the statement by a Telstra spokesman on 18 February 2003 in the Mercury that `there was a need to review the promotion', has Telstra conducted the review; if so, what was the outcome.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Telstra advised that the closing date of the Talk L8 promotion, which included free 15 minute calls to other Communic8 mobiles, was 31 December 2002, as set out in the terms and conditions of the promotion. I am advised that all Communic8 customers were advised of this closing date. Telstra further advised that it let the promotion run past this date, and it was withdrawn on 15 February 2003.

Telstra advised that it did not directly advise customers of the extension of the promotion, as Telstra considered the extension could only be beneficial to customers. Telstra further advised that it also did not directly advise customers of the new closing date for the promotion, however the Telstra Communic8 website, Telstra front-of-house consultants and the Communic8 Welcome Letters sent to new customers all referenced the new date. I understand that the closure of the promotion was confirmed via an SMS message to all Communic8 pre-paid customers on 16 and 17 February, and new customers were advised of the closure via a recorded voice announcement from 16 February when they first used the service.

(2) Telstra advised that a review of Telstra's pre-paid product was conducted in 2002 for the first time in the 6 years since its introduction. I understand that this review led to the changes in the Talk L8 promotion and then to a Telstra announcement on 13 March 2003 outlining further changes to the Telstra pre-paid product.

Telstra advised that the changes included some price changes and a new off-peak bonus offer to replace Talk L8, called `One cent for One Minute'. I am advised that the new offer provides customers with access to low cost mobile calls to a larger group of mobile phone users and for a longer period than Talk L8.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 26 June 2003:

question.para: With reference to Tasmania's rainforests, including those on private lands, and their conversion to plantations under the Government's Regional Forest Agreement:
(1) What area and percentage of the original area remained in 1996.
(2) Since 1996, what area and percentage of the rainforests has been converted to plantations.
(3) From 1996, what area and percentage of the rainforests will be converted to plantations.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The area of rainforest mapped in 1996 for the purposes of the Comprehensive Regional Assessment of Tasmania's forests was 600,700 hectares. This is 93 per cent of the approximately 646,560 hectares covered by rainforest in 1750.

(2) The report Sustainability Indicators for Tasmanian Forests 1996-2001 prepared for the first five year review of the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement records there were 598,100 hectares of rainforest in 2001, a decrease of 2,600 hectares since 1996 or 0.4 per cent of the estimated 1750 area. It is not known how much of this decrease was a result of conversion to plantations. It is also recorded that 411,170 hectares (68 per cent of the 1996 area) of rainforest are now in reserves.

(3) The Tasmanian Forest Practices Board records in its Annual Report for 2001-2002 that the conversion of a further 1135 hectares of rainforest (or 0.18 per cent of the 1750 area) to other uses was approved, but not necessarily converted, in 2001-2002. No information is available on possible future conversion of rainforest to plantations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 26 June 2003:

question.para: With reference to Tasmania's native forests and their conversion to plantations under the Government's Regional Forest Agreement (RFA):
(1) What area and percentage of Tasmania's original native forest cover remained in 1996.
(2) Since 1996, what additional area and percentage of the remaining area has been converted.
(3) From 1996, what further area and percentage of the remaining area will be converted.
(4) Where, in the RFA, are these parameters set out and agreed to.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The area of native forest mapped in 1996 for the purposes of the Comprehensive Regional Assessment of Tasmania's forests was 3,207,300 hectares. This is 67 per cent of the approximately 4,822,000 hectares covered by native forest in 1750.

(2) The report Sustainability Indicators for Tasmanian Forests 1996-2001 prepared for the first five year review of the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement records that there were 3,169,200 hectares of native forest in 2001, a decrease of 38,100 hectares since 1996 or 0.8 per cent of the estimated 1750 area. It is not known how much of this decrease was a result of conversion to plantations. It is also recorded that 1,271,200 hectares (40 per cent of the 1996 area) of native forest are now in reserves.

(3) The Tasmanian Forest Practices Board records in its Annual Report for 2001-2002 that the conversion of a further 9294 hectares of native forest (or 0.2 per cent of the 1750 area) to other uses was approved, but not necessarily converted, in 2001-2002. No information is available on possible future conversion of native forest to plantations.
(4) The broad policy framework by which the Tasmanian Government agreed to maintain a permanent forest estate is set out in Clause 60 and Attachment 9 of the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 26 June 2003:

question.para: With reference to Tasmanian forests on public and private lands, under the Regional Forest Agreement planning:

(1) (a) How many specific coupes have been assured for: (i) clearfell logging, and (ii) selective logging; and (b) in each case, how many of the coupes were assessed by a qualified: (i) archaeologist or anthropologist, (ii) botanist, (iii) zoologist, (iv) geologist, and (v) pleontologist.
(2) If figures are not kept, is it a fact, in each case, that much less than one quarter of the coupes were assessed.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Day-to-day management of Tasmania's forests, including planning, is a State responsibility. Therefore, the Tasmanian RFA does not specify specific coupes for clearfelling or selective logging. The Tasmanian Forest Practices System provides that special values for all areas subject to forestry operations are identified and considered in planning. The Tasmanian Forest Practices Board employs specialist scientists in the fields of botany, zoology, archaeology, geomorphology, landscape, soil and water to provide expert advice and input to forest practices plans. The Forest Practices Board's Annual Reports detail the number of plans certified and the area of forest approved for harvesting by different methods. The Commonwealth does not keep details on the number of coupes assessed by specialist scientists.
(2) As provided in (1) above, the Commonwealth does not keep figures on coupes assessed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 26 June 2003:

question.para: (1) On how many occasions since 1997 have representatives of the Commonwealth Government inspected proposed or active logging sites under the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement to make independent assessments.
(2) What did these assessors report.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Under the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement there is no requirement for the Commonwealth to conduct inspections of proposed or active harvesting sites or make independent assessments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 28 July 2003:

question.para: (1) Can a breakdown be provided of all expenditure (such as advertising costs, administrative costs, staff costs, agents fees, consultants fees, design fees etc) incurred by the Government in preparing for the sale and leaseback of Russell Offices in Canberra.
(2) Given that the proposed sale of Russell Offices has been abandoned, has any compensation been paid to the property sales consultant that won a $264 000 contract to manage the sale process.
(3) Has any money out of the $264 000 been paid to the contractor.
(4) Has the contractor made any claim against the Commonwealth for damages and/or compensation as a result of the abandonment of the proposed sale.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator Minchin
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. Work commenced on the sale process in July 2002 with the appointment of the Lead Transaction Manager in October 2002. A breakdown of costs incurred for the period from 1 July 2002 to 30 June 2003 is presented as follows:
(2) No compensation has been paid to the property sales agent.
(3) Yes. Costs of $43,225.00 (GST exclusive) have been paid to the property sales agent for work completed up to the time that the decision was made not to proceed with the sale.
(4) The property sales agent has not made any claim against the Commonwealth for damages and/or compensation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 1 August 2003:

question.para: Further to the answer to question on notice no. 1370 concerning the northern peninsula of Recherche Bay, Tasmania

(1) What steps is the Commonwealth taking to establish the significance of the cultural landscape of the northern peninsula of Recherche Bay, including all the areas occupied and traversed by the D'Entrecasteaux expedition.

(2) Has the Commonwealth commissioned research to establish the significance of the area; if so: (a) who is undertaking the research; (b) how much will it cost; (c) when will it be completed; and (d) will the report be made public.
(3) When will the Commonwealth be in a position to consider the issue of acquisition.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Heritage Commission is currently awaiting a heritage assessment for Recherche Bay, Tasmania, to be provided by the Tasmanian Heritage Council.
(3) As the heritage values of the place have not yet been assessed it is premature to consider whether acquisition is the most appropriate course of action.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 1 August 2003:

question.para: (1) What is the current total capacity of Australia's domestic excisable fuel ethanol production.

answer.para: According to figures provided by the two current ethanol producers the answers to the questions are as follows:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 1 August 2003:

question.para: (1) Has an estimate of the liability under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 for compensation claims been done since that done for the Tanzer Review in 1998; if not, why not.

(2) For the purpose of fiscal planning, has the Department of Finance and Administration ever consulted with the Department of Veterans' Affairs on more accurately identifying the nature of its future liability for all costs including health care and compensation.
(3) What role does the Repatriation Commission have in monitoring the liability incurred under the Act.
(4) What is the current estimated full life cost of a totally and permanently incapacitated pension including service pension and allowances to a person aged 55.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Veterans' Affairs engaged the Australian Government Actuary in 2000 to examine liabilities arising from the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

(2) and (3) No, except for the purpose of determining the forward estimates. The forward estimates are an accurate estimate of emerging cash payments and take into account expected changes in recipient numbers, forecast rate changes and injuries or diseases for which benefits will be granted during the forward estimates period.

The role of the Repatriation Commission, subject to the control of the Minister, is to administer the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA). Under section 196 of the VEA the Secretary of the Department is required to provide staff necessary to assist the Commission in performing its functions including departmental officers to prepare and monitor the forward estimates.
(4) The Australian Government Actuary has provided the following advice:
The individual full life costs in present value terms, of a grant of the special rate of disability pension, service pension and allowances to a veteran aged 55 years are:
The following benefits have been valued (rates at 1 August 2003):
Service pension of $440.30 per fortnight; and
pharmaceutical allowance of $5.80 per fortnight; and
No other allowances have been considered.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Veterans' Affairs: Overseas Travel
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1704)

talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 1 August 2003:

question.para: (1) For the past 7 years, on how many occasions has the Minister for Veterans' Affairs travelled overseas.
(2) What was the cost of each journey in relation to: (a) travel; and (b) allowances.
(3) For each journey: (a) how many staff accompanied the Minister; and (b) what was the cost of staff travel.
(4) (a) On how many occasions was the Minister accompanied by a spouse or partner; and (b) what was the added cost.
(5) What was the purpose of each journey.
(6) Has a full acquittal been completed for each journey by ministers and staff.
(7) What was the total cost of that travel.

talker.name: Abetz, Sen Eric
Senator Abetz
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: Data provided for the period up to September 1999 in answer to this question has been extracted from an archived entitlements management system and, due to the technical limitations of the archiving process, the Department is unable to guarantee that the data is comprehensive. Data that may not have been captured for this period includes costs of accommodation initially paid through overseas posts.

answer.para: In answer to this question there is no mechanism to distinguish between costs incurred in relation to travel in the portfolio responsibilities of the current Minister for Veterans' Affairs who is also the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence.
(1) In the period 1 August 1996 - 1 August 2003, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs travelled overseas on 19 occasions.
(2) The cost of each journey in relation to (a) travel and (b) allowances was:
(3) For each journey the number of staff that accompanied the Minister (a) and the cost of staff travel (b) was:
(4) The Minister was accompanied by a spouse on (a) occasions at the added cost of (b):
(5) The purpose of each journey was:
1 Vietnam - Attend commemorations for the 30th anniversary of Lon Tan.
2 Belgium, France and the UK - Attend 80th anniversary of the battle of Ypres and the 70th anniversary of the dedication of the Menin Gate Memorial.
3 Thailand - Visit Kranji War Cemetary and Changi Chapel site; Lead the veterans' group to Hellfire Pass Memorial Museum opening by the Prime Minister.
4 France - Attend the opening of Le Hamel Memorial Park and Memorial Park Fromelles.

5 Belgium and Turkey - Participate in ceremonies to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of World War I; Hold discussions with Turkish Ministers on International Peace Park Project and inspect commemorative sites at Gallipoli.
6 Malaysia and Singapore - Lead Government mission of veterans and war widows to dedication of Sandakan Memorial Park; Meet with counterpart.
7 Papua New Guinea - Visit Peace Monitoring Group and hold discussions with Ministry about defence issues.
8 East Timor - Visit defence personnel to assess conditions under which Australian forces are working and evaluate the personnel support measures currently in place.

9 Turkey, Canada and the USA - Attend ANZAC Day ceremonies and inauguration of new ANZAC Cove Commemorative site; Bilateral discussions Canada and the USA; Examine partnerships between Defence and Veterans' Administration in Ottawa, Washington, New York and Honolulu; Participate in ceremonies commemorating ANZAC Day.
10 Korea - Attend commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean War.
11 Korea - Attend commemoration of the 50th Anniversary of the Korean War.
12 Greece and the UK - Discuss proposed London Memorial in Hyde Park; Attend official events associated with the commemoration of the 60th Anniversary of the battles of Greece and Crete.
13 East Timor - Visit deployed AADF personnel.
14 Singapore and Malaysia - Lead a mission to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the Fall of Singapore.
15 France and Belgium - Represent Australia at the 2002 Anzac Day commemorations.
16 Papua New Guinea - Lead a commemorative mission of veterans and war widows for the dedication of memorials at Milne Bay and Popondetta.
17 East Timor - Visit deployed AADF personnel.
18 Belgium, France and the UK - Visit World War I battle sites and represent Australia at ANZAC Day ceremonies; Inspect the site for the proposed Australian War Memorial and meet with officials.
19 Korea and Vietnam - Meet with senior Vietnamese officials and participate in the opening ceremony of the Da Bac Kindergarten.
(6) Acquittals for each journey by Ministers and staff have been completed as follows:
(7) In the period 1 August 1996 - 1 August 2003, the total cost of overseas travel by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs was $582,283.30.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 11 August 2003:

question.para: (1) With regard to the Government's decision to provide domestic ethanol manufacturers with a production subsidy to offset the excise of 38.143 cents per litre applying to ethanol: (a) can the Minister advise: (i) what work was undertaken by Environment Australia, the Government's Energy Task Force or any other Commonwealth agency to model the effects on livestock feed grains (in terms of price and availability) within Australia as a result of this decision prior to the introduction of this measure in September 2002; and (ii) what work was undertaken by Environment Australia, the Government's Energy Task Force or any other Commonwealth agency to model the effects on livestock feed grains (in terms of price and availability) within Australia as a result of the decision to extend this measure to 2008; and (b) can a copy be provided of reports by Environment Australia, the Government's Energy Task Force or any other Commonwealth agency on the effects of these measures on livestock feed grains within Australia; if not, why not.

(2) What work was or is currently being undertaken by Environment Australia, the Government's Energy Task Force or any other Commonwealth agency to model the effects on livestock feed grains (in terms of price and availability) within Australia as a result of the following promises contained in the Coalition's 2001 Election Statement entitled `Our Future Action Plan Growing Stronger': (a) setting a target that biofuels contribute 350 million litres to the total annual transport fuel supply by 2010; and (b) introducing a capital subsidy of $0.16 for each litre of new or expanded biofuel production capacity until the additional 310 million litres target is reached or by the end of 2006-07.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) (i) To the best of my knowledge, no modelling was undertaken by the Department of the Environment and Heritage or any other Government department or agency, on the effects of the ethanol excise/subsidy policy on livestock feed grains. The Energy Task Force was formed after the introduction of the production subsidy in September 2002.
(ii) To the best of my knowledge, no such modelling was undertaken by the Department of the Environment and Heritage or any other Government department or agency.

On 18 June 2003, the Chair of the Energy Task Force met with representatives of the Australian Lot Feeders Association (ALFA) and discussed their concerns about the impact of the ethanol subsidy on feedstock prices. ALFA also provided the Energy Task Force with a copy of a report outlining their concerns. The Energy Task Force took into consideration the concerns of ALFA about the impact of the production subsidy on livestock feed grains when forming its advice to Government on fuel excise and subsidies but no modelling was done.
(b) No reports were produced specifically dealing with the effects of the ethanol measures on livestock feed grains within Australia.

The issue was noted in a wide ranging set of papers prepared by the Energy Task Force for Cabinet consideration of excise related issues. It was also noted in separate material prepared for Cabinet by the Department of the Environment and Heritage. As the papers were prepared for Cabinet, copies have not been provided in response to this question.

(2) (a) and (b) No specific modelling is being undertaken. The Government has commissioned a report on the 350ML biofuels target, to be prepared by the CSIRO, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and the Bureau of Transport and Regional Economics. The potential impact of expanded biofuels production on the price and availability of livestock feed grains and flow-on impacts to other industries will be covered as part of that report.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 26 August 2003:

question.para: (1) What was the rationale for producing advertisements of government health policy from 1996 to the present in all major newspapers on 21 August 2003.
(2) Have the advertisements been paid for through Coalition funding for party campaigns; if not, why not.
(3) What was the total cost of these advertisements.
(4) Are further advertisements to be placed in print media or in any other form of media.
(5) Were the advertisements developed by a consultant, ministerial staff and/or the department.
(6) If a consultant was engaged: (a) who was it; and (b) what was their fee.
(7) Was advice sought as to whether the advertisements violate any covering existing protocol, code of conduct or legislation from the purchase of these advertisements; if so, whom; if not, why not.
(8) Can a copy of this advice be provided.

(9) (a) With reference to the graph of Commonwealth health expenditure published in the advertisement, is the $2.4 billion private health insurance rebate included; (b) what services or programs comprise the `other' category in the graph; and (c) how much of this total is for administration costs.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government decided to place advertisements in national newspapers on 21 August 2003, to provide the public with factual information about the Australian Government's commitment to the health and ageing system.

The advertisements described the range of Australian Government health initiatives and the Government's record under those initiatives. They covered funding for Medicare, public hospitals, prescription medicines, private health insurance, rural health and aged and community care.
It is normal for the Government to wish to inform the public about programs and initiatives through information activities. The timing of these activities is the decision of Government.
(2) The advertisements were paid for by the Government through the Department of Health and Ageing.

The advertisements provided a non-campaign, factual account of the Australian Government's activities in health and aged care. It is therefore appropriate that funds from within the Department were used for the advertisements.
(4) Subsequent decisions about whether further advertisements of this kind will be placed in the media rest with the Government.
(5) Copy for the advertisements was developed by officials, in consultation with the relevant ministerial offices, as is normally the practice for public materials of this kind.

When public notices of this nature are called for, the content is developed by the relevant Department in conjunction with the Government Communications Unit in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, which facilitates media placement.
No consultants were used to develop the content of the advertisement.

(7) The advertisements did not violate existing protocols, code of conduct or legislation relating to Government advertising. Information activities are part of normal business for the Government and for government departments. In fact, current guidelines make it clear that information activities are an integral element of departmental programs.

The Guidelines for Australian Government Information Activities - Principles and Procedures (1995) make it clear that all departments are required to conduct their public information programs “at a level appropriate for their impact on the community, particularly where they concern the individual's benefits, rights and obligations.”
The Guidelines also state “Information activities are to be regarded as an integral part of the management of departmental programs and of the development of new programs.”

As the relevant agency for this issue, the Department of Health and Ageing followed appropriate procedure, consulting with the Government Communications Unit of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet about the placement of the advertisements and also approving their lodgement in accordance with the requirements of the Central Advertising System.
(8) No advice was needed as the action taken was in accordance with Government information activities guidelines.

(9) (a) The figures for the Private Health Insurance Rebate are included in `Health Other'. However, the Australian Taxation Office component of the rebate (which is in the order of $180 million in 2003-04) is not included in the graph.

(b) `Health Other' includes administration costs and all other programs excluding Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS), Pharmaceutical Benefits Schedule (PBS) and Australian Health Care Agreements (AHCAs). For example, Vaccines, Population Health and National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) funding are some of the programs included in `Health Other'.
(c) The Australian Government's administration costs are included in the graph. In 2003-04, $1,030 million is included in administration costs. This consists of
$818 million for health within the Health and Ageing portfolio (including the portfolio agencies involved);
$115 million for ageing programs within the Health and Ageing portfolio; and
$97 million for Department of Veterans' Affairs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 September 2003:

quote.para: In relation to the proposal by ES Link and Portsea Camp for use of Commonwealth land at Point Nepean:

question.para: (1) (a) What is the status of this proposal; and (b) have discussions taken place between the Commonwealth or its representatives and ES Link and/or Portsea Camp; if so: (i) when, (ii) who participated, and (iii) what was the subject of the discussions.
(2) Are there any connections between the Commonwealth Government and ES Link, its directors and shareholders or related entities; if so, can details be provided.

(3) Under this proposal: (a) would all land remain accessible to the public; (b) what if any new development on the land is required; if so, what area will this involve and what is the purpose; and (c) would the public have access to the beach at all times.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The previously announced freehold sale by tender was terminated by the Government on 25 August 2003. For confidentiality and probity reasons, both of which seek to protect the commercial and other interests of the bidders and the robustness of the decision-making process, the Department is not able to publicly announce the identity of bidders in either process.
(b) The Department is not aware of any contact between ES Link or Portsea Camp and officers of the Commonwealth.
(2) None that the Department is aware of.

Senator Ellison

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) (a) None. (b) Customs Corporate Communication Section consists of 12 officers, five of whom have backgrounds and/or qualifications in journalism.
(4) Publication one is sent to approximately 3150 external subscribers. Publication two is sent to approximately 4010 Customs officers.
(6) The total numbers of media releases issued by me across the portfolio in the last 24 months are listed below:
(10) No services were provided to external media agencies, but see (11) below.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 9 September 2003:

question.para: (1) Have Benaris Energy NV and Woodside Energy Ltd applied to the Commonwealth for permits to undertake seismic testing and survey work in coastal waters around south eastern Australia; if so, where.
(2) Will the testing include 3D seismic surveys.
(3) Will the testing include the 12 Apostles Marine National Park.

(4) What are the impacts of 3D seismic testing on marine animals and are the impacts variable depending on the reproductive cycles of the animals; if so, will the Government prohibit testing during breeding and spawning periods.
(5) What consultation has the Government conducted with local communities and key stakeholder groups in relation to the proposed Benaris and Woodside seismic surveys; if none, why.
(6) Does the Government require the applications for permits to be publicly advertised; if not, why not.
(7) Will the Government exercise the precautionary principle in relation to these permit applications.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Woodside Energy Ltd and Benaris Energy NV referred proposals to undertake seismic surveys, pursuant to the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act), on 18 June 2003 and 1 August 2003 respectively.

(3) Benaris Energy NV proposes to undertake seismic survey within several Petroleum Permit Areas, including VIC/P38(V) which includes the waters of the Twelve Apostles Marine Park within the jurisdiction of the Victorian Government. Assessment of the impacts of activities in the Park are the responsibility of the Victorian Government.

(4) Seismic testing may have a variety of impacts on marine animals depending upon the noise levels produced, propagation characteristics of the receiving environment, and timing or proximity of the survey relative to important life-cycle attributes. The Government is committed to the conservation and protection of our threatened marine species and will not allow actions with serious or irreversible impacts to proceed.
(5) The referrals were made available for public comment for a period of 10 business days as required under the EPBC Act.
(7) Yes. Section 391 of the EPBC Act requires that the precautionary principle be taken into account in deciding whether or not a referred proposal is a controlled action.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 September 2003:

question.para: (1) Can a breakdown be provided of all costs associated with the planned disposal of the Defence land at Point Nepean in Victoria, including all marketing, advertising, tender evaluation, legal and other costs.
(2) Can this information be provided in respect of both the abandoned proposal to sell the Point Nepean land and the current proposal to lease the site.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) A breakdown of all costs to date associated with the disposal of Defence land at Point Nepean, as at 22 September 2003 is as follows:

The information provided is that which is readily available from the Department's Financial Management Information System and the structure of the financial Chart of Accounts. The costs provided do not include employee or other administrative costs, and costs are not captured against activities such as tender evaluation.

As advised in the response to Senate Question on Notice No. 1582 (Senate Hansard, 11 September 2003), the cost associated with producing the draft Portsea Defence Land Community Master Plan, including the Community Reference Group and Planning Reference Group activities was approximately $260,000. This figure is included in Property Studies in the above breakdown.

(2) The disposal of the Defence land at Portsea is managed as a single project and costs have not been captured specifically at this point against the freehold sale process as against the current request for tender leasehold process.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 10 September 2003:

question.para: (1) What is the Rural and Remote Area (RRMA)-by-Rural and Remote Area (RRMA) breakdown for the percentage of total unreferred general practitioner (GP) attendances bulk billed for the 12 months ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002; and (d) 30 June 2003.

(2) What is the RRMA-by-RRMA breakdown of the number of total unreferred GP attendances bulk billed by, federal electoral division, for the 12 months ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002; and (d) 30 June 2003.

(3) What is the RRMA-by-RRMA breakdown for the average patient contribution per service (patient billed services only) for total unreferred GP attendances by, federal electoral division, for the 12 months ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002; and (d) 30 June 2003.

(4) What is the RRMA-by-RRMA breakdown for the number of services for total unreferred GP attendances by, federal electoral division, for 12 months ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002; and (d) 30 June 2003.

(5) For the 12 months to 30 June 2003, what is breakdown by RRMA of the percentage of GPs who bulk billed for unreferred services in the following bands: (a) less than 5%; (b) 5% to 25%; (c) 25% to 50%; (d) 50% to 70%; (e) 70% to 75%; (f) 75% to 80%; (g) 80% to 95%; and (h) greater than 95%. Include only those GPs who provided 1 000 or more unreferred services in the period.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The percentage of total non-referred general practitioner (GP) attendances bulk billed, by Rural, Remote and Metropolitan Area (RRMA) classification for the 12 Months ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002; and (d) 30 June 2003, is as follows:

entry.para: BY RURAL, REMOTE AND METROPOLITAN AREA (RRMA)

answer.para: (2) (a), (b), (c) & (d), (3) (a), (b), (c) & (d) and (4) (a), (b), (c) & (d) While Medicare statistics can be compiled by RRMA or by electorate, the statistics are not available by RRMA by electorate. Many electorates will contain areas in different RRMAs.

(3) For general practitioner providers of at least 1,000 non-referred attendances, the percentage of providers by percentage of non-referred attendances bulk billed range, by Rural, Remote and Metropolitan Area (RRMA) classification of provider, 2002-03, is as follows:

entry.para: MEDICARE - FOR GP PROVIDERS OF 1000 NON-REFERRED ATTENDANCES
BY PERCENTAGE OF NON-REFERRED ATTENDANCES BULK BILLED RANGE
AND BY RURAL, REMOTE AND METROPOLITAN AREA (RRMA) CLASSIFICATION

answer.para: These statistics relate to non-referred (general practitioner) attendances that were rendered on a `fee-for-service' basis and for which benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in the respective periods. Excluded are details of non-referred attendances to public patients in hospital, to Department of Veterans' Affairs patients and some compensation cases.

The statistics provided in answer to (1) were compiled from Medicare data by patient enrolment postcode, while those provided in answer to (5) were based on major practice postcode in the June quarter 2003.

In answering (5), in general terms, practitioners were taken to be general practitioners, if they had more than 50 per cent of Schedule fee income in the June quarter 2003, from non-referred (general practitioner) attendances.

question.para: (1) What are the breakdowns, by state and territory, of the percentage of total unreferred general practitioner (GP) attendances bulk billed for the quarters ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002; and (d) 30 June 2003.

answer.para: (3) The average patient contribution per service (non-hospital, patient billed services only), for non-referred (general practitioner) attendances, by State/Territory (based on patient enrolment postcode), for the quarters ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002; and (d) 30 June 2003 (period of processing) is as follows:

(4) The total number of non-referred (general practitioner) attendances, by State/Territory (based on patient enrolment postcode), for the quarters ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002; and (d) 30 June 2003 (period of processing) is as follows:

answer.para: These statistics relate to non-referred (general practitioner) attendances that were rendered on a `fee-for-service' basis and for which benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in the respective quarters. talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 10 September 2003:

question.para: (1) What are the breakdowns of the percentage of total unreferred attendances bulk billed by, federal electoral division, for the quarters ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002 and 30 June 2003.

(2) What are the breakdowns of the number of total unreferred attendances bulk billed by, federal electoral division, for the quarters ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002; and (d) 30 June 2003.

(3) What are the breakdowns for the average patient contribution per service (patient billed services only) for total unreferred attendances by, federal electoral division, for the quarters ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002; and (d) 30 June 2003.

(4) What are the breakdowns for the number of services for total unreferred attendances by, federal electoral division, for the quarters ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002; and (d) 30 June 2003.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The percentage of non-referred (general practitioner) attendances that were bulk billed under Medicare, by federal electorate division (based on patient enrolment postcode), for the quarters ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002 and 30 June 2003 (quarter of processing) is as follows:
% BULK BILLED BY FEDERAL ELECTORAL DIVISION

(2) The number of non-referred (general practitioner) attendances that were bulk billed under Medicare, by federal electorate division (based on patient enrolment postcode), for the quarters ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002 and 30 June 2003 (quarter of processing) is as follows:

(3) The average patient contribution per service (patient billed services only) for total non-referred (general practitioner) attendances by federal electorate division (based on patient enrolment postcode), for the quarters ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002 and 30 June 2003 (quarter of processing) is as follows:

(4) The total number of non-referred (general practitioner) attendances claimed under Medicare, by federal electorate division (based on patient enrolment postcode), for the quarters ending: (a) 30 June 2000; (b) 30 June 2001; (c) 30 June 2002 and 30 June 2003 (quarter of processing) is as follows:
TOTAL NUMBER OF SERVICES BY FEDERAL ELECTORAL DIVISION

These statistics relate to non-referred (general practitioner) attendances that were rendered on a `fee-for-service' basis and for which benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in the respective quarters. Excluded are details of non-referred attendances to public patients in hospital, to Department of Veterans' Affairs patients and some compensation cases.

These statistics were compiled from Medicare data by patient enrolment postcode. Where a postcode overlapped electoral boundaries, the statistics were allocated to electorate using statistics from the Census of Population and Housing, showing the proportion of the population of each postcode in the electorate in question.

Medicare statistics for some postcodes have not been allocated to electorates where the postcodes were not listed on the Census file. The national totals for the number of GP attendances bulk billed and number of GP services in (2) and (4) above will therefore be slightly lower than those recorded elsewhere.

In (3), statistics are not available on the average patient contribution per service for patient billed services in hospital. The Medicare system does not record gap payments under private health insurance arrangements.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 September 2003:

question.para: (1) Are any officials, employees, advisors or contracted staff of the department entitled to any monetary loans, discount or otherwise, from the Treasury, the Reserve Bank or any other Commonwealth agency; if so, can the details and nature of such monetary loans including interest rates and fees be provided.

(2) Do any current or former officials, employees, advisors or contracted staff of the department currently have, or have they ever had, any monetary loan arrangements, discount or otherwise, with the Treasury, the Reserve Bank or any other Commonwealth agency; if so, can the details and nature of such monetary loans be provided, including interest rates and fees.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator Minchin
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No officials, employees, advisors or contracted staff of the Treasury are entitled to any monetary loans, discount or otherwise, from the Treasury, the Reserve Bank or any other Commonwealth agency.

(2) Following the bushfires that struck Canberra on 18 January 2003, the Treasury made an offer of assistance to employees who were directly affected by the fires - that is, through loss or substantial damage to their homes. The offer included short-term, interest free loans, based on demonstrated need. Two employees took up the offer. They were loaned $2000 and $1000 respectively. The latter has been repaid in full; the former is subject to regular repayments and will be fully paid in November.
I have interpreted the honourable senator's question to exclude amounts paid to employees as acquittable advances for travel allowance and relocation costs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 11 September 2003:

question.para: With reference to the assertion made on page 14 of the Report of the Expert Advisory Group on Hepatitis C and Plasma that “There have been no reports of HCV in recipients of blood products made from pools of plasma that included anti-HCV positive units dispatched from the Central Coast Blood Bank to Commonwealth Serum Laboratories”: Was there a process for identifying or notifying all patients who may have received or used recalled product manufactured from hepatitis C contaminated plasma; if so, were such patients tested for HCV.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: CSL Limited (CSL) and the Australian Red Cross Blood Service (ARCBS) have advised that the following process was followed:
CSL agreed the process with the Recall Section of the Therapeutic Goods Administration;
CSL subsequently advised those Blood Transfusion Services that had received the designated batches of Prothrombinex of necessary action;
The Blood Transfusion Services notified all end users (such as hospitals) in writing of the recall and provided a list of those end users to CSL;
CSL dispatched recall letters to the end users on that mailing list, including hospital pharmacists, blood banks, and Directors of Haematology and to private pathologists and individual doctors;

The ARCBS advised that it is not aware of what steps might have been taken by hospitals or clinicians to advise their patients of the recall nor whether end users recommended that their patients seek hepatitis C testing.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Remote Australia: Satellite Technology
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2028)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 15 September 2003:

question.para: In regard to the provision of two-way satellite broadband access for rural areas in Australia: (a) What advantages or disadvantages does the satellite option have for remote communities compared with other options; (b) does the satellite option offer Australians in remote or rural areas services similar to those available in metropolitan areas: and (c) are any proposals being considered by the Government.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (a) The key advantages of satellite may be summarised as:

Ubiquitous availability: Satellite technology is one of the few options for rural and remote residents without access to wireline broadband technologies. The main advantage of satellite broadband technology is that it enables the delivery of broadband to all Australians, in both urban and regional areas.

Reduced infrastructure and ease of deployment: With a terrestrial network, deployment and installation at new locations can be a complicated process. In contrast, a broadband satellite Internet connection is relatively simple and can be installed quickly as no additional infrastructure (other than customer premises equipment) is required.

Superior economics in certain situations: In less populous areas, broadband satellite technology can be much less costly to deploy, maintain and operate than terrestrial broadband network technologies.
Multicasting compatibility: Applications relying on multicasting information from one point to many users are best suited to satellite delivery systems, for example, webcasting conferences.
The disadvantages of satellite broadband technology include:

Costs: While the use of satellite technology to provide broadband services in some situations is more cost-effective than terrestrial solutions, the unit cost of two-way satellite services is relatively high compared to situations where wireline technologies can be economically deployed.

Inherent latency: Real time services like on-line games and voice or video-conferencing over the Internet are affected by unavoidable data latency. This is primarily due to the physics of operating a geostationary satellite 36,000km from Earth. However, some latency issues can be overcome by smart processing. Web surfing, file downloads and video-streaming are satisfactory using the latest satellite systems.

Inclement weather and obstructions: Rain, high-wind and snow may cause periodic lapses in service. Trees, mountains, or tall buildings interfering with the line of sight between the user's satellite dish and the orbiting satellite can also interfere with satellite signals.

(b) Yes, satellite services do offer Australians in regional, rural and remote areas services similar to those available in metropolitan areas, subject to the issues discussed above. In many circumstances, satellite technology is the only economically realistic solution.

Australians in regional, rural and remote areas have a choice of one-way and two-way broadband satellite packages to suit a range of residential and business needs. As noted above, the cost of satellite services is generally higher than services available in metropolitan areas. For this reason, the Government has established the Special Digital Data Service Obligation (SDDSO) and is now establishing the Higher Bandwidth Incentive Scheme (HiBIS).

(c) The Australian Government, like many commercial service providers, has long recognised the ability of satellite to provide access to higher bandwidth and broadband services in less populous areas such as regional, rural and remote Australia. This Government has undertaken a number of initiatives to improve access in regional, rural and remote Australia to higher bandwidth and broadband services delivered by satellite. In particular:

The Government introduced the Digital Data Service Obligation (DDSO) in October 1999. The DDSO consists of a general and special obligation. The general obligation requires Telstra to provide a 64 kbps ISDN service, on request, to the majority of the population. The Special Digital Data Service Obligation applies to the rest of the population that is unable for technical reasons to access the ISDN service.

The special obligation provides for the supply of a one-way satellite service that compares to the ISDN service. A rebate of 50 percent of the price, capped at $765, may be payable in relation to satellite equipment and installation.

The Government committed $150 million from the proceeds of the second partial sale of Telstra to provide Australians who live in `Extended Zones' access to telephone calls and connection to the Internet via an Internet Service Provider (ISP) at the untimed local call rate. The `Extended Zones' are large Telstra calling areas covering the most remote geographic areas of Australia (some 80 per cent of the landmass).

Telstra was selected through a competitive tender process to provide untimed local calls and undertake an upgrade of the underlying infrastructure used to provide services to Extended Zone customers. Part of this upgrade included ensuring that customers on Digital Radio Concentrator Systems (DRCS) could access the Internet at speeds of at least 14.4 kbps, and untimed local call access to the Internet be provided in a competitively neutral manner. Telstra also committed to install two-way satellite services for Internet use, on a concessional basis within the Extended Zones, for a limited time period that has now closed.

The $50 million National Communications Fund (NCF) is assisting in the rollout of the infrastructure and applications to enable high-speed telecommunications networks to deliver education and health services in regional Australia. The NCF's objective is to achieve significant improvements in service delivery in the education and health sectors through funding large-scale telecommunications projects in regional areas.

The eight successful projects will improve the delivery of broadband education and health services in regional areas of Australia, including services such as clinical diagnosis and counselling (for example, teleradiology and telepsychiatry) and improved online delivery of primary, secondary and vocational courses to students. For example, one NCF project will install broadband satellite infrastructure to enable School of the Air Students in New South Wales and the Northern Territory to see, as well as hear, their school teacher and classmates for the first time.

The Regional Telecommunications Inquiry recommended that the Government establish an incentive scheme to enable Australians in regional, rural and remote areas to have access to higher bandwidth services at prices comparable to those in metropolitan areas.

In response, the Government will spend $107.8 million over four years on the Higher Bandwidth Incentive Scheme (HiBIS). HBIS will be a pro-competitive and transparent scheme aimed at improving equitable access to broadband services. It will provide incentive payments to higher bandwidth service providers to offer services in regional, rural and remote areas at prices comparable to those in metropolitan areas. A one-off per customer payment will be made to providers of higher bandwidth data services in areas where a defined minimum level of service, in terms of price and functionality, is not available. This will stimulate the take-up of higher speed services, enabling users to experience the economic, social and cultural benefits of the information economy.

A key principle of the HiBIS is technology neutrality. Service providers will be supported under the Scheme provided defined price and service levels can be met. It is expected that satellite technologies will play an important part in the scheme.

The Government is currently finalising the details of the scheme and is engaging in public consultation with key regional stakeholders and interest groups. The HiBIS is scheduled to commence in early 2004.

talk.start.para: asked portfolio Ministers, upon notice, on 15 September 2003:

question.para: (1) For the financial years 2001-02 and 2002-03, have there been any laptop computers lost or stolen from the possession of any officer of the department and/or any agency within the portfolio, if so: (a) how many have been lost; (b) how many have been stolen; (c) what is the total value of these computers; (d) what is the average replacement value per computer; and (e) have these computers been recovered or replaced.

(2) Have the police been requested to investigate any of these incidents, if so: (a) how many were the subject of police investigation; (b) how many police investigations have been concluded; (c) in how many cases has legal action commenced; and (d) in how many cases has action been concluded and with what result.

(3) How many of these lost or stolen items had, on their hard disc drives or in the form of floppy disc, CD-ROM or any other storage device, departmental documents, content or information other than operating software.
(4) How many of the documents referred to in to paragraph (3) were classified for security or any other purpose; if any, what was the security classification involved.
(5) (a) How many of the documents referred to in paragraph (3) have been recovered; and (b) how many documents referred to in paragraph (4) have been recovered.
(6) What departmental disciplinary or other actions have been taken in regard to the items referred to paragraph (1), or in relation to the documents referred to in paragraphs (3) and (4).

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I provide the following answer, on behalf of all portfolio Ministers, to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The answers reveal the extent of computer losses and theft for all Australian Government agencies with the exception of Telstra and the ABC for the financial years 2001-02 and 2002-03. Answers in respect of those two agencies will be provided when the information is available.

While the loss of any Commonwealth owned asset is a matter of concern to the government, the answers to the honourable senator's questions reveal that the loss rate of laptop computers across all Australian Government agencies is relatively low by industry standards. META Group, a leading provider of information technology research services, has reported that private sector firms in the United States experience a loss rate of 10-15 per cent of their laptops a year. In comparison, the loss rate for laptops across all Australian Government agencies is less than 1 per cent.

Australian Government agencies lease or own more than 37,000 laptop computers. In the last two financial years, around 530 laptops with a value of approximately $1.4 million have been lost or stolen. Many of these computers were stolen from private residences and vehicles. Portfolio secretaries have been asked to regularly remind staff in their portfolios of the need to secure laptops and ensure that sensitive or national security information is not stored on laptops.
The value of desktop computers and other items of computer equipment lost or stolen in those two financial years is approximately $475,000.
None of the losses of computer equipment detailed in the answers below has compromised national security.

para.inline: Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM&C)

answer.para: (b) A total of two (2) laptops were stolen.
(c) The total value of these Laptops is $8,000.
(d) The laptops were replaced under the insurance arrangements of the lease.
(e) None of the laptops has been recovered. The laptops have been replaced.
(a) Both incidents were subject to police investigation.
(3) and (4) Two laptops contained departmental data. No documents had national security classifications. Both laptops encrypt information on the hard disks.
(6) Staff are reminded periodically about the importance of adhering to proper security procedures when using and transporting laptops.
(1) Yes, there was a break-in at the Australian Public Service Commission's office in Melbourne in 2001 during which two laptop computers were stolen. So the answers to the remaining questions are:
(c) The total value of these computers is $6,941.40

(d) The average replacement cost per computer is $3,470.70 based on the unamortised amount which is the full 36 months rental, minus what rental has been already paid by the agency from the full period (in this case 6 months) = thirty months.

(2) The police were requested to attend the office and they took fingerprints from the main door and associated cabinets. We have not received any further information about the outcome of any investigation.

(3) Both units would have contained information relating to some training seminars on the APS Code of Conduct. This information was already in the public domain and was not sensitive, private or personal.

para.inline: The Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman

answer.para: (1) Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman - YES one laptop stolen. Cost $3,894. The unit was replaced under insurance 25/10/01.
(2) The police were requested to investigate the once only incident. There has been no conclusion to this investigation and hence not resolved and no legal action.
(3) There were no departmental documents on the storage devices of the stolen laptop.
(6) As a result of the stolen laptop there was a re-notice of security procedures around the use of laptops and policy of record keeping around mobile data.

para.inline: The Office of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security (OIGIS)
The Office of the Official Secretary to the Governor-General (OOSGG)

answer.para: (1) Eleven laptop computers were stolen from the ANAO Canberra and Sydney Offices in Financial Year 2001-02. Two laptop computers were stolen from staff residences in Canberra in Financial Year 2002-03.
(a) There were no ANAO laptop computers lost in 2001-02 or 2002-03.
(b) 2001-02: Two laptop computers were stolen from the ANAO Sydney Office, and nine from the ANAO Canberra Office.
2002-03: Two laptop computers were stolen from staff residences in Canberra.

(c) 2001-02: The total written down value of the two laptop computers stolen from the Sydney Office was approximately $1330. The total written down value of the nine laptop computers stolen from the Canberra Office was approximately $21 000.
2002-03: The total written down value of the two laptop computers stolen from staff members Canberra residences was approximately $3600.

(d) 2001-02: The average replacement value of the laptop computers stolen from the Sydney Office was approximately $4000. The average replacement value of the nine laptop computers stolen from the Canberra Office was approximately $3500.
2002-03: The average replacement value of the two laptop computers stolen from staff members' Canberra residences was approximately $3500.
(e) None of the stolen laptop computers were recovered and all have since been replaced.
(2) All thefts were reported to the Australian Federal Police (AFP).
(a) All thefts were investigated by the AFP.
(c) No legal action has commenced in relation to any of the thefts.
(3) All stolen laptops are believed to have had content or information other than operating software on their hard disc drives.

(4) The ANAO is not aware that any of the stolen laptops contained any classified information. The ANAO's IT Security Policy stipulates that no information above “In Confidence,” or the National Security Classification of “Restricted,” should be stored on computer equipment.
(6) No disciplinary action was taken as a result of the investigations of the theft of laptop computers.
