answer.para: There has been no finding of misconduct against anyone who was responsible for the safekeeping of any of the stolen laptop computers. Following the theft of 10 laptop computers in the 2001-02 financial year, steel security cables were issued to employees holding a laptop computer. Employees were also reminded to be more careful with the security of the computers. In the 2002-03 financial year, only one laptop computer was reported missing.
(1) Incidents were logged, reported to Police and additional procedural and physical security measures introduced to minimise recurrence.
(3) Whilst the hardware has not been recovered, information contained within was recoverable from the agency network.
(4) Whilst the hardware has not been recovered, information contained within was recoverable from the agency network.
(a) The number lost in 2001/2002 was nil, and in 2002/3 one (1).
(b) The number stolen in 2001/2002 was two (2), and in 2002/3 six (6).
(c) The total value for 2001/2002 was $6540, and for 2002/3 $12,849.
(d) The average replacement value for 2001/2002 was $5,000 and for 2002/3 $4,414.
(e) None have been recovered, and all have been replaced.
(a) The number subject to police investigation in 2001/2002 were two (2), and in 2002/3 six (6).
(b) The ABS has not been advised by police of the conclusion of any investigation in regard to items stolen in 2001/2002 and 2002/2003.
(c) The ABS has not been advised by police how many of the cases, in respect of items stolen in 2001/2002 and 2002/2003, have had legal action commenced.
(d) The ABS has not been advised by police how many of the cases, in respect of items stolen in 2001/2002 and 2002/2003, have been concluded or the result.

(3) The number of items stolen which had departmental documents, content or information stored therein, other than operating software, was two (2) in 2001/2002 and six (6) in 2002/2003. All information was encrypted.
(4) Some of the documents, approximately 600, referred to in paragraph 3 were classified `In-Confidence'. All were encrypted.
(5) (a) All of the information referred to in paragraph (3) for 2001/2002 and 2002/2003 has been recovered.
(b) All of the information referred to in paragraph (4) for 2001/2002 and 2002/2003 has been recovered.
(6) In one instance an officer was counselled.
(6) Agency staff are regularly reminded of the need for appropriate security of departmental documentation and computer equipment.
(1) (a) 12 laptops were lost in the financial years 2001-02 and 2002-03.
(b) 3 laptops were stolen in the financial years 2001-02 and 2002-03.
(d) The replacement value per computer was approximately $4,800.00.
(2) There is no record of police investigations having been carried out on stolen computers.
(3) Most, if not all, of these computers would have held departmental documents.

(6) No formal disciplinary action was taken in regard to these items. Staff involved in these incidents were reminded of the duty of care they have over APRA's equipment. All staff are required to sign the APRA security policy which covers issues regarding document security and agency assets. Reminders regarding these policies are communicated to staff on a regular basis.
(d) Two - perpetrator(s) could not be identified

(6) PC was protected by DSD approved security software rendering the hard disk unusable. This includes PC vault to encrypt hard disks on all laptops and home PC's, secure remote for VPN connection to the ASIC network and user login and password protection on all laptops.
(a) 8 laptop computers were lost in 2001-02, and 4 were lost in 2002-03.
(b) 36 laptop computers were stolen in 2001-02, and 31 were stolen in 2002-03.
(c) The estimated total value of the machines was approximately $65,000.
(d) The average replacement value per machine was $4,900.

(a) 26 incidents were reported to the police in 2001-02, and 23 were reported in 2002-03. The number of resultant investigations is not known as the police do not routinely advise the ATO of such matters.
(b) The police have not advised the ATO of the conclusion of any investigation.

(3) 25 in 2001-02, and 22 in 2002-03. Current encryption software encrypts the hard drive and any information stored on laptop computers, thereby preventing access to software and data. Prior to September 2001, laptop design prevented full encryption of the hard drive. However, encryption of the boot sector of the hard drive prevented access to software and data by password protecting the access.

Encryption software is DSD (Defence Signals Directorate) accredited and the expertise and equipment needed to break the code is extremely high. It is extremely unlikely that any individual would possess the resources to break the code and therefore an opportunistic theft would pose almost no threat of access to the data.

(4) 20 of the 44 laptops lost or stolen in 2001-02 contained classified documents, and 16 of the 35 laptops lost or stolen in 2002-03 contained classified documents. In all cases, the classified data held was taxpayer data relating to the immediate case or cases being dealt with by the officer. This data is therefore classified as “In Confidence”. Case data is held on the laptop for 14 days only and is then automatically deleted. The hard disks are also encrypted as described above and therefore access to the data by unauthorised persons is virtually impossible.
ATO staff who use laptops in their work are required to follow corporate guidelines and policy in regard to the physical security of the equipment and the data stored on them.

(6) No formal departmental disciplinary actions have been taken in regard to the items referred to in paragraph (1), or in relation to the documents referred to in paragraphs (3) and (4). However, where incidents of equipment theft and losses are reported by staff, the manager of the staff member concerned is advised for appropriate follow-up action.

A number of intranet notices have been published, alerting staff to the need to take appropriate action to guard against the theft of equipment, information and belongings.
The electronic security system is being upgraded to provide fully auditable access control, intruder detection and CCTV monitoring;
Two factor authentication (smartcard and pin) has been introduced to the department's IT network; and
A department-wide, on-line security awareness training program, coordinated through the Attorney-General's Department, has been implemented.

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Government: Missing Desktop Computers and Computer Hardware
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question Nos 2088 to 2105)

talk.start.para: asked the Ministers shown below, upon notice, on 15 September 2003:

question.para: (1) For the financial years 2001-02 and 2002-03, have there been any desktop computers, or any other item of computer hardware, other than laptop computers, lost or stolen from the possession of any officer of the department and/or any agency within the portfolio, if so: (a) what and how many have been lost; (b) what and how many have been stolen; (c) what is the total value of these items; (d) what is the nominal replacement value per item; and (e) have these computers been recovered or replaced.

(2) Have the police been requested to investigate any of these incidents, if so: (a) how many were the subject of police investigation; (b) how many police investigations have been concluded; (c) in how many cases has legal action commenced; and (d) in how many cases has action concluded and with what result.

(3) How many of these lost or stolen items had, on their hard disc drives or in the form of floppy disc, CD-ROM or any other storage device, departmental documents, content or information other than operating software.
(4) How many of the documents referred to in paragraph (3) were classified for security or any other purpose; if any, what was the security classification involved.
(5) (a) How many of the documents referred to in paragraph (3) have been recovered; and (b) how many documents referred to in paragraph (4) have been recovered.
(6) What departmental disciplinary or other actions have been taken in regard to the items referred to paragraph 1, or in relation to the documents referred to in paragraphs (3) and (4).

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I provide the following answer, on behalf of all portfolio Ministers, to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The answers reveal the extent of computer losses and theft for all Australian Government agencies with the exception of Telstra and the ABC for the financial years 2001-02 and 2002-03. Answers in respect of those two agencies will be provided when the information is available.

While the loss of any Commonwealth owned asset is a matter of concern to the government, the answers to the honourable senator's questions reveal that the loss rate of laptop computers across all Australian Government agencies is relatively low by industry standards. META Group, a leading provider of information technology research services, has reported that private sector firms in the United States experience a loss rate of 10-15 per cent of their laptops a year. In comparison, the loss rate for laptops across all Australian Government agencies is less than 1 per cent.

Australian Government agencies lease or own more than 37,000 laptop computers. In the last two financial years, around 530 laptops with a value of approximately $1.4 million have been lost or stolen. Many of these computers were stolen from private residences and vehicles. Portfolio secretaries have been asked to regularly remind staff in their portfolios of the need to secure laptops and ensure that sensitive or national security information is not stored on laptops.
The value of desktop computers and other items of computer equipment lost or stolen in those two financial years is approximately $475,000.
None of the losses of computer equipment detailed in the answers below has compromised national security.

A number of intranet notices have been published, alerting staff to the need to take appropriate action to guard against the theft of equipment, information and belongings.
The electronic security system is being upgraded to provide fully auditable access control, intruder detection and CCTV monitoring;
Two factor authentication (smartcard and pin) has been introduced to the department's IT network; and
A department-wide, on-line security awareness training program, coordinated through the Attorney-General's Department, has been implemented.
