talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 16 September 2003:

question.para: (1) Given the department's concerns with the maladministration of the Northern Suburbs Migrant Resource Centre in Perth, Western Australia, why was an administrator not put in charge of the organisation.
(2) Why did the department not ask the South Metropolitan Migrant Resource Centre in Perth to move its operations to another location that better suited the needs of the migrant community of Perth.
(3) What consultations were undertaken with local stake-holders prior to the decision to merge the two Western Australian Migrant Resource Centres (MRCs).
(4) Has the department explored how the needs of migrants in the outer metropolitan suburbs of Perth can be met with minimal travel time and expense.
(5) Why is the Minister phasing out MRCs, given their capacity to provide services that are culturally and linguistically appropriate than equivalent Commonwealth services.

(6) Why does the department persist in the practice of placing non-voting members on the management committees of MRCs, when the Commonwealth provides greater funding to other mainstream organisations, without requiring participation in management committees.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Migrant Resource Centres (MRCs) are independent organisations, which can receive funding from a wide range of sources, including my Department. While it is within my powers to cease the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) funding, it is not within my powers to appoint an Administrator to a Migrant Resource Centre. That decision would be one for the Management Committee of the MRC to take.

(2) The Department has been encouraging South Metropolitan MRC to seek an alternative location for the past two years. Their client base had moved from the Fremantle hub used by the MRC but the MRC had not sought to shift their focus accordingly.

(3) Departmental officers had, at various times, discussed my Department's management concerns with Northern Suburbs MRC and the locational issues with South Metropolitan MRC, with other Commonwealth and State funding bodies. Since the amalgamation process began, my Department has been in close consultation with these funding bodies and other relevant local stakeholders.

(4) The task force, which is managing the amalgamation of my Department's funded services, has committed to maintaining services that cater for the needs of this client group. The task force comprises representatives of the Northern Suburbs and South Metropolitan MRCs, as well as my Department.

(5) I am not phasing out MRCs. The Government is committed to the continuing development of a strong and effective network of settlement service providers, including the Migrant Resource Centre (MRC) and Migrant Service Agency (MSA) network. The amalgamation of the MRCs in Perth is taking place in order to position a single, stronger MRC to serve new arrivals from all over Perth, as is the case in Brisbane and Adelaide where centrally located MRCs provide services across those cities. The new Perth MRC will determine its own location and outreach circumstances, taking into account the imperative for the MRC to be close to transport and services relevant to the client base.

(6) The practice of placing non-voting departmental staff on the management committees of MRCs has principally been for the purpose of performance monitoring. This approach was reviewed as part of the recent Review of Settlement Services. The Department is currently working to develop alternative mechanisms for monitoring performance, which would allow it to withdraw from participation on management committees.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 September 2003:

question.para: With regard to the e-Defence project (Project Joint 2054) in the Defence Capability Plan:
(1) Can a description of all the phases of this project be provided.
(2) What was the original timeline for the completion of the project, including the dates for completing each of the phases in the project.
(3) What was the original budget for this project, including the budget for each of the phases.
(4) What is the current schedule for completing this project, including the dates for each of the phases.
(5) What is the current budget for the project, including the budget for each of the phases.
(6) What has been the cost of this project to date, including the cost for each phase completed.
(7) What are the reasons for the delays being experienced with Phase 1 of this project.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The e-Defence Project (JP2054) seeks to provide a secure e-mail based messaging environment for Defence through the implementation of security services to the desktop. Two phases of the project are planned.

(a) Phase 1A is to provide a secure e-mail based messaging capability, and an authentication framework and directory to support secure messaging, e-Business within Defence, and e-Commerce with Industry.
(b) Phase 2 is to provide a technology refresh and an incremental upgrade of the system developed in Phase 1A. It is as yet unapproved.

Project JP2054 was originally approved in December 1997 for completion by December 2004. The project was restructured in 2000 and retitled as JP 2054 Phase 1A, replacing the non phased JP2054 project.

In November 2000, Phase 1 was reconsidered by Defence as part of the Defence 2000 White Paper process and re-approved in the context of the 2001/02 budget for completion in late 2004. This project has now been suspended to allow issues associated with the business case to be reviewed.
JP2054 Phase 2 - Planned as a $100m -$150m project within the Defence Capability Plan.
JP2054 Phase 1A - Schedule for completion is subject to a project capability review.
JP 2054 Phase 2 - A schedule is yet to be programmed as the project is unapproved
JP2054 Phase 2 - Planned as a $100m -$150m project within the Defence Capability Plan.
JP2054 Phase 1A has expended $49.85m as at 12 September 2003 providing:
A Secure E-mail-based messaging capability that has been successfully piloted, proving product integration and operation on the Secret Network.
A secure corporate directory for messaging and wider Defence use.
The establishment of an authentication system that allows the identity of message recipients and message originators to be assured.
A basic level of functionality to enable secure electronic business and commerce transactions, specifically the implementation of Public Key Infrastructure and Digital signatures capability.
The project is being paused to allow for a Business case review as indicated in (2) above. The review will:
assess the ability of the project to deliver its scope under current funding guidelines;
review, clarify, and re-validate requirements, taking into account changes in Defence operations, business needs, and technological advancements;
develop the relevant Capability Definitions Documents;
establish an updated schedule for delivery of the capability;
assess the impact on reliant capabilities and the aging DISCON system; and
establish a way ahead, including acquisition strategy, for the achievement of the required capability.
Issues affecting progress to date have been:
The slower than expected maturation of commercial off the shelf products with features to support Military Messaging requirements.
The need to finalise agreed standards for allied interoperability and the implementation of military messaging amongst our allies, which is currently being progressed.
The transition to a single e-mail client across the Defence Restricted and Secret Network systems, which is currently being progressed by Defence.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 17 September 2003:

question.para: (1) Has the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Service (ATSIS) notified certain Indigenous organisations that funding will be provided on a cyclical basis or will cease completely; if so, how many organisations have had their funding withdrawn or altered since the changeover from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) to ATSIS.
(2) Which organisations, by name, category and location, have: (a) received ATSIC funding in the 2002-03 financial year; and (b) had their funding altered in the changeover to ATSIS.
(3) (a) How many of these organisations have been notified; and (b) how long will these changes be in place.
(4) What reasons for the changes have been provided to the relevant organisations.
(5) Where funding has or will cease, can organisations appeal to the Minister against the ATSIS decision.
(6) Where funding has or will cease, what Government policy objectives will be achieved.
(7) Has ATSIS made any costs savings as a result of the changeover from ATSIC.
(8) (a) What plans does the Government have for any surplus funds; and (b) what programs will be funded using this surplus.
(9) (a) What ATSIC assets, if any, have been transferred to ATSIS and; (b) what is the legal basis for assets transfers.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Services has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) All 2002/2003 ATSIC funded organisations were advised of the new Agency arrangements in April 2003. The advice emphasised that ATSIC Commissioners and Regional Councillors would continue to determine policies and priorities for the allocation of program funds, with the new Agency, ATSIS, managing the programs and making individual funding decisions in line with these policies and priorities.
To facilitate this, extensive instructions were provided to ATSIS staff and delegates (see Attachment A).

ATSIS directly funds over 1000 Indigenous organisation in any one year for around 3,000 individual activities. It also indirectly funds numerous other organisations through arrangements with the States/Territories.

It is not an unusual occurrence for funding to particular organisations to change from year to year. This is also not unique to ATSIC. In situations where funds are provided for ongoing operational costs, the amount of funding may vary from year to year, based on a number of factors including changes to identified need, past performance of grantee organisations in managing financial aspects and achievement of outcomes, one-off funding for infrastructure or capital purchase and changes to ATSIC policies and priorities.

Given the range and number of grants, ATSIS is unable to undertake a detailed examination and comparison of funding provided in the financial years 2002/2003 and 2003/2004 and include a comprehensive analysis of reasons for such variations in the timeframe available for response to this question.

With the establishment of ATSIS on 1 July 2003, ATSIS delegates were required to formally make all 2003/2004 funding decisions, including those already taken by ATSIC Regional Councils prior to that date. In a relatively small number of cases, ATSIS made decisions different from those of Regional Councils.

In addition, in an effort to improve the delivery of services to clients by funded organisations, a number of entities were offered funding in 2003/2004 for a limited period in order that a more in-depth assessment of the delivery of those services could be made.

(2) As indicated earlier, there are in excess of 1000 Indigenous organisations funded for over 3000 individual activities in any one year. A full and comprehensive examination and analysis was not possible in the timeframe allowable and would absorb considerable scarce resources. If essential, ATSIS could undertake the work to provide a listing of decisions taken by Regional Councils which were subsequently amened by a Delegate following the establishment of ATSIS.
(3) (a) All organisations that have had their funding altered have been notified, except in a small number of cases where a delegate is still considering submissions.

(b) Currently, the majority of funding decisions are made annually. For the bulk of recipient organisations, the funding level remains unchanged for the financial year. There are, however, a number of cases in any one year where particular funding arrangements are altered for reasons largely relating to performance of organisations and, in some cases, redirection of funding. Procedures have been in place since the commencement of ATSIC and these procedures have been carried over to the operations of ATSIS.
(4) The reasons for the changes to funding levels vary considerably and include:
changes to Board of Commissioner and Regional Council priorities and policies;
changing circumstances in relation to needs in a particular region;
overall levels of program funds available;
decisions to introduce contestability and market testing into the delivery of some services; and
a renewed focus on organisational capacity and performance based contracts.
(5) Organisations are free to appeal funding decisions to the Minister if they so desire. Organisations are also at liberty to seek review of funding decisions through the Federal Court.

(6) The policy objective to be achieved, where ongoing funding arrangements have been reviewed, is to ensure effective and efficient use of public moneys and improved outcomes for Indigenous peoples through ensuring value for money in program delivery.
(7) There have been no `costs savings' per se resulting from the introduction of the ATSIS decision-making arrangements.
(b) Any reductions in particular program areas have been allocated to meeting other program priorities.

ATSIC had a cash carry forward as at 30 June 2003. The ATSIC Board has determined how those funds should be used to meet program priorities and a Ministerial Estimates Variation has been signed by Minister Ruddock approving the expenditure in 2003/04. These funds are to be transferred to ATSIS, enabling the program delivery to be done via ATSIS.

(9) (a) No. ATSIC assets have been transferred to ATSIS. ATSIS has care, custody and control of ATSIC administrative assets but title/ownership remains with ATSIC. With ATSIC's consent, certain contracts which were due to be renewed by ATSIC after 1 July are being renewed in the name of ATSIS.
(b) An agreement between ATSIC and the Commonwealth represented by ATSIS sets out the administrative arrangements governing the relationship between the two bodies.
“When exercising delegations in relation to grant decisions, staff must take into account:
ATSIC Board and Regional Council priorities and polices;
Funding decisions, commitments or endorsements made already by Regional Councils in relation to 2003/04 Grants;
Information provided by National Program Managers;
The capacity of the grantee organisation to deliver the services;
Any subsequent directions from the Minister.
Where delegates decide they cannot approve a grant previously approved by Regional Council, the Regional Manager should take the following steps:
clearly establish that the project is one which was not previously recommended by staff;
revisit the recommendations and justification and consider the reasons why the Regional Council made its decision;
consider the relevance of the project to the Regional Council Plan and established Council policies and priorities and identify alternative ways of addressing the Regional Council priority;

consider implications and options where an organisation has expectations about the level of ongoing funding, and determine how this may be best managed. (eg 6 monthly grant only, grant controller etc);
negotiate other ways of delivering the service where the difficulty is with the capacity of the grantee to administer the grant or provide the services;
discuss with the relevant Program Manager if the issue is adherence to program guidelines;
use good judgement about the significance of the proposed variation before changing the Regional Council decision; and
seek other views (eg. Program Manager, Field Staff, General Manager Network,) to develop a justifiable statement of reasons for making a decision which varies from that of the Regional Council.
In all cases, every effort is to be made to meet the Regional Council's priorities and required outcomes.
In committing any unallocated funds ATSIS delegates should:
consider any decisions made by the Regional Council about allocations to programs, use of unallocated funds, or reasons for holding back contingency funds; and
in line with the budget approved by the Minister, alternative projects must stay within the same Program.

All submissions recommended for decline will also need to be reconsidered as part of this process and it may be that some projects declined by Regional Council are subsequently approved, especially if additional allocations become available. A similar process to that above should be followed.”

subdebateinfo.title: Health: Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2176)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 1 October 2003:

quote.para: With reference to the report, The Health and Welfare of Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples, which identified poorer living conditions and health for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians than for non-Indigenous Australians, can specific details be provided of current or planned programs, including details of budgets and targets for populations reached and outcome improvements in respect of the following problems identified in the report:

question.para: (a) over a quarter of the communities with a population of 50 or more that were not connected to the town water supply had failed water quality tests at least once during the previous 12 months;
(b) a fifth of the communities had water supplies that had not been tested in the past 12 months;
(c) more than one in three communities with 50 people or more experienced water restrictions in the past 12 months;
(d) just under half of the communities with a population of 50 or more reported that sewerage system overflows or leakages had occurred in the past 12 months;
(e) ponding of stagnant water occurred in 42 per cent of the communities with a population of more than 50;
(f) Indigenous adults were about half as likely as non-Indigenous adults to be employed in health-related occupations;

(g) Indigenous separation rates were higher than non-Indigenous rates for all age groups except those aged 75 years and over, with the highest rate differences being for both males and females in the age groups between 35 and 64 years;

(h) principal diagnoses for which high incidence ratios were evident in the 2000-01 financial year were: (i) care involving dialysis (6.6:1 for males, 12.6:1 for females), (ii) endrocrine, nutritional and metabolic diseases (3.5:1 for males, 3.8:1 for females), and (iii) diseases of the respiratory system (2.6:1 for males, 3.1:1 for females);
(i) babies of Indigenous mothers were twice as likely to be of low birthweight (13 per cent of births) than babies of non-Indigenous mothers (6 per cent);
(j) the perinatal death rate for births to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander mothers was 20 per thousand live births and stillbirths, compared with 10 per thousand for non-Indigenous mothers;

(k) reports of long-term health conditions increased with age from 34 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children aged under 5 years to 99 per cent of Indigenous Australians aged 55 years and over;
(l) eye/vision problems were the most commonly reported conditions (29 per cent), followed by asthma (16 per cent), back problems (15 per cent) and ear/hearing problems (15 per cent);

(m) the National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System reports disease rates for Indigenous Australians are many times those among non-Indigenous Australians with incidence ratios particularly high for: (i) gonococcal infection (69:1), (ii) syphilis (42:1), and (iii) chlamydia (18:1); and for most other communicable diseases reported to the surveillance system, the incidence rates for Indigenous persons are generally in the range 5 to 10 times higher than for non-Indigenous persons;

(n) incidence ratios for: (i) ischaemic heart disease hospitalisations are 1.4:1 for males and 2.4:1 for females, (ii) respiratory diseases, 2.6:1 for males and 3.1:1 for females, (iii) infectious and parasitic diseases, 2.7:1 for males and 3.1:1 for females, and (iv) injury and poisoning, 1.9:1 for males and 2.3:1 for females;

(o) among the latter group (injury and poisons), hospitalisations that are attributed to `assault' are 8 times higher for Indigenous males and 28 times higher for Indigenous females, compared with non-Indigenous males and females respectively;
(p) Indigenous children living in non-remote areas were less likely than non-Indigenous children to have been breastfed for more than 6 months;

(q) higher proportions of Indigenous Australians in non-remote areas reported medium to high vegetable intake (two or more serves per day) but more non-Indigenous Australians reported medium to high fruit intake;
(r) Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples were more likely to consume whole (full cream) milk rather than reduced fat alternatives and to add salt to meals after cooking;
(s) the percentage of Indigenous adults classified as overweight or obese was 61 per cent, compared with 48 per cent of non-Indigenous adults;

(t) Indigenous persons aged 18 years and over were twice as likely as non-Indigenous persons to be current smokers (51 per cent compared with 24 per cent); with higher rates applying to both sexes and across all age groups; and

(u) Indigenous adults aged 18 years and over were less likely (42 per cent) than non-Indigenous adults (62 per cent) to have consumed alcohol in the week prior to interview for the 2001 National Health Survey; however, those who consumed alcohol were more likely to have consumed at risky/high levels than non-Indigenous consumers (29 per cent compared with 17 per cent).

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (a) to (e) Issues relating to the supply and quality of fresh water to Indigenous Australian communities and the provision of sewerage infrastructure are the responsibility of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Services (ATSIS). Therefore, parts (a) to (e) of this question should be addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, as the Minister responsible for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act.

(f) The Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Workforce National Strategic Framework is a 5-10 year reform agenda to build a competent health workforce to address the health needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. A key objective of the Workforce Strategic Framework is to increase the participation of Indigenous Australians in the health workforce.

Implementation of these strategies is occurring through the AHMAC Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Workforce Working Group and through the State and Territory Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Partnership Forums. Key activities underway include:

1. The development of up-to-date, functional Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Worker competencies to underpin further work to train and support Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Workers;

2. The establishment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Worker associations in each state and territory. South Australia has the first association established to date. The associations promote and support the role of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Workers, provide a forum for professional development, support and representation and improved access for effective training and development opportunities;

3. Commissioning research into why Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people choose health careers, the impact of mainstream health workforce programs on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander primary health care services and opportunities for remote area employment agencies to improve their role in supporting these services;
4. Collection of baseline data in partnership with the department of Education, Science and Training on current Indigenous Australian participation rates in health professional training;

5. The Australian Government has provided funding and secretariat support to two separate working groups to develop strategies to include Indigenous health issues in medical and nursing core curricula. The Department has committed $100,000 in 2002-03 to the University of Melbourne to employ a Project Officer to develop a national curriculum framework and key learning objectives for the inclusion of Indigenous health in core medical curricula on behalf of the Committee of Deans of Australian Medical Schools (CDAMS). It is expected that the curriculum framework and on-going development of the broader project (implementation, recruitment and retention issues) will be endorsed by CDAMS and the Medical School Accreditation Committee at the Australian Medical Council meeting in March 2004.

From 2002-03 to 2003-04 the Australian Government is providing funding to the Australian Catholic University to employ a Project Officer to coordinate the implementation of the “getting em n keepin em' report on behalf of Australian Council of Deans of Nursing. The report was developed by the Indigenous Nursing Education Working Group, comprising representatives from the Australian Council of Deans of Nursing, the Congress of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Nurses and the Commonwealth. This report was published in 2002 and makes thirty-two recommendations to ensure that all nursing curricula includes Indigenous content and that there is a concerted effort to recruit and retain Indigenous people in the nursing workforce.

The Australian Nursing Council is the peak body established by the Australian nursing regulatory authorities to develop national standards for statutory nursing regulation. The Council has now developed a position paper in consultation with the Australian nursing regulatory authorities endorsing the inclusion of clearly identified core components on Indigenous culture, history and health in nursing degrees.

6. The Australian Government has provided funding of $2.7 million over five academic years (2002-2006) to fund undergraduate scholarships for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students in health courses. Under the Puggy Hunter Memorial Scholarships Scheme scholarships will be granted to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students for:
- Certificate level III and IV Aboriginal Health Worker courses.
- Diploma and Advanced Diploma level Aboriginal Health Worker courses.
$174,261 was spent in 2002, $483,658 will be spent in 2003, and $2 million is projected for the rest of the scheme over the period 2004 to 2006; and

7. The Australian Government also provided recurrent funding of $650,540 to the Australian Indigenous Doctors Association in 2003 and $550,000 to the Congress of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Nurses in 2002-03 and 2003-04 to develop infrastructure and networks and to invest in the development of the Indigenous health workforce.

The Australian Indigenous Doctors' Association has been granted $93,500 to undertake the Commonwealth Indigenous Workforce Project in order to identify best practice in recruitment of an support for Indigenous medical students. The Australian Government is currently negotiating with the Australian Indigenous Doctors Association and the Congress of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Nurses to undertake mentoring projects in relation to Indigenous nursing and medical careers.

(g) to (u) Indigenous Australian hospital separation rates in 2000-01 were higher than non-Indigenous rates. This principally reflects a higher burden of chronic disease in Indigenous Australians. These conditions are best addressed through improving access to comprehensive primary health care services, rather than in the tertiary health sector.

The Australian Government's strategy is to influence the mainstream health system so that it better meets the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, complemented by supporting Indigenous-specific services. Action across the health system includes:
- Targeted assistance to supplement service delivery through mainstream programs, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Primary Health Care Services and Substance Use Services; and
Improving access to mainstream health programs and services:
- Programs and services intended to meet the needs of all Australians including Medicare Benefits Scheme (MBS) and Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

In order to provide appropriate quality primary health care services, the Australian Government funds and supports 184 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community controlled health services, 24 of which provide both primary health care and substance use services and 43 are stand alone substance use services. The Australian Government has provided $258 million in 2003-04 for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community controlled health services to provide high quality coordinated clinical care, population health and health promotion activities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

Further details of the Australian Government's current or planned programs (including Indigenous specific programs/services and mainstream programs) which address the problems outlined in parts (g) - (u) are as follows:

The Australian Government is currently developing a National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Child and Maternal Health Framework (incorporating nutrition) which will complement and enhance existing activity in the area of Indigenous child and maternal health in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander primary health care sector.

In 2002-03, the Australian Government provided $120,000 to the Ngaanyatjarra Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara Women's Council (NPYWC) under the Department's Integrated Funding Agreement to facilitate a nutrition project for mothers, babies and other carers.

para.inline: National Child and Maternal Health Exemplar Site Initiative

answer.para: An Exemplar Site Initiative commenced in 2002-03. The primary purpose of the Initiative is to establish a service level mechanism to inform national, regional and local Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Child and Maternal Health policy development and service delivery. Funding of $145,000 has been provided to Townsville Aboriginal and Islander Health Services (TAIHS) in 2002-03 and $107,000 has been provided to Nganampa Health Council in 2003-04 under this Initiative.

para.inline: Office of Rural Health - Child and Maternal Health Pilot Projects

answer.para: In October 2002, funding of $500,000 per annum for 3 years ($1.5 million in total) was provided to conduct child and maternal health projects in rural and remote areas. The projects will be conducted within existing Office of Rural Health Regional Health Services to capitalise on existing infrastructure and capacity to deliver services.

Maternal and child health issues such as child nutrition are identified as priority actions in the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Nutrition Strategy and Action Plan 2000-2010 (NATSINSAP). The strategy focuses on Indigenous nutrition issues and forms an integral component of the National Public Health Partnership's broader agenda for action Eat Well Australia 2000-2010. Australian Government initiatives addressing some of these issues include the National Child Nutrition Program and the establishment of the National Obesity Taskforce.

The Australian Government is providing $13.6 million for the National Child Nutrition Program, a three-year community based grants program that aims to improve the diets of young Australian children aged 0-12 years and pregnant women in around 110 high need communities. Through this Program, the Australian Government directly funds projects that encourage community partnerships, build on existing infrastructure and programs, improve nutrition related knowledge and skills of children and their parents and improve access to nutritious food.

National Child Nutrition Program grants to remote Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities constitute over $4.3 million, representing 32% of the Program's total funding to 37 community-based projects. The Indigenous-specific round of the Program (Round 2) supports Indigenous communities to undertake 24 projects to improve the nutrition of children in Indigenous communities and to improve the literacy and numeracy levels of Indigenous children through nutrition projects.

In addition to Indigenous specific initiatives, two evaluation projects are receiving funding of $100,000 under the National Child Nutrition Program in Victoria and Western Australia. This involves evaluating clusters of similar projects including those with a focus on Indigenous children, schools, breastfeeding promotion and projects producing education materials. These projects are expected to be completed in 2004-05 and will help inform future policy.

As part of the work of the National Obesity Taskforce (established by Australian Health Ministers' Conference in November 2002), the Australian Government in collaboration with the West Australian Department of Health recently hosted an Indigenous workshop to identify and seek participant agreement on the priorities for action to address obesity among Indigenous people. The Workshop aimed to build on the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Nutrition Strategy and Action Plan 2000-2010 (NATSINSAP) endorsed by Australian Health Ministers' Conference in 2001. The results of the Workshop will be included in the final report by the Taskforce to Health Ministers in November 2003.

The Australian Government, though the Office for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health has undertaken a number of initiatives to strengthen Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander primary health care services' capacity in the prevention and management of chronic diseases, specifically renal disease, diabetes and cardiovascular disease.

The Australian Government has contributed $3.7 million in funding for specific chronic disease programs and initiatives between 1999-00 and 2002-03. Specific chronic disease programs and initiatives have included:

a number of specific projects that address the recommendations from the National Diabetes Strategy and Implementation Plan (1998) and the Office for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Diabetes Plan (1996) have been supported by the Australian Government;
trial programs for screening and management of renal disease in the primary health care setting in the Northern Territory and South Australia;
supporting the non-government sector to undertake research and policy development; and

commencing in 2003 the Australian Government is supporting a number of continuous improvement projects in the early detection and management of chronic diseases for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander primary heath care setting. The aims of these projects are to:

- to identify, in partnership with services, the essential elements of a sustainable comprehensive systems approach to the early detection and management of chronic diseases in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community controlled health care setting;
- to foster a continuous improvement approach to chronic disease early detection and management;
- to enhance the sharing of information arising from the projects between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander primary health care services; and
- to inform the development of a chronic diseases framework.

These projects and initiatives complement work being undertaken in mainstream health program areas. This includes the Sharing Health Care Initiative which is testing models of chronic condition self-management in urban, rural and remote settings. Self-management aims to help people with chronic conditions work in partnership with their health provider to better manage their condition and improve their quality of life. Under this initiative funding of $2.3 million is being provided to support five demonstration projects in Indigenous communities.

In addition, a Rural Chronic Disease Initiative is assisting small rural communities to prevent and better manage chronic conditions and preventable injuries by supporting skills development and leadership at the local level, developing and disseminating high quality information, and investing in innovative chronic disease and injury prevention and management projects. $0.68 million has been provided to support 9 projects in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities that have developed, and are now implementing, culturally appropriate local solutions for the prevention and better management of health issues. This includes improving awareness through promoting physical activity and healthy eating, improving access to healthy foods, increasing knowledge of risk factors, and developing effective support systems for people living with a chronic disease or injury.

In recognition of the burden of renal disease amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and poor access to renal replacement therapies particularly in rural and remote areas, the Australian Government has contributed $2.7million in capital funding for the establishment of three satellite dialysis facilities in partnership with the Health Departments of Western Australia, Queensland and Northern Territory: Western Australia - Broome ($0.5m), Queensland - Weipa/Bamaga ($1.0m) and Northern Territory - Tiwi Islands ($1.2). It is anticipated that information from these pilot renal dialysis sites will assist jurisdictions and the Australian Government in the identification of the components of a sustainable tertiary service delivered in a remote/primary health care context.

para.inline: The National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Eye Health Program

answer.para: The National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Eye Health Program commenced in 1998 following a Review of Eye Health in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities by Professor Hugh Taylor. Through increasing access to specialist eye health services within the context of comprehensive primary health care, the Program aims to address the range of eye health conditions experienced by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, such as cataract, diabetic retinopathy, trachoma and refractive error.
$11.6 million has been invested in the Eye Health Program over 1998-99 to 2001-02.

The Australian Government funds an ear and hearing health program that targets Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children up to five years old through screening and early intervention through the continued implementation of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Hearing Strategy 1995-99 (the Strategy). It was implemented in 1996 with initiatives in four complimentary areas: training and equipment; child health sites; capital infrastructure; and strategic research. In 2002-03 $2,212,600 was allocated for this program.

The Work Plan for Future Actions in Ear and Hearing Health was jointly developed by the Office for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health and the Office of Hearing Services. The Work Plan contains key actions drawn from the set of policy principles and strategies outlined in the Report on Commonwealth Funded Hearing Services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples: Strategies for Future Action. Implementation of the Work Plan will seek to improve service delivery, workforce and coordination of primary, secondary and tertiary hearing services.

Funding from the Office of Hearing Services for the Commonwealth Hearing Services Program in 2002-03 totalled $180.243 million, including $151.28 million for services provided to eligible adults under the Hearing Services Voucher System and $28.963 million for a range of Community Services Obligations, including services to eligible Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, delivered by Australian Hearing. This included expenditure of approximately $1 million in 2002-03 for the delivery of outreach services through the Australian Hearing Specialist Program for Indigenous Australians.
The National Indigenous Pneumococcal and Influenza Immunisation Program

The National Indigenous Pneumococcal and Influenza Immunisation Program aims to improve the health status of the Indigenous adult population by providing better access to preventive medicine at the primary health care level. Specific objectives of the immunisation program are to:

Reduce morbidity and mortality rates associated with the vaccine preventable pneumococcal (streptococcus pneumoniae) and influenza diseases through increasing pneumococcal and influenza immunisation coverage within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population; and
Prevent chronic respiratory problems as a consequence of pneumococcal and influenza disease.

The cohort population for both vaccines is all Indigenous people aged 50 years and over, and Indigenous people in the 15-49 years age group who meet the National Health and Medical Research Council recommendations for immunisation based on risk factor assessment.
In 2002-03 a total of $1,811,586 was provided for vaccine purchase and $352,500 for national and local communication strategies.

The National Childhood Pneumococcal Vaccination Program aims to reduce rates and severity of pneumococcal disease in high risk childhood populations in Australia and provides access to free pneumococcal vaccine for children considered at highest risk from invasive pneumococcal disease. The Program was endorsed by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) and funded ($19.21 million over the following 3 years, including catch-up) under the National Immunisation Program (NIP) in 2001. The Program targets four main groups:
all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children (aged under 2 years);
Aboriginal children in Central Australia and any region likely to have a similar very high incidence of pneumococcal infection (aged under 5 years);
non-Aboriginal children in Central Australia (aged under 2 years); and
children under 5 years of age with medical risk factors that predispose them to high rates or high severity of pneumococcal infection.

In September 2003, the Australian Government announced an expansion to the Program to include additional at risk children under the medical risk factors category. Following this expansion, the National Childhood Pneumococcal Vaccination Program will cost $21.23 million over the next four years and provide access to free vaccine for 91,000 children over this period.

As at 10 October 2003, a total of 44,180 children have received one or more doses of pneumococcal vaccine under the National Childhood Pneumococcal Vaccination Program. Of these, 19,498 children (44%) have consented to being identified as an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander on the Australian Childhood Immunisation Register (ACIR). The Australian Government, in partnership with State and Territory Governments and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander primary health care sector, is working to improve the level of identification of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander status on the ACIR.

Data provided by the Northern Territory and Queensland Health Departments at a pneumococcal workshop in 2002 and published in Communicable Diseases Intelligence Vol 27 No 1 April 2003, indicate that the uptake of the program is good.

In the Northern Territory 96% of the eligible cohort received the first dose of pneumococcal conjugate vaccine at 2 months of age. Approximately 74% of older children had commenced the catch-up schedule and 64% of older children had completed the catch-up schedule.
In Queensland the figures for children in the eligible cohort considered to be fully vaccinated varies according to region. In northern Queensland 69% of children were fully vaccinated.

In 2002-03, $11.8 million was allocated through the National Indigenous Australians' Sexual Health Strategy for prevention, treatment, care and support, workforce, research and data collection, and evaluation and monitoring projects.

The Australian Government makes funding available to the States and Territories under the Indigenous Sexual Health Program for the implementation of the National Indigenous Australians' Sexual Health Strategy. Projects managed include the following:

A significant number of projects involve the employment of male and female Indigenous sexual health workers in both the community controlled primary health sector and State-funded health sector. These positions provide a range of services including clinical treatment, counselling, contact tracing and STI Sexually Transmissible Infections (STIs) and HIV education.

Programs have been established to deliver comprehensive and opportunistic screening for STIs in a number of States and Territories, particularly those in Central and Northern Australia where the burden of disease is higher.

A total of $1million has been allocated for the 2.5 year life span of this project to eliminate Donovanosis from endemic regions of Australia. Funding supports the employment of four project officers (one in Western Australia, two in the Northern Territory and one in Queensland). The project officers support improvements in testing, community education, capacity building, screening programs, syndromic management and data collection. The project is overseen by the National Donovanosis Eradication Advisory Committee (NDEAC).

para.inline: Nucleic Acid Amplification (NAA/PCR) - STI Screening Program

answer.para: In the 1998-99 Budget the Australian Government announced the allocation of $10.5 million over four years for Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) testing in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations for the detection of STIs. The funding was allocated for PCR testing for gonorrhoea and chlamydia (and trichomonas in the Northern Territory only). The Program ensures that there are no direct costs to clients and that early detection and treatment for STIs is available, using non-invasive testing technology. In 2002, funding of $12.1 million was provided to extend the program for another 4 years.

para.inline: Substance Use (including smoking, poisoning and alcohol use)

answer.para: In 2002-03 the Australian Government provided funding of $16.4 million to support sixty-seven (67) Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander substance use services nationally. Forty-three (43) of these services are specific Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander substance use services. Thirty-four (34) of these are residential in status, while nine (9) are non-residential. The remaining twenty-four (24) are funded as part of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander primary health care services. These services predominantly support clients with issues in relation to alcohol.

The Australian Government directs funding towards improving access to appropriate educational material and health promotion information about alcohol and other drugs. In 2002-03 the Australian Government achieved this through a number of initiatives including:
Deadly Vibe Magazine and Deadly Sounds radio program to promote health related messages nationally to young people about alcohol, tobacco and other drugs - ($618,000).

One-off sponsorship funding towards a pilot television program `Beyond Their Limits'. This pilot program utilised Indigenous Australian Football League (AFL) players as a conduit for healthy lifestyle and health promotion messages to Aboriginal communities in rural and remote locations - ($104,000).

The second series of the National Indigenous 3on3 Basketball Challenge has been jointly funded between the Department of Health and Ageing, ATSIC and Rio Tinto that uses the medium of 3on3 street basketball to promote health and substance free lifestyles to young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples aged between 10 - 18 years of age - ($24,000).

In 1999 the Australian Government funded the development of National Recommendations for the Clinical Management of Alcohol in Indigenous Primary Health Care Settings to provide clinicians with a better understanding of the social context and natural history of alcohol use within Indigenous communities. The Clinical Recommendations are also used to improve practice and treatment approaches for clinicians in assisting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander patients who present with alcohol related problems.

The National Recommendations were implemented through a series of workshops across the country. A Report on the Implementation of the National Recommendations was provided to the Australian Government in 2002. The Report recommended the development of a strategy for regular review and update of the National Recommendations to include a similar initiative to address clinical management issues arising from other substance use. The Australian Government is currently reviewing a proposal to update the Recommendations.

In addition, in1999 the Australian Government provided funding for the printing and distribution of The Grog Book - Strengthening Indigenous Community Action on Alcohol. In 2001 the Australian Government developed the Flip Chart Talking about alcohol with Indigenous patients, a brief intervention tool for Indigenous alcohol use for use by general practitioners. The Flip Chart is currently being updated and the revised version will be distributed to all Australian Government-funded Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander primary health care services.

para.inline: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Tobacco Project

answer.para: In May 2002 (World No Tobacco Day), the Australian Government announced a package of measures worth $1 million over three years (2002-03 - 2004-05) designed to address tobacco use in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. The measures correspond to some of the most pressing needs identified in the National Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisation's report, Time for Action - National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Tobacco Control Project.
Subsequently, the Koori Health Centre (in Melbourne) was selected through an open tender process to undertake three projects including:

The establishment of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander tobacco control clearinghouse, supporting the collection and dissemination of information, and the promotion and uptake of best practice in Indigenous tobacco control;

The development of strategies aimed specifically at Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Workers to address the high smoking prevalence rate among this group and develop the groups' capacity to assist the community with smoking interventions; and
The development of culturally appropriate tobacco control resources targeted at Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

para.inline: Mainstream projects and initiatives addressing substance use issues

answer.para: The Australian Government supported the development of the National Drug Strategy Complementary Action Plan for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples. The Action Plan complements existing action plans and strategies under the National Drug Strategic Framework to ensure Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander substance use issues are addressed. The Complementary Action Plan was endorsed by the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy in August 2003.

In August 2003, the Prime Minister announced that $10.5 million will be made available to a new program - the National Drug Strategy Indigenous Community Initiative. Projects funded under the initiative will address key areas for action identified in the Complementary Action Plan and enable Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities to develop local solutions to prevent harmful substance use and violence.

$488,079 in 2002-03 under the National Illicit Drug Strategy Non-Government Organisations Treatment Grants Program for projects targeting illicit drug use within Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities (including petrol sniffing in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Lands of SA).

$210,000 in 2002-03 under the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) Illicit Drug Diversion Initiative to petrol sniffing programs in Central Australia and the Top End of the Northern Territory. This funding is drawn from the $1 million announced by the Prime Minister in February 2001.

The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) has provided $52,885 in 2002-03 to a consultant to conduct research around `The Policy Response to Indigenous Petrol Sniffing - and how to improve'. The primary purpose of this project is to examine governments' policy responses to petrol sniffing in the past, and to identify practicable changes that could reasonably be expected to lead to the accumulation of knowledge about effective interventions, and to the formulation of sustainable, evidence-based policies and programs.

$40,000 in 2002-03 for the Australian Alcohol Guidelines: Communicating with Indigenous Communities Project - resources being developed by the Aboriginal Drug and Alcohol Council of SA (ADAC) to convey to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people the messages contained in the NHMRC Australian Alcohol Guidelines regarding standard drinks and levels of low, medium and high risk drinking.

In response to the high incidence of preventable injuries amongst Indigenous communities, the National Public Health Partnership (NPHP) established the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Injury Prevention Action Committee (ATSIIPAC), to develop a National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Injury Prevention Plan: 2004 and beyond.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 1 October 2003:

question.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 1643 (Senate Hansard, 8 September 2003, p.14018);

(1) Given that there is an apparent discrepancy in the Australian Grand Prix Corporation's (AGPC) claim of 55 billion televisions viewers of the Formula 1 series, (350 million viewers per race, multiplied by 17, the number of races equals 5.9 billion, not 55 billion), and given that the figure of 350 million per race also cannot be proved, is the Minister satisfied that the Formula 1 Grand Prix is an event of international significance; if so, why.

(2) Given that according to the AGPC, spending by additional overseas visitors attracted by the Formula 1 Grand Prix equates to $15.3 million; that this spending equates to about $3 million in actual profit (assuming normal commercial margins); and that the operating loss of the event is now $10 to 12 million, a major factor being the race licence fee (believed to be $20-25 million, exported in US dollars): does the Minister consider that losing the event would cause economic hardship to Australia; if so, why.

(3) Given that the grounds on which the AGPC applied for an exemption from the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 appear to be incorrect, will the Minister give consideration to cancelling the exemption for the 2004 race; if not, why not.

(4) In light of the Government's recently-stated intention to sign the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control: (a) can the Government confirm that this includes a commitment not to permit the export of tobacco advertising; and (b) does this mean that the Australian Grand Prix, because it is broadcast worldwide, will not receive an exemption from the requirements of the Tobacco Advertising Act for 2004 and beyond; if not, why not.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Grand Prix Corporation has provided evidence that the event is of international significance. The evidence included a report prepared by the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research. The report found that in 2000, the Australian Grand Prix event attracted 19,627 overseas visitors (13.6% of the total attendance at the four day event). 7,556 of these overseas visitors visited Australia solely due to the staging of the Grand Prix.

(2) Economic hardship is not a factor that is required to be considered when granting an exemption under section 18 of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992. It is therefore not relevant to consider whether losing the Australian Grand Prix would cause economic hardship to Australia. To grant an exemption under section 18 of the Act, the Minister must be satisfied that the event is of international significance, and that a failure to specify the event would be likely to result in the event not being held in Australia.

(3) There is nothing to indicate that the grounds upon which the AGPC applied for an exemption from the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 for the 2003 Australian Grand Prix were incorrect. The AGPC's applications for exemptions under section 18 of the Act for the 2003 and 2004 events satisfied the Minister that the events were of international significance, and that failure to specify the events would be likely to result in the events not being held in Australia. There is therefore no reason to consider cancelling the exemption for the 2004 event.

(4) (a) and (b) The Framework Convention on Tobacco Control requires a comprehensive ban on tobacco advertising, as opposed to a total ban. This was acknowledged and understood by the Government in coming to a decision to sign the Convention.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 October 2003:

quote.para: For each of the following financial years: 2001-02, 2002-03 and 2003-04 to date; on how many occasions has the department and its agencies been swept for listening devices; and for each sweep can the following information be provided: (a) when the sweep was undertaken; (b) where the sweep was undertaken; (c) when the sweep was ordered and who ordered it; (d) why the sweep was ordered; (e) who conducted the sweep; and (f) what was the result of the sweep including, if applicable, the nature of any discovery, the resulting investigation, and details of any action taken against any persons.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: In accordance with good security practice, departments and agencies undertake Technical Surveillance Counter-Measures testing (`sweeps' for listening devices) as and when required.
Some agencies maintain their own sweeping capability, while others engage ASIO to conduct testing for them.
The reasons for sweeping, and the timing and results of sweeps are not made public for reasons of national security, in accordance with the practice of successive governments.

subdebateinfo.title: Health and Ageing: National Drug Research Committee
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2184)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 3 October 2003:

question.para: (1) Did the Intergovernmental Committee on Drugs establish a National Drug Research Committee to identify research needed to fill gaps in knowledge concerning the development of illicit drug policy.

(2) Has the National Drug Research Committee prepared a draft National Drug Research Strategy; if so: (a) when was it provided to the Minister; (b) what is the status of the strategy; and (c) what research does it propose.
(3) When is it expected that the Intergovernmental Committee on Drugs will meet to consider the draft National Drug Research Strategy.
(4) Has the Intergovernmental Committee on Drugs already decided not to endorse the draft National Drug Research Strategy; if so, why.
(5) Can the Minister table a copy of the draft National Drug Research Strategy; if not, why not.
(6) Does the Government accept that it is still possible for the operations of drug syndicates to be profitable even if they lose up to 90 per cent of their product to seizures.
(7) Has the Commonwealth commissioned research into the economic drivers of the illicit drug market; if not, does it plan to do so, and when.
(8) Has the Commonwealth commissioned research into the marketing strategies of drug syndicates; if not, does it plan to do so.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. I have been advised that the Intergovernmental Committee on Drugs established a National Drug Research Committee in 1999.
(2) The National Drug Research Committee prepared a Draft National Drug Research Strategy for the consideration of the Intergovernmental Committee on Drugs.
(a) The Draft National Drug Research Strategy has not been provided to the Minister.
(b) The Draft National Drug Research Strategy is a working document and has not been cleared by all state and territory government members of the Committee.
(c) I am unable to respond to this question until the state and territory government members of the Committee endorse the document. See (b) above.
(3) I have referred this question to the Chair of the Intergovernmental Committee on Drugs for response.
(4) I have referred this question to the Chair of the Intergovernmental Committee on Drugs for response.
(5) The Department of Health and Ageing has contacted members of the Intergovernmental Committee on Drugs to see if they are prepared to clear the document.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, upon notice, on 7 October 2003:

quote.para: With reference to the Halcombe Hill section of the New England Highway and in particular, the railway overpass bridge, approximately 3 kilometres north of Aberdeen and 10 kilometres south of Scone:

question.para: (1) How many accidents have there been along this stretch of road since September 1997, including the recent fatal accident that occurred on Wednesday, 1 October 2003.

(2) How many fatalities and serious injuries have occurred as a result of accidents along this section of road since September 1997, including the four fatalities that occurred on Wednesday, 1 October 2003.

(3) Has the Commonwealth provided any funding for any projects along this stretch of road since 1996; if so: (a) what was the cost and nature of the projects undertaken; and (b) have any such projects been completed and if so, when.

(4) Does the Commonwealth have any plans to fund any new projects along the Halcombe Hill section of the highway that might rectify it as a safety blackspot; if not, why not; if so (a) what is the cost and nature of the project(s); and (b) when will the project(s) be completed.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The following information has been provided by the New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority (RTA). Accident data for the Hunter Region for the period 1/1/1998 to 30/4/2003 indicates that there have been 11 reported accidents at Halcombe Hill over the above period. The advice from the RTA does not include the recent fatality on 1 October 2003. The RTA also advises that data for the period from 30/4/2003 is not yet available.
(2) Advice from the RTA is that there have been 4 fatalities and 6 serious accidents, (those involving injuries) along this section of road. (This includes the recent accident on 1 October 2003).

(3) The Australian Government has provided $433,000 under the National Highway Safety and Urgent Works Programme in 1998/99 - 1999/00 for the widening of the eastern side of the curve to increase the radius, providing a 2.8m painted median and reconstructing the existing shoulder.

(4) Following the accident on 1 October 2003, a request has been made to the RTA for an urgent report on this section of the National Highway. Once this report has been received, consideration will be given to any recommended safety improvements. As an interim measure, the RTA has reduced the speed limit at Halcombe Hill until a full investigation of this site has been completed and necessary safety improvements have been identified.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 7 October 2003:

question.para: (1) At what rate are Australian children currently being formally diagnosed with an autistic disorder.
(2) At what rate are Australian children currently being diagnosed with Asperger's Syndrome.
(3) Are the rates of diagnosis higher than was previously observed for: (a) an autistic disorder; (b) Asperger's Syndrome; and (c) pervasive developmental disorders/Autism spectrum disorders (ASD).

(4) Is Professor Fiona Stanley, Australian of the Year and a senior epidemiologist, correct about the existence of an epidemic of autism; if so: (a) what is the extent of the epidemic; (b) is the Government concerned about this epidemic; and (c) what action is the Government taking in relation to the increasing numbers of ASD diagnoses among Australian children.

(5) Given that information from authoritative sources in the United States, that outcomes for children with (untreated) Autism are especially poor; and the findings of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition, Text Revisions (DSM-IV-TR) that: `Available follow-up studies suggest that only a small percentage of individuals with the disorder go on as adults to live and work independently. In about one-third of cases, some degree of partial independence is possible. The highest functioning adults with Autistic Disorder typically continue to exhibit problems in social interaction and communication along with markedly restricted interests and activities.' (p.73); and given that the United States Senate reported that `Three quarters of those with autism spend their adult lives in institutions or group homes, and usually enter institutions by the age of 13'; does a similar situation exist in Australia.
(6) What proportion of Australian adults with autism live independently.
(7) What proportion of Australians with autism work independently.

(8) How many, or what proportion of, Australian children aged 13 years or older with autism spend on average one or more nights per week in care or away from their family home: (a) is the level of unmet need for this type of service measured and reported; if so, how is it measured; and (b) what is the observed level of unmet need.
(9) What other long-term outcomes are observed or reported for Australians with Autism.
(10) What specific treatment do Australians with autism receive for their disorder.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (2) and (3), (a), (b) and (c) There are no national data on the diagnostic profiles of people with autistic disorder, Asperger's syndrome and pervasive developmental disorders/autism spectrum disorders (ASD). Autism is one of a number of intellectual and developmental disorders that are clustered together under the International Classification of Disease (ICD10) guidelines which describe autism as `a type of pervasive developmental disorder'.

Autism Spectrum Disorders are a general classification within the group of Pervasive Developmental Disorders and encompass a range of subtypes of autism (Asperger's Disorder and Autistic Disorder) with varying degrees of severity. In general, Autism Spectrum Disorders are a group of disorders that have in common lifelong developmental disability. The disorders are thought to be caused by dysfunction in parts of the central nervous system that affects the way the individual processes information. There is no cure for the disorders though changes in ability and behaviour occur over time, and some individuals show remarkable improvement throughout their lives.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not separately identify data on autism. Autism is not a reportable medical condition and the numbers of autistic children identified in the 1998 Survey of Disability, Ageing and Carers is self reported and are relatively small and subject to sampling error.
Autism is a disability condition with disability services being primarily the responsibility of the Department of Family and Community Services.
(4) (a), (b) and (c) We have no evidence by which to assess this.
(5) We have no evidence by which to assess whether a similar situation exists in Australia.

(6) (7), (8) (a) and (b) and (9) As stated in Questions 1, 2 and 3 above, there are no national data on the diagnostic profiles of people with autistic disorder and/or Asperger's syndrome and/or pervasive developmental disorders.
(10) The provision of treatment is the responsibility of the treating clinician. Therefore, I cannot specifically comment on this question.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs: Identification Cards
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2188)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 7 October 2003:

question.para: Does the department still provide `miniature evidentiary certificates', that is, the credit card sized identification cards containing information equivalent to that of a naturalisation certificate, to naturalised Australians; if not, is the department considering re-introducing such a card as a convenient, portable alternative for the A4-sized naturalisation certificates; if not, why not.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The practice of providing evidence of Australian citizenship in the form of a credit card-size “declaratory certificate” ceased on 31 October 1984 following concerns expressed by the Stewart Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking, about misuse of the card as an identity document.

There are no plans to reintroduce the credit card-size citizenship identification card. The citizenship certificate, in its current format, is sufficiently portable for use on those few occasions when a person is required to produce evidence of Australian citizenship.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 8 October 2003:

question.para: (1) Since, 1996, what funding has the Government provided for research or any projects involving the platypus.
(2) Is the platypus endangered or threatened overall in any of the regions it inhabits; if so: (a) in what way; and (b) what remedy is being sought.
(3) Are any platypuses kept in captivity; if so: (a) where are they; (b) for what purpose are they kept in captivity; and (c) who approved their capture and why.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Under the Natural Heritage Trust and the Grants to Voluntary Environment and Heritage Organisations, the Government has provided $250,903 to projects involving the platypus since 1996.

(2) The platypus is listed as endangered in South Australia, being considered to be extinct on the mainland part of the State and existing in a translocated population on Kangaroo Island. It is not currently listed as threatened under national legislation or any other State legislation:
(a) the specific reason for the decline of the Platypus on the South Australian mainland is not known; and
(b) as far as I am aware, the South Australian Government has no targetted programs for the recovery of the Platypus.

(a) According to the Regional Census and Plan by the Australasian Regional Association of Zoos and Aquaria (ARAZPA), published 1 January 2003, there are 9 male and 8 female platypuses held at 4 different ARAZPA member institutions, with an aim of increasing this total to 13 males and 14 females across 7 institutions.
The following ARAZPA member institutions currently hold platypuses:

Not all institutions that hold platypuses in captivity are members of ARAZPA. For instance, platypuses may also be held by Universities and other institutions such as the Warrawong Earth Sanctuary in South Australia;

(b) Each captive population is held for a variety of purposes relating to exhibition, education, conservation and research as determined by the individual institutions in accordance with relevant State and Territory legislation;

(c) The collection of platypuses from the wild falls under the jurisdiction of State and Territory Governments. Each State and Territory has laws relating to the taking of native animals from the wild.
Permits or licences for the taking of native wildlife are issued by the following agencies:
NSW - National Parks and Wildlife Service
SA - Department for the Environment and Heritage
Vic - Department of Sustainability and Environment
Tas - Department of Primary Industries, Water and Environment
WA - Department of Conservation and Land Management

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Research Council: Energy Research and Development Projects
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2192)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 9 October 2003:

question.para: (1) Can details be provided of all renewable energy research and development projects that have received funding from the Australian Research Council since 1 July 1998.

(2) Can details be provided of all renewable energy research and development projects that have received funding from the Commonwealth since 1 July 1998, other than those projects that have received funding from the Australian Research Council.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Science and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Since 1998, the Australian Research Council has funded 126 new projects in the field of renewable energy research and development, to a total sum of $51,062,318. Details of these projects are provided at Attachment A.

(2) Support for renewable energy research and development projects from within the Education, Science and Training portfolio, apart from the ARC, is provided through the Australian CRC for Renewable Energy (ACRE) and CSIRO.

ACRE aims to brings together excellent research capabilities and market knowledge into a world class centre for innovation and for the commercialisation of renewable energy systems. The Department of Education, Science and Training provides block funding to ACRE but does not specify the projects that ACRE should support. Since 1998, ACRE has received the following amounts from the Commonwealth:

The table at Attachment B lists the renewable energy research projects and consultancies conducted by CSIRO since July 1998 and the CSIRO research division where the research has been carried out. The CSIRO list includes areas of research activity as well as research projects and as a result, exact funding amounts have been difficult to obtain. CSIRO will provide funding details to the Senate as soon as it has been compiled.

The project list has been determined using the ABS Social and Economic Objective (SEO) code group entitled “Renewable Energy”. It should be emphasised that there are other SEO categories likely to encompass some aspects of renewable energy research, such as those covered by Conservation and Efficiency (SEO 060400) or Energy Distribution (SEO 060300).
