subdebateinfo.title: Australian Greenhouse Office: Energy Research and Development Projects
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2194)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 8 October 2003:

question.para: Can details be provided of all renewable energy research and development projects that have received funding from the Australian Greenhouse Office since 1 July 1998.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: There have been no renewable energy research and development projects funded through the Australian Greenhouse Office.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 9 October 2003:

quote.para: With reference to the article in the Melbourne Herald Sun of 3 October 2003, `Mobiles Lacking Radiation Research', and in particular, remarks made by Dr Colin Roy, Director of the non-ionising radiation branch of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency: Does the Government intend to fund a replication of the Dutch study in Australia; if not, why not.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Herald Sun article was in response to a report on a Dutch study which was quoted as reporting that electromagnetic fields generated by 3G mobile phone base stations can affect well-being and cognitive powers.

Since 1996, the Australian Government has provided significant funding for a research and public information program into Electromagnetic Energy Research. The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) administers the research component of this program. This ensures that funded research in this area is of the highest scientific standard, and complements studies being undertaken overseas.

Through the NHMRC, Australia is part of a worldwide research effort facilitated by the World Health Organization (WHO) into possible health risks of electromagnetic fields, including mobile phone use. The WHO Research Coordination Committee is monitoring studies in electromagnetic field exposure, with a final WHO assessment not expected before 2005.

The 2001 Federal Budget clearly conveyed the Government's continued commitment to supporting research into the health effects of electromagnetic radiation. A levy on the industry provides $1 million per annum for Australian-based research, public information and collaboration with the WHO's international research effort.

It is not appropriate for the NHMRC to consider funding a validation of the Dutch study until it has been published and reviewed by independent assessors who deem the research to be of such considerable significance that it should be added to, for example, the WHO research agenda.

subdebateinfo.title: Environment and Heritage: Air Transport System
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2196)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 8 October 2003:

question.para: With reference to the Australian Antarctic Division's proposed Air Transport System (ATS): Has the initial environmental evaluation (IEE) for the operation of CASA 212 aircraft on the intra-continental segment of the proposed ATS been concluded; if so, why was it not made available for public comment; if not, why has the Australian Antarctic Division committed $66 million over 12 years to operate CASA 212 aircraft on the intra-continental segment of the system before the IEE has been completed.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: A referral for the air transport system under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 was lodged on 12 September 2002. The referral was made available for public comment for a period of ten working days following the lodgement. On 14 October 2002 the Minister for the Environment and Heritage decided that the proposal was not a controlled action provided that it was conducted in a specified manner. The Australian Antarctic Division entered into a contract for the provision of the intracontinental component of the air transport system subsequent to this decision under the EPBC Act.

A draft IEE, under the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980, has been prepared and its availability for public comment will be notified in the Government Notices Gazette of 5 November 2003. CASA 212 aircraft operations are planned to commence in the 2004/05 season after the assessment process is satisfactorily completed.

subdebateinfo.title: Environment and Heritage: Air Transport System
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2197)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 8 October 2003:

question.para: With reference to the Australian Antarctic Division's proposed Air Transport System (ATS):

(1) Can the Minister confirm that once the sea ice melts from mid-to late December onwards, the aircraft will have to operate on the ice plateau about 30 kilometres from the Davis station; if so, is the only means of transport from the skiway to the station by helicopter.
(2) What is the projected number of helicopter flights transporting passengers and cargo from the skiway to the station.
(3) What is the projected quantity of fuel that will have to be transported to the skiway, including that needed for intra-station flights and for science and other operational related flights.
(4) What will be the impact on wildlife and the environment from these helicopter flights.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: — The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes, the sea ice can become unsuitable for aircraft operations from around December onwards. When the sea ice is no longer suitable for aircraft operations, flying would need to be conducted from a skiway located near or on the ice plateau. The location of the site varies depending on snow and ice conditions and can be up to 30 kms from Davis station. The most practical means of accessing the skiway is helicopter.
(2) Approximately 100 if the air transport system is implemented in full.

(3) Approximately 46,000 litres if the air transport system is implemented in full. However, overall fuel usage is expected to decrease due to the reduced requirement for early and late season voyages to transport passengers. For example, a single early season voyage uses approximately 1,500,000 litres.
(4) Negligible. Flight routes from the Davis station to the skiway location are determined to ensure that impact on wildlife and the environment are negligible.

subdebateinfo.title: Environment and Heritage: Air Transport System
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2198)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 8 October 2003:

question.para: With reference to the Australian Antarctic Division's proposed Air Transport System (ATS):

(1) Does the ATS require the construction of a rock and gravel runway at Davis station in order to operate successfully; if so, why has the proposal to construct this runway not been included in the environmental assessments and public consultation relating to the ATS.

(2) Given that both the current proposed ATS and a rock and gravel runway would cause environmental damage, is the construction of this runway for intra-continental aircraft at Davis station a more or less efficient, safe and environmentally damaging system than that proposed under the ATS; if so, why; if not, why not.

(3) If the current ATS proceeds, does the Australian Antarctic Division rule out seeking environmental approval for a rock and gravel runway now or in the foreseeable future; if not, will the Minister rule out approving such a runway proposal.

(4) Given the uncertainty surrounding a possible rock and gravel runway, will the Minister establish an independent evaluation of the ATS, with particular reference to the Davis Plateau link, to determine whether the link as proposed is flawed and should not proceed.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) to (4) The AAD does not intend to construct a rock or gravel runway.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 8 October 2003:

question.para: (1) In relation to the 2002 agreement between the Commonwealth and Queensland, that the total number of spectacled flying-foxes to be killed in accordance with state permits/licences in the 2002-03 fruit season would not exceed 1.5 per cent of the agreed national population estimate for the species, what population estimate was used for spectacled flying-foxes in the 2002-03 fruit season.

(2) In relation to the 2002 agreement between the Commonwealth and Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland, that the total number of grey-headed flying-foxes to be killed in accordance with state permits/licenses in the 2002-03 fruit season would not exceed 1.5 per cent of the lowest agreed national population estimate for the species, what population estimate was used for grey-headed flying-foxes in the 2002-03 fruit season.

(3) In relation to the Commonwealth announcement, that the same cooperative flying-fox management and conservation approach implemented by the states and Commonwealth in 2002 be instituted for the 2003-04 fruit season: What population estimate will be used for: (a) spectacled flying-foxes and (b) grey-headed flying-foxes in the 2003-04 fruit season.
(4) What funding has the Commonwealth allocated for the preparation of the recovery plan for: (a) the spectacled flying-fox; and (b) the grey-headed flying-fox.

(5) What funding has the Commonwealth provided for: (a) the establishment of nets on fruit farms to protect fruit crops from flying-foxes; (b) research into the conservation status of grey-headed flying-foxes, spectacled flying-foxes and any other species of flying-foxes that are suspected to be at risk of extinction; and (c) research into non-lethal methods of protecting fruit crops from flying-foxes.

(6) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 1833 (Senate Hansard, 7 October 2003, p.15825), in which the Minister stated that the Commonwealth is supporting national population counts for spectacled and grey-headed flying-foxes, can further details be provided concerning: (a) the population counts that are being conducted, including who is responsible for the counts, and where these are being carried out; and (b) how the Commonwealth is supporting the national population counts, including details of any funding provided by the Commonwealth.

(7) Given the fact that, when a female flying-fox that is nursing a juvenile is killed, the juvenile is also likely to die, will the Minister consider amending the Administrative Guidelines for grey-headed and spectacled flying-foxes to ensure that killing a member of either of these species during the peak birthing season is a controlled action for the purposes of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

(8) Can information be provided concerning the natural mortality rates of grey-headed and spectacled flying-foxes; if so, can this information be provided no later than 5pm on Wednesday, 15 October 2003.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The population estimate used for the spectacled flying-fox in the 2002-03 fruit season was 120,000 animals.
(2) The population estimate used for the Grey-headed Flying-fox in the 2002-03 fruit season was 320,000 animals.
(3) The population estimates that will be used for the 2003-04 fruit season will be (a) 120,000 for the spectacled flying-fox and (b) 320,000 for the Grey-headed Flying-fox.

(4) The Australian Government has allocated (a) $52,442 for the preparation of the recovery plan for the spectacled flying-fox, and (b) $66,784 for the preparation of the recovery plan for the Grey-headed Flying-fox.

(5) (a) The Australian Government has provided $29,980 under the Natural Heritage Trust for a fruit-grower in North Queensland to trial a retractable orchard netting system to be used by the fruit-growing industry, as a means of non-lethal control of flying-foxes.

(b) The Australian Government has to date provided $23,650 towards the national counts of Grey-headed Flying-foxes, the results of which are used in assessing the conservation status of the Grey-headed Flying-fox.

The Australian Government has not provided funding towards research into the conservation status of the spectacled flying-fox, but has worked cooperatively with the Queensland State Government who have undertaken their own population counts of the species.
(c) The Australian Government has provided around $140,000 towards research into non-lethal methods of protecting fruit crops from flying-foxes.

(6) (a) The national population counts for the Grey-headed Flying-fox will be facilitated by New South Wales, with assistance and cooperation from Queensland and Victoria. An independent national coordinator, whom the Australian Government will provide funding for, will oversee the national counts. Queensland will facilitate the population counts for the spectacled flying-fox. The counts are carried out at known Grey-headed Flying-fox and spectacled flying-fox campsites, both permanent and temporary, within the ranges of the two species.
(b) The Australian Government provided $23,650 towards the national counts of Grey-headed Flying-foxes in 2002-03 and it is expected that it will provide a similar amount of funding during 2003-04.

(7) A take of 1.5per cent of the agreed national population of Grey-headed and spectacled flying-foxes is a precautionary figure, which recognises that both natural and unnatural mortality occurs within flying-fox populations.
(8) Flying-fox researchers and carers suggest a 10per cent natural mortality rate for both Grey-headed Flying-foxes and spectacled flying-foxes, although this figure may vary from year to year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 9 October 2003:

quote.para: In relation to the report of the Strategic Leaders Group for the Mineral Exploration Action Agenda: (a) which of the 12 recommendations does the Minister accept; (b) when will those recommendations accepted be implemented; and (c) has funding been allocated to implement these recommendations in each of the following financial years: (i) 2003-04, (ii) 2004-05, (iii) 2005-06.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator Minchin
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: I initiated the development of a Mineral Exploration Action Agenda as part of a two-pronged approach to address significant structural changes in the mineral exploration sector which threaten to impede future growth.

The 12 recommendations made by the Strategic Leaders Group in their July report represented a suite of measures which were then further complemented with the release of the Prosser Inquiry report in September.
The Prosser reports' 28 recommendations reflected the major issues raised by the SLG, and also addressed a number of petroleum industry specific issues.
A comprehensive government response to recommendations made in both reports will incorporate measures to address a range of issues affecting resources exploration in Australia.

answer.para: The cost implication of these measures has been considered.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 9 October 2003:

question.para: With reference to the development of the Nanotechnology industry in Australia:

(1) (a) What funding has been allocated to the nanotechnology (nanoscience) industry per year over the past 5 financial years; and (b) how much will this expenditure increase over the next 5 financial years.
(2) What is the nanotechnology industry currently worth to the Australian economy.
(3) What regulations are in place to govern the research and use of nanotechnology in Australia.
(4) What steps has the department taken to ensure that substances, materials, products etc, produced using nanotechnology will not have a detrimental effect on the total environment.

(5) Will organisations that are using the technology be required to follow the precautionary principle i.e., the proponents must confirm that there will be no harm to any part of the environment for each product developed.
(6) Are there current labelling regulations for products developed through the use of nanotechnology; if not, will the Minister introduce such regulations in the near future.
(7) Is there a register of products, covering all industries including medical and information technology, which have been and will be developed using nanotechnology.
(8) Will an agency be established to ensure nanotechnology is used in an ethical manner.
(9) Will the Minister facilitate a full public debate on the use of this technology, as was the case with genetic engineering.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator Minchin
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) No specific funding programs have been established specifically for the nanotechnology industry in the past 5 financial years by the Industry, Tourism and Resources portfolio. The Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources, guided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics Australian and New Zealand Standard Industrial Classification (ANZSIC), does not recognise a nanotechnology industry. Nanotechnology is an enabling technology that has possible applications across many industries.
The Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources has supported specific nanotechnology initiatives through the Innovation Access Program and through Invest Australia.
(b) No specific funding programs have been allocated to the nanotechnology industry in the next 5 financial years by the Industry, Tourism and Resources portfolio.

The Industry, Tourism and Resources portfolio delivers a variety of competitive grants programs. Projects that utilise nanotechnology are eligible to receive competitive grants funding. It is not possible to foresee the type or value of projects that will be successful in applying for grant funding in the future.

Invest Australia funding for the next 5 years will be consistent with Global Returns: The National Strategic Framework for Attracting Foreign Direct Investment. Invest Australia has a dedicated team with a focus on nanotechnology which is implementing a national approach to promoting Australian nanotechnology capability and facilitating foreign investment.
(2) Statistics relating to the value of an Australian nanotechnology industry are not available, due to reasons provided in (1) (a) above.
For qualitative examples of industry applications of nanotechnology see:

Department of Industry, Science and Resources, Proceedings and Outcomes Report of a 30 March 2001 Workshop on Nanotechnology in Australian Industry. 2001. http://www/ library/content_library/NanoWorkshopReport.pdf
Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources, Occasional Paper #16: Nanotechnology Applications and Opportunities for Australian Industry. 2002.

(3) The Industry, Tourism and Resource portfolio is not responsible for the first element of question (3) relating to regulations governing research into nanotechnology. The Minister for Science, Education and Training has responded to this element of the question (see QoN1661, Hansard, Monday 8 September 2003, page 14564).
ITR is not aware of nanotechnology-specific regulations governing the use of nanotechnology by Australian industry over and above any current industry-related regulatory arrangements.

(4) The Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources does not have regulatory responsibility in this area. Responsibility is with other portfolios, eg the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), the National Industrial Chemicals Notification and Assessment Scheme for industrial chemicals (NICNAS) and the Office of Gene Regulation within the Department of Health and Ageing, and various environmental regulations either within the Department of the Environment and Heritage or within State Governments.
(5) The Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources does not have regulatory responsibility in this area.

(6) As far as ITR is aware, labelling regulations in Australia are not specific to nanotechnology. As outlined in the response to question (3) above, Australian industries are governed by regulations specific to their business. A case would need to be made to the responsible Ministers and agencies that the current regulatory arrangements are not sufficient.

(7) The development of a register of products which have been and will be developed using nanotechnology does not lie within the current responsibilities of the Industry, Tourism and Resources portfolio. The Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources is not aware of any industry specific registers that capture nanotechnology use. A case would need to be made to the responsible Ministers and agencies that the current regulatory arrangements are not sufficient.

(8) The Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources is not aware of any plan to establish such an agency. A case would need to be made to the responsible Ministers and agencies that the current government structures arrangements are not sufficient.

(9) The Industry, Tourism and Resources portfolio would support and participate in any public debate on nanotechnology. As noted in our response to question (2), the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources has published two recent reports on nanotechnology.

subdebateinfo.title: Roads and Railways: New South Wales North Coast
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2206)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 October 2003:

quote.para: With reference to the north coast railway: What Commonwealth funding has been provided for:
(a) the construction of the divided Pacific Highway between Newcastle and Tweed Heads; and
(b) major improvement of the North Coast railway between Broadmeadow and Murwillumbah.
If no funding has been provided, why not.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (a) Commonwealth funding provided for the construction of the divided Pacific Highway between Newcastle and Tweed Heads is $600 million over the ten year period 1996/97 to 2005/06.

(b) The Australian Government and Australian Rail Track Corporation (ARTC) have proposed to lease the mainline rail corridors in NSW including the North Coast line. As part of that proposal more than $870m would be invested on the NSW track including some $122m on the North Coast line from Maitland to the Queensland Border.
The line to Murwillumbah from Casino (which is on the North Coast line) is a branch line and not part of the lease proposal and will remain the funding responsibility of the NSW Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 9 October 2003:

question.para: (1) What was Centrelink's expenditure on contracting private sector recruitment companies to recruit non-executive staff for each of the following financial years: (a) 2000-01; (b) 2001-02; and (c) 2002-03.

(2) (a) Can a list of these companies be provided indicating whether they are, or were, a Job Network provider or a Government-approved job placement organisation; and (b) how many people have been recruited through the use of such companies.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator Patterson
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: These figures include payments made to Employment National Oz Jobs which became a private sector company in November 2002.

(2) (a) As with all procurement processes, value for money is the primary consideration. Job Network status is therefore not relevant to the process for selecting recruitment organisations. A significant proportion of these organisations would also be providing services to Centrelink jobseekers under ESC3 and its predecessors. Centrelink also has local arrangements for filling short term, temporary roles through local Job Network Members.
The following is a list of recruitment organisations who assisted in general non-executive recruitment over the last three financial years.
(2) (b) The total number of staff recruited by Centrelink is shown in the following table.

talk.start.para: asked all Ministers, upon notice, on 14 October 2003:

answer.para: I am replying on behalf of all Ministers.
The Australian Government has had no communications with the facilitator in relation to increasing the use of fuel ethanol in the Australian Government's fleet of vehicles.

(6) What steps has the department taken to ensure that paper and paper products sourced by the department from other countries comply with the ISO 14001 environmental management system standard.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Campbell
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) During 2001-02, the Department spent $416,184.89 (GST exclusive) on paper and paper products, and in 2002-03, the Department spent $498,923.87 (GST exclusive) on paper and paper products.

(2) During 2001-02, the Department sourced these products from Australia and the European Union, and in 2002-03, the Department sourced these products from Australia, Indonesia, and the European Union.

(3) During 2001-02, the companies that the Department sourced these products from were Fuji Xerox, National 1, Boise, Spicers Office Papers, SPS Supply, BHP, Paragon, Panther and CPP, and during 2002-03 the products were sourced from the following companies: BHP, CPP, Union Offset, Pirion, Fuji Xerox, Corporate Express, Boise, Spicers Office Papers, National 1, and SPS Supply.
(4) The percentage of the total of paper and paper products in value (in AUD) sourced by the Department by country in 2001-02 was:
The percentage of the total of paper and paper products in value (in AUD) sourced by the Department by country in 2002-03 was:

(5) The percentage of the total of paper and paper products in value (in AUD) sourced by the Department by company, and percentage breakdown of paper and paper products for companies during 2001-02 was:
The percentage of the total of paper and paper products in value (in AUD) sourced by the Department by company, and percentage breakdown of paper and paper products for companies during 2002-03 was:
(6) The Department has taken steps to ensure that paper and paper products sourced by the department from other countries comply with ISO 14001 environmental management system.

In keeping with ISO 140001, the Department's Environmental Policy commits the Department to operating in an ecologically sustainable manner. The Department endeavours to incorporate the National Packaging Covenant principles in its operations, and routinely takes opportunities to influence purchasing decisions by its outsourced providers by ensuring they comply with the Australian Government procurement policy to consider all relevant environmental policies, programs, costs and benefits when making purchasing decisions.

The Department is in the process of developing its Environmental Management System (EMS) and, through the preliminary environmental audits, has identified that it can have an impact on the consumption of paper and paper products. To date the Department has focused on purchasing paper sourced from recycled pulp and new pulp from sustainable managed plantations within Australia. However, the Department is currently engaged in discussions with outsourced providers (such as the cleaning contractor) to encourage them to routinely seek out paper products sourced from more sustainable processes.

Senator Ian Macdonald

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of the Environment and Heritage spent $548,300 in 2001-02 and $471,900 in 2002-03.

(2) Almost all paper and paper products procured by the Department are sourced in Australia. A small quantity of copy paper supplied by a third party provider in Darwin was sourced in Austria. It is possible that other paper stock provided under unrelated contractual arrangements such as cleaning could also be sourced from countries other than Australia.

(3) Paper and paper products are procured from many sources across Australia. It is difficult to identify all companies which supply paper and paper products because these products are often supplied under unrelated contractual arrangements such as printing, cleaning and copying services. Some of the companies providing significant quantities of paper and paper products to the Department include:

(4) It is estimated that approximately 95% of paper and paper products are sourced in Australia with the remaining 5% sourced in Austria. For the reasons outlined in (3) it is difficult to provide a precise response.
(5) The percentage of the total of paper and paper products by value for the Department's principal suppliers may be summarised as follows:

(6) Although the majority of the Department's office-based activities are certified by independent audit as complying with the International Standard ISO 14001, no specific steps are taken to ensure that products sourced from other countries comply with the standard.

answer.para: Due to the wide scope of possible interpretations of “paper products” the Department is aligning its response with that of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM&C) to include: photocopying and printer paper; envelopes; paper towels; and toilet paper. The majority of paper products used by the Department of Education, Science and Training are sourced on our behalf by our major paper supplier Boise Office Products and our printer JS McMillan Pty Ltd.

(6) The Department fully supports environmentally friendly products and practices and has taken the following steps to ensure that the paper and paper products sourced from other countries by our major paper supplier comply with ISO 14001 environmental management standard:
Under the Department's contract Boise Office Products supplies 99% Australian made paper. That paper is sourced from Australia's largest mill, Maryvale Mill which is fully compliant with ISO 14001.

The Department's service level agreement in its contract with JS McMillan also requires compliance with its environmental management policies including use of recycled Australian made paper unless there is no suitable product for specialised printing requirements.
The steps outlined above result in the predominant use of recycled Australian made paper product by the Department.

talk.start.para: asked all Ministers, upon notice, on 14 October 2003:

question.para: In relation to the department's vehicle fleet:
(1) How many litres of petrol did the department use for its fleet in each of the following financial years: (a) 2001-02; and (b) 2002-03.
(2) How many litres of petrol blended with fuel ethanol did the department's fleet use in each of the following financial years: (a) 2001-02; and (b) 2002-03.
(3) What steps are being taken to ensure that the department's fleet can operate on fuel ethanol (E10) safely and without voiding any manufacturer's warranty.
(4) What steps are being taken to ensure that the department uses fuel ethanol (E10) in its fleet.
(5) How many litres of diesel did the department's fleet use in each of the following financial years: (a) 2001-02; and (b) 2002-03.
(6) How many litre of biodiesel did the department's fleet use in each of the following financial years: (a) 2001-02; and (b) 2002-03.
(7) What steps are being taken to ensure that the fleet can operate on biodiesel safely and without voiding any manufacturer's warranty.
(8) What steps are being taken to ensure that the department uses biodiesel in the department's fleet of vehicles.

talker.name: Abetz, Sen Eric
Senator Abetz
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: I am replying on behalf of all Ministers.
(1) In 2001-02 and 2002-03, Departments consumed the following amounts of fuel by type:

(2) The extent of petrol blended with fuel ethanol being consumed is not able to be reported as there is no distinction made by fuel producers between unblended unleaded fuel and ethanol blended unleaded fuel in their reporting to the Australian Government's contracted fleet manager.

(3) Following vehicle testing results that showed petrol containing ethanol blends of 20 per cent or more may cause engine problems in some older vehicles, the Minister for Environment and Heritage, the Hon Dr Kemp announced on 11 April 2003 that the Government would move to limit the blend of ethanol in petrol to 10 per cent while tests on the effects of higher blends continued. He also announced mandatory Commonwealth labelling. The amendment to the Fuel Standard (Petrol) Determination 2001, which sets the 10% ethanol limit, was made on 24 April 2003 and gazetted on 7 May 2003. The 10% limit came into force on 1 July 2003. The Government is also working actively with the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries (FCAI) to develop a list of vehicles suitable for E10 use.

As lessees of vehicles, Australian Government Departments must not do anything that may invalidate a manufacturer's vehicle warranty. The Fleet Monitoring Body within the Department of Finance and Administration will continue to monitor the position of relevant manufacturers in relation to E10 fuel to ensure vehicle warranties are maintained.

(4) The Government has in place industry assistance arrangements for the Australian biofuels industry (including ethanol). Fuel purchasing decisions are made by Departments and drivers of their vehicles from retail outlets having regard to convenience factors (location of service stations) and fuel price. Australian Government vehicles are expected to make use of E10 fuel as it becomes widely available in the locations that the vehicles operate.

(7) The Department of the Environment and Heritage has developed an Australian fuel standard for biodiesel as part of its responsibilities under the Fuel Quality Standards Act. The Commonwealth aims to set fuel quality standards that allow for optimum vehicle and environmental performance. The biodiesel standard was approved by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage on 18 September 2003.

As lessees of vehicles, Departments must not do anything that may invalidate a manufacturer's vehicle warranty. The Fleet Monitoring Body within the Department of Finance and Administration will continue to monitor the position of relevant manufacturers in relation to biodiesel to ensure vehicle warranties are maintained.

(8) The Government has in place industry assistance arrangements for the Australian biofuels industry (including biodiesel). Fuel purchasing decisions are made by Departments and drivers of their vehicles from retail outlets having regard to convenience factors (location of service stations) and fuel price. Australian Government vehicles are expected to make use of biodiesel as it becomes widely available in the locations that the vehicles operate.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 16 October 2003:

question.para: With reference to the Interactive Gambling Act 2001:
(1) What is the status of the review required under section 68(1) of the Act.

(2) Given that section 68(3) of the Act requires that a report of the review required under section 68(2) must be tabled within 15 sitting days of its receipt by the Minister, will the Minister undertake to table the report on or before 4 December 2003, being the last scheduled sitting day for 2003.

(3) What is the status of investigations, if any, by the Australian Federal Police into breaches of section 8A(2), which concerns betting after the commencement of sporting events, by overseas wagering operators aggressively targeting Australian punters.

(4) What is the status of investigations, if any, by the Australian Tax Office or other authorities in relation to overseas wagering operators which fail to register for the goods and services tax while aggressively targeting Australian punters and, in some cases, have staff and consultants based in Australia.

(5) Do exemptions or exclusions under the Act override or provide immunity from state and territory laws in relation to the advertising, promotion or conduct of interactive gambling services providers that are not licensed or authorised by those states and territories.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) The Interactive Gambling Act 2001 (IGA) establishes a complaints-based legislative framework to address community concerns about the availability and accessibility of interactive gambling in Australia. The IGA makes it an offence to provide an interactive gambling service to customers in Australia and to advertise an interactive gambling service - including online casino-style services involving games of chance or mixed chance and skill, such as roulette, poker, craps online poker machines and blackjack.

Subsection 68(1) of the IGA requires the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts to cause to be conducted, before 1 July 2003, a review of issues related to the Commonwealth's interactive gambling legislative framework.

On 12 January 2003 the former Minister instructed the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts to conduct the review and consider a broad range of issues, including the operation of the IGA and its effectiveness in dealing with the social and commercial impact of interactive gambling services, among other matters.

In response to a discussion paper, over 40 submissions were received for the review from a wide range of stakeholders. The Allen Consulting Group has also provided research, analysis and other technical supporting material.

Subsection 68(3) requires the Minister to cause copies of the report of the review, once completed, to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House. The Minister expects the Department to provide a report of the review later this year and will table the report in accordance with the requirements of the Act.

(3) The Australian Federal Police (AFP) have advised that they are not currently investigating a complaint concerning a breach of subsection 8A(2) of the IGA. The AFP are investigating, however, the potential breach of sections 15 and 61EA of the Act. These sections prohibit the provision of an interactive gambling service to customers located in Australia and the publication of an interactive gambling service advertisement in Australia respectively. The AFP have advised their investigation of the complaint is currently ongoing.
(4) The Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer informs me that the ATO have advised that there are no specific investigations into this matter.
(5) The IGA does not limit the operation of a law of a state or territory, to the extent that that law is capable of operating concurrently with the IGA. This is reflected in section 69 of the IGA.

subdebateinfo.title: Education, Science and Training: Alternative Dispute Resolution
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2353)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 3 November 2003:

question.para: (1) Does the department use Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) in an effort to avoid litigation; if not, why not; if so, are there specific guidelines for the Department to follow when using ADR.
(2) If the department is not using ADR provisions, what process is used in cases that require resolution.
(3) Has the department been advised of any development of guidelines for the use of ADR.

(4) Does any of the legislation for which the department has responsibility contain ADR procedures; if so, (a) can each relevant provision be identified (eg. by statute name and section number); and (b) are guidelines provided for the use of ADR provisions in these instances; if so, can a copy of the guidelines be provided.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Science and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department is involved in very few disputes where ADR is available as a resolution option. All Departmental standard form contracts include clauses mandating alternative dispute resolution processes to avoid litigation of contractual matters. The Department is also required to comply with the Legal Services Directions issued by the Attorney-General under the Judiciary Act 1903 in relation to all claims and litigation by or against the Commonwealth. In particular, the Directions require the Department to act as a model litigant in handling claims and litigation brought by or against the Department by:
(a) paying legitimate claims without litigation, including making partial settlements of claims or interim payments, where it is clear that liability is at least as much as the amount to be paid; and
(b) endeavouring to avoid litigation wherever possible.

The Directions also require the Department to consider settlements of monetary claims in accordance with legal principle and practice. The Department seeks legal advice in relation to all options whenever a claim is made against it. The Department endeavours to avoid litigation wherever possible.
